column1: 280;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Hemochromatosis ?;"Treatments for hemochromatosis include therapeutic phlebotomy (fleh-BOT-o-me)
column2: iron chelation (ke-LAY-shun) therapy
column3: dietary changes
column4: and treatment for complications.

column1: The goals of treating hemochromatosis include:
Reducing the amount of iron in your body to normal levels
Preventing or delaying organ damage from iron overload
Treating complications of the disease
Maintaining a normal amount of iron in your body for the rest of your life
Therapeutic Phlebotomy
Therapeutic phlebotomy is a procedure that removes blood (and iron) from your body. A needle is inserted into a vein
column2: and your blood flows through an airtight tube into a sterile container or bag.

column1: The process is similar to donating blood; it can be done at blood donation centers
column2: hospital donation centers
column3: or a doctor's office.

column1: In the first stage of treatment
column2: about 1 pint of blood is removed once or twice a week. After your iron levels return to normal
column3: you may continue phlebotomy treatments. However
column4: you may need them less oftentypically every 24 months.

column1: As long as treatment continues
column2: which often is for the rest of your life
column3: you'll need frequent blood tests to check your iron levels.

column1: Iron Chelation Therapy
Iron chelation therapy uses medicine to remove excess iron from your body. This treatment is a good option for people who can't have routine blood removal.

The medicine used in iron chelation therapy is either injected or taken orally (by mouth). Injected iron chelation therapy is done at a doctor's office. Oral iron chelation therapy can be done at home.
Dietary Changes
Your doctor may suggest that you change your diet if you have hemochromatosis. You may be advised to:
Avoid taking iron
column2: including iron pills
column3: iron injections
column4: or multivitamins that contain iron.

column1: Limit your intake of vitamin C. Vitamin C helps your body absorb iron from food. Talk with your doctor about how much vitamin C is safe for you.
Avoid uncooked fish and shellfish. Some fish and shellfish contain bacteria that can cause infections in people who have chronic diseases
column2: such as hemochromatosis.

column1: Limit alcohol intake. Drinking alcohol increases the risk of liver disease. It also can make existing liver disease worse.
Treatment for Complications
Your doctor may prescribe other treatments as needed for complications such as liver disease
column2: heart problems
column3: or diabetes.";Hemochromatosis
column4: an iron overload disorder
column5: can be managed through various treatments. Phlebotomy
column6: a process similar to blood donation
column7: is the primary treatment. Regular removal of blood helps reduce iron levels. Medications
column8: such as deferoxamine
column9: deferiprone
column10: and deferasirox
column11: can also be used to remove excess iron from the body. If the condition is severe
column12: liver transplantation may be considered as a last resort. Regular monitoring of iron levels and liver function is necessary to track progress and adjust treatment accordingly. Lifestyle modifications
column13: including avoiding iron-rich foods and alcohol
column14: can also contribute to managing hemochromatosis.;0.005;353.0;87.0;0.283;0.068;0.197;0.787;-0.057;-0.151;0.037

column1: 281;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Paget's Disease of Bone ?;Enlarged and Misshapen Bones Paget's disease of bone causes affected bones to become enlarged and misshapen. Our bones are living tissue
column2: and our bodies are constantly breaking down old bone and replacing it with new bone. In Paget's disease
column3: however
column4: old bone is broken down and replaced at a faster rate than normal. The new bone is larger and weaker than normal bone. Paget's disease can occur in any bone in the body
column5: but it is most common in the pelvis
column6: spine
column7: skull
column8: and leg bones. It may occur in just one bone or in several bones
column9: but it does not affect the entire skeleton or spread from affected bones to normal bones. Common symptoms include pain
column10: misshapen bones
column11: and a greater chance of broken bones. Complications Paget's disease can also lead to complications
column12: such as arthritis
column13: headaches
column14: hearing loss
column15: or nervous system problems
column16: depending on which bones are affected. If not treated
column17: Paget's disease can reduce a person's ability to perform activities of daily living
column18: thereby reducing quality of life. Although it is the second most common bone disease after osteoporosis
column19: Paget's disease is still uncommon. According to Bone Health and Osteoporosis: A Report of the Surgeon General
column20: an estimated 1 million people in the U.S. have Paget's disease
column21: or about 1.3 people per 100 men and women age 45-74. The disease is more common in older people and those of Northern European heritage. Men are more likely than women to have the disease. Cause is Unknown Paget's disease is named after the British surgeon
column22: Sir James Paget
column23: who first identified the disease in 1877. Researchers are not sure what causes it. Heredity may be a factor in some cases. Research suggests that a close relative of someone with Paget's disease is seven times more likely to develop the disease than someone without an affected relative. However
column24: most people with Paget's disease do not have any relatives with the disease. Researchers think the disease also may be caused by other factors
column25: such as a slow-acting virus. A Treatable Disease The good news is that Paget's disease of bone is treatable
column26: especially if it is diagnosed early. In recent years
column27: the Food and Drug Administration has approved several medications that can stop or slow the disease's progression. In some cases
column28: surgery can help patients manage the symptoms and complications of the disease.;Paget's Disease of Bone is an uncommon chronic bone disorder that affects one or multiple bones. It is characterized by excessive bone breakdown and formation
column29: leading to abnormal bone remodeling. This results in bones that are enlarged
column30: brittle
column31: and weakened. The cause of Paget's disease is unknown
column32: but it is believed to be a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment options may include medications to slow down bone breakdown and formation
column33: pain relievers

column1: 282;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) polycystic kidney disease ?;Polycystic kidney disease is a disorder that affects the kidneys and other organs. Clusters of fluid-filled sacs
column2: called cysts
column3: develop in the kidneys and interfere with their ability to filter waste products from the blood. The growth of cysts causes the kidneys to become enlarged and can lead to kidney failure. Cysts may also develop in other organs
column4: particularly the liver.  Frequent complications of polycystic kidney disease include dangerously high blood pressure (hypertension)
column5: pain in the back or sides
column6: blood in the urine (hematuria)
column7: recurrent urinary tract infections
column8: kidney stones
column9: and heart valve abnormalities. Additionally
column10: people with polycystic kidney disease have an increased risk of an abnormal bulging (an aneurysm) in a large blood vessel called the aorta or in blood vessels at the base of the brain. Aneurysms can be life-threatening if they tear or rupture.  The two major forms of polycystic kidney disease are distinguished by the usual age of onset and the pattern in which it is passed through families. The autosomal dominant form (sometimes called ADPKD) has signs and symptoms that typically begin in adulthood
column11: although cysts in the kidney are often present from birth or childhood. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease can be further divided into type 1 and type 2
column12: depending on the genetic cause. The autosomal recessive form of polycystic kidney disease (sometimes called ARPKD) is much rarer and is often lethal early in life. The signs and symptoms of this condition are usually apparent at birth or in early infancy.;Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of multiple cysts in the kidneys. These cysts are filled with fluid and can enlarge over time
column13: causing the kidneys to become enlarged and unable to function properly. PKD can lead to high blood pressure
column14: kidney failure
column15: and other complications. There are two main types of PKD: autosomal dominant PKD (ADPKD) and autosomal recessive PKD (ARPKD). ADPKD is the more common type and is caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 genes. ARPKD is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene.;0.026;224.0;87.0;0.349;0.141;0.256;0.828;0.101;-0.026;0.231

column1: 283;gemini-pro;considerations;What to do for Urinary Incontinence in Men ?;- Urinary incontinence (UI) is the loss of bladder control
column2: resulting in the accidental leakage of urine from the body.  - The urinary tract is the bodys drainage system for removing urine
column3: which is composed of wastes and extra fluid.  - Every day
column4: the kidneys filter about 120 to 150 quarts of blood to produce about 1 to 2 quarts of urine.  - To urinate
column5: the brain signals the muscular bladder wall to tighten
column6: squeezing urine out of the bladder. At the same time
column7: the brain signals the sphincters to relax. As the sphincters relax
column8: urine exits the bladder through the urethra.  - UI results when the brain does not properly signal the bladder
column9: the sphincters do not squeeze strongly enough
column10: or both.  - Urgency incontinence happens when a man urinates involuntarily after he has a strong desire
column11: or urgency
column12: to urinate.  - Stress incontinence results from movements that put pressure on the bladder and cause urine leakage
column13: such as coughing
column14: sneezing
column15: laughing
column16: or physical activity.  - Functional incontinence occurs when physical disability
column17: external obstacles
column18: or problems in thinking or communicating keep a person from reaching a place to urinate in time.  - When the bladder doesnt empty properly
column20: causing overflow incontinence. Weak bladder muscles or a blocked urethra can cause this type of incontinence.  - Transient incontinence is UI that lasts a short time. Transient incontinence is usually a side effect of certain medications
column21: drugs
column22: or temporary conditions.  - UI occurs in 11 to 34 percent of older men.  - Men should tell a health care professional
column23: such as a family practice physician
column24: a nurse
column25: an internist
column28: even if they feel embarrassed.  - Treatment depends on the type of UI. Some types of treatment include behavioral and lifestyle changes
column29: bladder training
column30: pelvic floor exercises
column31: and urgency suppression.  - People who smoke should stop. Quitting smoking at any age promotes bladder health and overall health.;"1. **Lifestyle Changes:**

column1: - Reduce caffeine and alcohol intake.
- Lose weight if overweight or obese.
- Engage in regular pelvic floor muscle exercises (Kegels).
- Manage underlying medical conditions.
2. **Behavioral Techniques:**
- Double voiding (urinating twice in a row).
- Scheduled voiding (urinating at regular intervals).
- Bladder training (gradually increasing the time between urinations).
3. **Medications:**
- Anticholinergics (e.g.
column2: oxybutynin
column3: tolterodine) to reduce bladder muscle spasms.

column1: - Alpha-adrenergic agonists (e.g.
column2: tamsulosin
column3: alfuzosin) to relax the prostate and bladder neck.

column1: - Mirabegron to increase bladder capacity and reduce urgency.
4. **Medical Devices:**
- Penile clamps or external catheters to prevent leakage.
- Intermittent catheterization to empty the bladder.
5. **Surgical Procedures:**
- Sling procedures (e.g.
column2: male sling
column3: artificial urinary sphincter) to support the urethra and prevent leakage.

column1: - Prostate surgery (e.g.
column2: prostatectomy) for men with enlarged prostate causing urinary incontinence.";0.005;277.0;123.0;0.227;0.026;0.068;0.557;-0.19;-0.166;-0.217

column1: 285;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) mitochondrial complex III deficiency ?;Mitochondrial complex III deficiency is a genetic condition that can affect several parts of the body

column3: kidneys
column4: liver
column5: heart
column6: and the muscles used for movement (skeletal muscles). Signs and symptoms of mitochondrial complex III deficiency usually begin in infancy but can appear later.  The severity of mitochondrial complex III deficiency varies widely among affected individuals. People who are mildly affected tend to have muscle weakness (myopathy) and extreme tiredness (fatigue)
column7: particularly during exercise (exercise intolerance). More severely affected individuals have problems with multiple body systems
column8: such as liver disease that can lead to liver failure
column9: kidney abnormalities (tubulopathy)
column10: and brain dysfunction (encephalopathy). Encephalopathy can cause delayed development of mental and motor skills (psychomotor delay)
column11: movement problems

column13: and difficulty with communication. Some affected individuals have a form of heart disease called cardiomyopathy
column14: which can lead to heart failure. Most people with mitochondrial complex III deficiency have a buildup of a chemical called lactic acid in the body (lactic acidosis). Some affected individuals also have buildup of molecules called ketones (ketoacidosis) or high blood sugar levels (hyperglycemia). Abnormally high levels of these chemicals in the body can be life-threatening.  Mitochondrial complex III deficiency can be fatal in childhood
column15: although individuals with mild signs and symptoms can survive into adolescence or adulthood.;"Mitochondrial complex III deficiency
column16: also known as ubiquinone-cytochrome c reductase deficiency
column17: is a rare genetic disorder that affects the electron transport chain in mitochondria
column18: impairing the ability of cells to produce energy (ATP) through oxidative phosphorylation. This deficiency can manifest in various ways
column19: depending on the severity of the mutation and the tissues affected

column23: and movement disorders; cardiac abnormalities like arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy; and metabolic problems

column1: 286;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Cold Sores ?;Cold sores are caused by a contagious virus called herpes simplex virus (HSV). There are two types of HSV. Type 1 usually causes oral herpes
column2: or cold sores. Type 1 herpes virus infects more than half of the U.S. population by the time they reach their 20s. Type 2 usually affects the genital area     Some people have no symptoms from the infection. But others develop painful and unsightly cold sores. Cold sores usually occur outside the mouth
column3: on or around the lips. When they are inside the mouth
column4: they are usually on the gums or the roof of the mouth. They are not the same as canker sores
column5: which are not contagious.    There is no cure for cold sores. They normally go away on their own in a few weeks. Antiviral medicines can help them heal faster. They can also help to prevent cold sores in people who often get them. Other medicines can help with the pain and discomfort of the sores. These include ointments that numb the blisters
column6: soften the crusts of the sores
column7: or dry them out. Protecting your lips from the sun with sunblock lip balm can also help.;Cold sores

column11: around the mouth

column1: 288;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Multiple myeloma ?;How is multiple myeloma diagnosed? A diagnosis of multiple myeloma may be suspected based on the presence of characteristic signs and symptoms. Additional testing can then be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. This may include: Specialized blood tests including immunoglobulin studies
column2: complete blood count with differential
column3: and blood chemistry studies Urine tests such as immunoglobulin studies and a twenty-four-hour urine test Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy Imaging studies such as an X-ray of the bones (skeletal bone survey)
column4: MRI
column5: CT scan
column6: and/or PET scan The American Cancer Society offers more information regarding the diagnosis of multiple myeloma
column7: including a summary of the many tests that may be recommended. Please click on the link to access this resource. Some affected people may have no suspicious signs or symptoms of multiple myeloma
column8: especially in the early stages of the condition. In these cases
column9: multiple myeloma is sometimes diagnosed by chance when a blood test or urine test is ordered to investigate another condition.;Multiple myeloma is diagnosed through a combination of tests
column10: including blood tests
column11: urine tests
column12: bone marrow aspiration and biopsy
column13: and imaging studies. Blood tests may reveal high levels of monoclonal proteins
column14: such as immunoglobulin light chains or whole immunoglobulins
column15: as well as elevated levels of calcium
column16: creatinine
column17: and beta-2 microglobulin. Urine tests can detect Bence Jones proteins
column18: which are fragments of monoclonal immunoglobulins. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy can reveal the presence of abnormal plasma cells
column19: which are the hallmark of multiple myeloma. Imaging studies
column20: such as X-rays
column21: CT scans
column22: and MRI scans
column23: can detect bone lesions
column24: lytic lesions
column25: and other complications of multiple myeloma. Additional tests may include genetic studies to identify specific genetic abnormalities associated with the disease and cytogenetic analysis to assess the chromosomal abnormalities in the myeloma cells.;0.089;147.0;126.0;0.364;0.132;0.267;0.823;0.093;0.103;0.08

column1: 289;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to leptin receptor deficiency ?;Leptin receptor deficiency is caused by mutations in the LEPR gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called the leptin receptor
column2: which is involved in the regulation of body weight. The leptin receptor protein is found on the surface of cells in many organs and tissues of the body including a part of the brain called the hypothalamus. The hypothalamus controls hunger and thirst as well as other functions such as sleep
column3: moods
column4: and body temperature. It also regulates the release of many hormones that have functions throughout the body.  The leptin receptor is turned on (activated) by a hormone called leptin that attaches (binds) to the receptor
column5: fitting into it like a key into a lock. Normally
column6: the body's fat cells release leptin in proportion to their size. As fat cells become larger
column7: they produce more leptin. This rise in leptin indicates that fat stores are increasing. In the hypothalamus
column8: the binding of leptin to its receptor triggers a series of chemical signals that affect hunger and help produce a feeling of fullness (satiety).  LEPR gene mutations that cause leptin receptor deficiency prevent the receptor from responding to leptin
column9: leading to the excessive hunger and weight gain associated with this disorder. Because hypogonadotropic hypogonadism occurs in leptin receptor deficiency
column10: researchers suggest that leptin receptor signaling is also involved in regulating the body's response to hormones that control sexual development
column11: and that this response is affected by LEPR gene mutations. However
column12: the mechanism of this effect is unknown.  Leptin receptor deficiency is a rare cause of obesity. Researchers are studying the factors involved in more common forms of obesity.;Leptin receptor deficiency is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the LEPR gene
column13: which encodes the leptin receptor. This receptor is responsible for binding leptin

column15: leading to leptin resistance and an inability to respond to the hormone's signals. As a result
column16: individuals with leptin receptor deficiency experience excessive hunger
column17: obesity
column18: and an increased risk of developing metabolic complications such as type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.;0.029;242.0;86.0;0.357;0.108;0.227;0.878;0.118;-0.025;0.267

column1: 295;gemini-pro;outlook;What is the outlook for Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia ?;Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options. The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on:         - How quickly and how low the leukemia cell count drops after the first month of treatment.    - Age at the time of diagnosis
column2: gender
column3: race
column4: and ethnic background.    - The number of white blood cells in the blood at the time of diagnosis.    - Whether the leukemia cells began from B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes.    - Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes or genes of the lymphocytes with cancer.    - Whether the child has Down syndrome.    - Whether leukemia cells are found in the cerebrospinal fluid.    - The child's weight at the time of diagnosis and during treatment.        Treatment options depend on:         - Whether the leukemia cells began from B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes.    - Whether the child has standard-risk
column5: high-risk
column6: or very highrisk ALL.    - The age of the child at the time of diagnosis.    - Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes of lymphocytes
column7: such as the Philadelphia chromosome.    - Whether the child was treated with steroids before the start of induction therapy.    - How quickly and how low the leukemia cell count drops during treatment.        For leukemia that relapses (comes back) after treatment
column8: the prognosis and treatment options depend partly on the following:         - How long it is between the time of diagnosis and when the leukemia comes back.    - Whether the leukemia comes back in the bone marrow or in other parts of the body.;The outlook for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) has improved dramatically over the past few decades. column9: the overall survival rate for children with ALL is now approximately 90%. However

column7: and may be unable to conceive children (infertile).;Leptin receptor deficiency is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the leptin receptor gene (LEPR). This receptor is responsible for transmitting signals from the hormone leptin

column9: body weight
column10: and energy expenditure. In individuals with leptin receptor deficiency
column11: the body is unable to respond to leptin

column14: and severe obesity. This condition can manifest early in life and is often accompanied by additional complications such as metabolic abnormalities

column1: 297;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Snoring ?;Snoring is the sound you make when your breathing is blocked while you are asleep. The sound is caused by tissues at the top of your airway that strike each other and vibrate. Snoring is common
column2: especially among older people and people who are overweight.    When severe
column3: snoring can cause frequent awakenings at night and daytime sleepiness. It can disrupt your bed partner's sleep. Snoring can also be a sign of a serious sleep disorder called sleep apnea. You should see your health care provider if you are often tired during the day
column4: don't feel that you sleep well
column5: or wake up gasping.    To reduce snoring       - Lose weight if you are overweight. It may help
column6: but thin people can snore
column7: too.    - Cut down or avoid alcohol and other sedatives at bedtime    - Don't sleep flat on your back       NIH: National Institute on Aging;Snoring is a common sleep disorder characterized by noisy breathing during sleep. It occurs when the airflow through the throat is obstructed
column8: causing the tissues to vibrate and produce a snoring sound. Snoring can be caused by various factors
column9: including nasal congestion
column10: enlarged tonsils or adenoids
column11: a deviated septum
column12: or obesity. It can also be a sign of more serious conditions such as sleep apnea
column13: in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts during sleep. While snoring is often considered a nuisance

column1: 298;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Rh deficiency syndrome ?;The Rh deficiency syndrome

column3: is a blood disorder where people have red blood cells (RBCs) lacking all Rh antigens. The Rh antigens maintain the integrity of the RBC membrane and therefore
column4: RBCs which lack Rh antigens have an abnormal shape. There are two types of Rh deficiency syndrome: The regulator type is associated with many different changes (mutations) in the RHAG gene .  The amorph type is caused by inactive copies of a gene (silent alleles) at the RH locus. As a result
column5: the RBCs do not express any of the Rh antigens. The absence of the Rh complex alters the RBC shape
column6: increases its tendency to break down (osmotic fragility)
column7: and shortens its lifespan

These patients are at risk of having adverse transfusion reactions because they may produce antibodies against several of the Rh antigens and can only receive blood from people who have the same condition. column11: while the mother has Rh-negative red blood cells. This can lead to the production of antibodies in the mother's body that attack the baby's red blood cells

column15: anemia

column19: and medications to suppress the mother's immune response. Prevention of Rh deficiency syndrome can be achieved through the administration of Rh immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) to Rh-negative mothers during pregnancy and after delivery.;0.073;159.0;122.0;0.245;0.072;0.181;0.74;0.011;-0.029;0.048

column1: How to Contact the Rickettsial Zoonoses Branch at CDC

The general public and healthcare providers should first call 1-800-CDC-INFO (1-800-232-4636) for questions regarding Q fever. If a consultation with a CDC scientist specializing in Q fever is advised
column2: your call will be appropriately forwarded.

column1: Case Definitions
As of January 1
column3: Q fever infections are reported under distinct reporting categories described in the 2009 Q fever surveillance case definition.

column1: 2009 Q Fever Case Definition
Case Report Forms
For confirmed and probable cases of Q fever that have been identified and reported through the National Notifiable Disease Surveillance System
column2: states are also encouraged to submit additional information using the CDC Case Report Form (CRF). This form collects additional important information that routine electronic reporting does not
column3: such as information on how the diagnosis was made
column4: and whether the patient was hospitalized or died. If a different state-specific form is already used to collect this information
column5: this information may be submitted to CDC in lieu of a CRF.

column1: How to Submit Specimens to CDC for Q FeverTesting
Private citizens may not directly submit specimens to CDC for testing. If you feel that diagnostic testing is necessary
column2: consult your healthcare provider or state health department. Laboratory testing is available at many commercial laboratories.

column1: State Health Departments
Specimens may be submitted to CDC for reference testing for Q fever. To coordinate specimen submission
column2: please call 404-639-1075 during business hours (8:00 - 4:30 ET).

column1: U.S. Healthcare Providers

Q fever laboratory testing is available at many commercial laboratories. U.S. healthcare providers should not submit specimens for testing directly to CDC. CDC policy requires that specimens for testing be submitted through or with the approval of the state health department. Please contact your state health department and request assistance with specimen submission and reporting of infection. For general questions about Q fever
column2: please call 1-800-CDC-INFO (1-800-232-4636). If you have questions about a suspect Q fever case
column3: please first consult your state health department. Healthcare providers requiring an epidemiologic or laboratory consultation on Q fever may also call 404-639-1075 during business hours (8:00 - 4:30 ET). Or 770-488-7100 after hours.

column1: Non-U.S. Healthcare Providers
Non-U.S. healthcare providers should consult CDC prior to submitting specimens for testing. For general questions about Q fever
column2: please call 1-800-CDC-INFO (1-800-232-4636). If you would like to discuss a suspect Q fever case with CDC
column3: please call 404-639-1075 during business hours (8:00 - 4:30 ET)
column4: or 770-488-7100 after hours.";Q Fever is a bacterial infection caused by Coxiella burnetii

column1: 313;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Narcolepsy ?;"Narcolepsy has no cure. However
column2: medicines
column3: lifestyle changes
column4: and other therapies can relieve many of its symptoms. Treatment for narcolepsy is based on the type of symptoms you have and how severe they are.

column1: Not all medicines and lifestyle changes work for everyone. It may take weeks to months for you and your doctor to find the best treatment.
Medicines
You may need one or more medicines to treat narcolepsy symptoms. These may include:
Stimulants to ease daytime sleepiness and raise your alertness.

column1: 322;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Hip Replacement;Summary : Hip replacement is surgery for people with severe hip damage. The most common cause of damage is osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis causes pain

column1: 326;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for High Blood Cholesterol ?;"High blood cholesterol is treated with lifestyle changes and medicines. The main goal of treatment is to lower your low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol level enough to reduce your risk for coronary heart disease
column2: heart attack
column3: and other related health problems.

column1: Your risk for heart disease and heart attack goes up as your LDL cholesterol level rises and your number of heart disease risk factors increases.

Some people are at high risk for heart attacks because they already have heart disease. Other people are at high risk for heart disease because they have diabetes or more than one heart disease risk factor.
Talk with your doctor about lowering your cholesterol and your risk for heart disease. Also
column2: check the list to find out whether you have risk factors that affect your LDL cholesterol goal:

column1: Cigarette smoking
High blood pressure (140/90 mmHg or higher)
column2: or youre on medicine to treat high blood pressure

column1: Low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (less than 40 mg/dL)
Family history of early heart disease (heart disease in father or brother before age 55; heart disease in mother or sister before age 65)
Age (men 45 years or older; women 55 years or older)
You can use the NHLBI 10-Year Risk Calculator to find your risk score. The score
column2: given as a percentage
column3: refers to your chance of having a heart attack in the next 10years.

column1: Based on your medical history
column2: number of risk factors
column3: and risk score
column4: figure out your risk of getting heart disease or having a heart attack using the table below.

column1: * Some people in this category are at very high risk because theyve just had a heart attack or they have diabetes and heart disease
column2: severe risk factors
column3: or metabolic syndrome. If youre at very high risk
column4: your doctor may set your LDL goal even lower
column5: to less than 70 mg/dL. Your doctor also may set your LDL goal at this lower level if you have heart disease alone.

column1: After following the above steps
column2: you should have an idea about your risk for heart disease and heart attack. The two main ways to lower your cholesterol (and
column3: thus
column4: your heart disease risk) include:

column1: Therapeutic Lifestyle Changes (TLC). TLC is a three-part program that includes a healthy diet
column2: weight management
column3: and physical activity. TLC is for anyone whose LDL cholesterol level is above goal.

column1: Medicines. If cholesterol-lowering medicines are needed
column2: theyre used with the TLC program to help lower your LDL cholesterol level.

column1: Your doctor will set your LDL goal. The higher your risk for heart disease
column2: the lower he or she will set your LDL goal. Using the following guide
column3: you and your doctor can create a plan for treating your high blood cholesterol.

column1: Category I
column2: high risk
column3: your LDL goal is less than 100 mg/dL.*

column1: * Your LDL goal may be set even lower
column2: to less than 70 mg/dL
column3: if youre at very high risk or if you have heart disease. If you have this lower goal and your LDL is 70 mg/dL or higher
column4: youll need to begin the TLC diet and take medicines as prescribed.

column1: Category II
column2: moderately high risk
column3: your LDL goal is less than 130 mg/dL

column1: Category III
column2: moderate risk
column3: your LDL goal is less than 130 mg/dL.

column1: Category IV
column2: low to moderate risk
column3: your LDL goal is less than 160 mg/dL.

column1: Lowering Cholesterol Using Therapeutic Lifestyle Changes
TLC is a set of lifestyle changes that can help you lower your LDL cholesterol. The main parts of the TLC program are a healthy diet
column2: weight management
column3: and physical activity.

column1: The TLC Diet
With the TLC diet
column2: less than 7 percent of your daily calories should come from saturated fat. This kind of fat is found in some meats
column3: dairy products
column4: chocolate
column5: baked goods
column6: and deep-fried and processed foods.

column1: No more than 25 to 35 percent of your daily calories should come from all fats
column2: including saturated
column3: trans
column4: monounsaturated
column5: and polyunsaturated fats.

column1: You also should have less than 200 mg a day of cholesterol. The amounts of cholesterol and the types of fat in prepared foods can be found on the foods' Nutrition Facts labels.
Foods high in soluble fiber also are part of the TLC diet. They help prevent the digestive tract from absorbing cholesterol. These foods include:
Whole-grain cereals such as oatmeal and oat bran
Fruits such as apples
column2: bananas
column3: oranges
column4: pears
column5: and prunes

column1: Legumes such as kidney beans
column2: lentils
column3: chick peas
column4: black-eyed peas
column5: and lima beans

column1: A diet rich in fruits and vegetables can increase important cholesterol-lowering compounds in your diet. These compounds
column2: called plant stanols or sterols
column3: work like soluble fiber.

column1: A healthy diet also includes some types of fish
column2: such as salmon
column3: tuna (canned or fresh)
column4: and mackerel. These fish are a good source of omega-3 fatty acids. These acids may help protect the heart from blood clots and inflammation and reduce the risk of heart attack. Try to have about two fish meals every week.

column1: You also should try to limit the amount of sodium (salt) that you eat. This means choosing low-salt and ""no added salt"" foods and seasonings at the table or while cooking. The Nutrition Facts label on food packaging shows the amount of sodium in the item.
Try to limit drinks with alcohol. Too much alcohol will raise your blood pressure and triglyceride level. (Triglycerides are a type of fat found in the blood.) Alcohol also adds extra calories
column2: which will cause weight gain.

column1: Men should have no more than two drinks containing alcohol a day. Women should have no more than one drink containing alcohol a day. One drink is a glass of wine
column2: beer
column3: or a small amount of hard liquor.

column1: For more information about TLC
column2: go to the National Heart
column3: Lung
column4: and Blood Institutes (NHLBIs) ""Your Guide to Lowering Your Cholesterol With TLC.""

column1: Weight Management
If youre overweight or obese
column2: losing weight can help lower LDL cholesterol. Maintaining a healthy weight is especially important if you have a condition called metabolic syndrome.

column1: Metabolic syndrome is the name for a group of risk factors that raise your risk for heart disease and other health problems
column2: such as diabetes and stroke.

column1: The five metabolic risk factors are a large waistline (abdominal obesity)
column2: a high triglyceride level
column3: a low HDL cholesterol level
column4: high blood pressure
column5: and high blood sugar. Metabolic syndrome is diagnosed if you have at least three of these metabolic risk factors.

column1: Physical Activity
Routine physical activity can lower LDL cholesterol and triglycerides and raise your HDL cholesterol level.
People gain health benefits from as little as 60 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity per week. The more active you are
column2: the more you will benefit.

column1: For more information about physical activity
column2: go to the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services' ""2008 Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans
column3: the Health Topics Physical Activity and Your Heart article
column4: and the NHLBI's ""Your Guide to Physical Activity and Your Heart.""

column1: Cholesterol-Lowering Medicines
In addition to lifestyle changes
column2: your doctor may prescribe medicines to help lower your cholesterol. Even with medicines
column3: you should continue the TLC program.

column1: Medicines can help control high blood cholesterol
column2: but they dont cure it. Thus
column3: you must continue taking your medicine to keep your cholesterol level in the recommended range.

column1: The five major types of cholesterol-lowering medicines are statins
column2: bile acid sequestrants (seh-KWES-trants)
column3: nicotinic (nick-o-TIN-ick) acid
column4: fibrates
column5: and ezetimibe.

column1: Statins work well at lowering LDL cholesterol. These medicines are safe for most people. Rare side effects include muscle and liver problems.
Bile acid sequestrants also help lower LDL cholesterol. These medicines usually arent prescribed as the only medicine to lower cholesterol. Sometimes theyre prescribed with statins.
Nicotinic acid lowers LDL cholesterol and triglycerides and raises HDL cholesterol. You should only use this type of medicine with a doctors supervision.
Fibrates lower triglycerides

column3: fibrates may increase the risk of muscle problems.

column1: Ezetimibe lowers LDL cholesterol. This medicine works by blocking the intestine from absorbing cholesterol.
While youre being treated for high blood cholesterol
column2: youll need ongoing care. Your doctor will want to make sure your cholesterol levels are controlled. He or she also will want to check for other health problems.

column1: If needed
column2: your doctor may prescribe medicines for other health problems. Take all medicines exactly as your doctor prescribes. The combination of medicines may lower your risk for heart disease and heart attack.

column1: While trying to manage your cholesterol
column2: take steps to manage other heart disease risk factors too. For example
column3: if you have high blood pressure
column4: work with your doctor to lower it.

column1: If you smoke
column2: quit. Talk with your doctor about programs and products that can help you quit smoking. Also
column3: try to avoid secondhand smoke. If youre overweight or obese
column4: try to lose weight. Your doctor can help you create a reasonable weight-loss plan.";"High blood cholesterol is a condition in which there is too much cholesterol in the blood. It is a major risk factor for heart disease
column5: stroke
column6: and other health problems. Treatment for high blood cholesterol typically includes lifestyle changes
column7: such as eating a healthy diet
column8: getting regular exercise
column9: and losing weight; and medication
column10: such as statins

column1: 330;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to spastic paraplegia type 8 ?;Mutations in the KIAA0196 gene cause spastic paraplegia type 8. The KIAA0196 gene provides instructions for making a protein called strumpellin. Strumpellin is active (expressed) throughout the body
column2: although its exact function is unknown. The protein's structure suggests that strumpellin may interact with the structural framework inside cells (the cytoskeleton) and may attach (bind) to other proteins.  KIAA0196 gene mutations are thought to change the structure of the strumpellin protein. It is unknown how the altered strumpellin protein causes the signs and symptoms of spastic paraplegia type 8.;Spastic paraplegia type 8 (SPG8) is caused by mutations in the NIPA1 gene
column3: which encodes a protein involved in neuronal survival and development. Mutations in this gene lead to a loss of function of the NIPA1 protein
column4: resulting in the degeneration of motor neurons and the development of spasticity and weakness in the lower limbs. The genetic changes associated with SPG8 are predominantly missense mutations
column5: which result in the substitution of a single amino acid in the NIPA1 protein. These mutations disrupt the normal structure and function of the protein
column6: leading to the neurological symptoms characteristic of SPG8.;0.045;77.0;84.0;0.318;0.054;0.206;0.689;0.114;0.098;0.126

column1: 331;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Imerslund-Grsbeck syndrome ?;Mutations in the AMN or CUBN gene can cause Imerslund-Grsbeck syndrome. The AMN gene provides instructions for making a protein called amnionless
column2: and the CUBN gene provides instructions for making a protein called cubilin. Together
column3: these proteins play a role in the uptake of vitamin B12 from food. Vitamin B12
column4: which cannot be made in the body and can only be obtained from food
column5: is essential for the formation of DNA and proteins
column6: the production of cellular energy
column7: and the breakdown of fats. This vitamin is involved in the formation of red blood cells and maintenance of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system).  The amnionless protein is embedded primarily in the membrane of kidney cells and cells that line the small intestine. Amnionless attaches (binds) to cubilin
column8: anchoring cubilin to the cell membrane. Cubilin can interact with molecules and proteins passing through the intestine or kidneys. During digestion
column9: vitamin B12 is released from food. As the vitamin passes through the small intestine
column10: cubilin binds to it. Amnionless helps transfer the cubilin-vitamin B12 complex into the intestinal cell. From there
column11: the vitamin is released into the blood and transported throughout the body. In the kidney
column12: the amnionless and cubilin proteins are involved in the reabsorption of certain proteins that would otherwise be released in urine.  Mutations in the AMN gene prevent cubilin from attaching to the cells in the small intestine and kidneys. Without cubilin function in the small intestine
column13: vitamin B12 is not taken into the body. A shortage of this essential vitamin impairs the proper development of red blood cells
column14: leading to megaloblastic anemia. Low levels of vitamin B12 can also affect the central nervous system
column15: causing neurological problems. In addition
column16: without cubilin function in the kidneys
column17: proteins are not reabsorbed and are instead released in urine
column18: leading to proteinuria.  Like AMN gene mutations
column19: some CUBN gene mutations impair cubilin's function in both the small intestine and the kidneys
column20: leading to a shortage of vitamin B12 and proteinuria. Other CUBN gene mutations affect cubilin's function only in the small intestine
column21: impairing uptake of vitamin B12 into the intestinal cells. Individuals with these mutations have a shortage of vitamin B12
column22: which can lead to megaloblastic anemia and neurological problems
column23: but not proteinuria.;Imerslund-Grsbeck syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by selective vitamin B12 malabsorption due to mutations in the CUBN gene
column24: which encodes the cubilin protein. Cubilin is a receptor expressed in the proximal tubules of the kidney and the ileum that is involved in the uptake of vitamin B12 from the gastrointestinal tract and its reabsorption in the kidneys. Mutations in the CUBN gene lead to impaired vitamin B12 absorption

column1: 332;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Oral lichen planus ?;How might oral lichen planus be treated? column2: antibiotics
column3: arsenic
column4: iodides
column5: chloroquine
column6: quinacrine
column7: quinidine
column8: antimony
column9: phenothiazines
column10: diuretics such as chlorothiazide
column11: and many others.[2483] Consideration regarding role of drugs that were started in recent months prior to the on set of oral lichen planus
column12: as well as any contact allergens identified by patch testing is recommended. Symptoms may improve with the following measures: Meticulous oral hygiene Stopping smoking Topical steroids as drops
column13: pastes
column14: gels or sprays (e.g.
column15: triamcinolone paste) Steroid injections (intralesional triamcinolone) Mouth rinse containing the calcineurin inhibitors: cyclosporin or tacrolimus In severe cases systemic corticosteroids may be used. Other possible therapeutic agents may include: Thalidomide Systemic retinoids (acitretin or isotretinoin) Griseofulvin Azathioprine Cyclophosphamide Dapsone Metronidazole Low molecular weight heparin;Oral lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory condition that affects the oral mucosa. Treatment options aim to manage symptoms and prevent complications. First-line treatments include topical corticosteroids
column16: such as clobetasol or fluocinonide

column20: such as avoiding triggers like certain foods or stress

Regular monitoring by a healthcare professional is essential to assess treatment response and prevent long-term complications.;0.048;143.0;108.0;0.277;0.066;0.195;0.736;-0.057;-0.174;0.063

column1: 333;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Desmoplastic infantile ganglioglioma ?;What treatment is available for desmoplastic infantile gangliomas? Surgical resection (removal of the area of the brain with the tumor) has been the standard treatment reported in the medical literature. The size of the resection is probably based on the size of the tumor
column2: although the extent of the resection is not documented for all cases reported in the medical literature. Adjuvant therapy is generally not performed when a gross total resection can be performed. When total resection is not possible
column3: some of suggested chemotherapy
column4: as the effects of radiation on extremely young children may be harmful.;Desmoplastic infantile ganglioglioma (DIG) is a rare brain tumor that typically affects infants and young children. There is no standard treatment for DIG

column6: chemotherapy
column7: radiation therapy

column1: 334;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Paranasal Sinus and Nasal Cavity Cancer ?;"New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.
Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.
Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.
For some patients
column2: taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice. Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process. Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.   Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials. Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.   Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future. Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments
column3: they often answer important questions and help move research forward.

column1: Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.

column1: Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment. Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better. There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.   Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country. See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials. These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.";Clinical trials are actively investigating new treatment strategies for paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer
column2: including targeted therapies
column3: immunotherapy
column4: and novel radiation techniques. Researchers are exploring the use of targeted drugs that block specific molecules involved in cancer growth and survival. Immunotherapy approaches aim to harness the body's immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells. Additionally
column5: clinical trials are evaluating the effectiveness of intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) and proton therapy in improving treatment outcomes while minimizing side effects. Ongoing research is also focused on identifying biomarkers that can predict treatment response and prognosis
column6: enabling personalized treatment plans for patients with paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.;0.011;234.0;104.0;0.211;0.034;0.126;0.363;-0.076;-0.065;-0.091

column1: 335;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Dry Eye ?;If your eyes dont make enough tears it can cause dry eye. Anything that changes the components of tears can cause dry eye. Many factors can lead to dry eye
column2: including aging
column3: medications
column4: problems with eyelid function
column5: disease
column6: some types of eye surgery
column7: environmental factors
column8: and allergies.;Dry eye disease is a condition in which the eyes do not produce enough tears to keep them moist and lubricated. Tears are essential for maintaining a healthy ocular surface and protecting the eyes from infection and irritation. Causes of dry eye can include age-related changes
column9: hormonal changes
column10: certain medical conditions
column11: medications
column12: environmental factors
column13: and lifestyle choices. Common causes include conditions such as blepharitis
column14: meibomian gland dysfunction
column15: Sjogren's syndrome
column16: and certain medications like antihistamines and antidepressants. Additionally
column17: environmental factors like wind
column19: and smoke can contribute to dry eyes
column20: as well as prolonged screen time and contact lens wear.;0.029;46.0;96.0;0.269;0.075;0.192;0.834;0.126;0.284;-0.026

column1: 337;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Fibrous dysplasia ?;How might fibrous dysplasia be treated? Unfortunately
column2: there is no cure for fibrous dysplasia. Treatment depends on the symptoms that develop. Fractures often require surgery
column3: but can sometimes be treated with casting or splints.] Surgery is most appropriate in cases where fractures are likely to occur
column4: or where bones have become misshapen. Surgery may also be used to relieve pain. Medications known as bisphosphonates are also used to relieve bone pain. Other healthy strategies such as physical activity and adequate intake of calcium
column5: phosphorus
column6: and vitamin D are also encouraged.[  Radiation therapy is not recommended for patients with fibrous dysplasia because it is associated with an increased risk of cancerous transformation. Careful
column7: long-term follow-up to monitor fibrous dysplasia is advised.;Fibrous dysplasia
column8: a bone disorder characterized by the abnormal growth of fibrous tissue within the bone
column9: can be managed through various treatment approaches. Treatment options may include medications
column10: such as bisphosphonates
column11: to reduce bone pain and prevent further bone loss. Surgery is sometimes necessary to correct bone deformities
column12: relieve pressure on nerves or blood vessels
column13: or remove weakened bone segments. Physical therapy and rehabilitation can help improve muscle strength and range of motion
column14: while bracing or casting can provide support and stability to affected areas. In severe cases
column15: targeted radiation therapy may be used to control excessive bone growth. Additionally
column16: medications like pamidronate or zoledronic acid can help reduce bone pain and prevent fractures. Ongoing monitoring and regular check-ups are essential to assess the effectiveness of treatment and make any necessary adjustments.;0.028;118.0;128.0;0.345;0.069;0.172;0.863;0.108;0.111;0.102

column1: 338;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Salivary Gland Cancer ?;Tests that examine the head
column2: neck
column3: and the inside of the mouth are used to detect (find) and diagnose salivary gland cancer. The following procedures may be used:         -  Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health. The head
column4: neck
column5: mouth
column6: and throat will be checked for signs of disease
column7: such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual. A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.    -   MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet
column8: radio waves
column9: and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body. This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).    -   CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body
column10: taken from different angles. The pictures are made by a computer linked to an x-ray machine. A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly. This procedure is also called computed tomography
column11: computerized tomography
column12: or computerized axial tomography.     -   PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body. A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein. The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body. Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.    -   Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas. For salivary gland cancer
column13: an endoscope is inserted into the mouth to look at the mouth
column14: throat
column15: and larynx. An endoscope is a thin
column16: tube-like instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.     -   Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.               -  Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle. An FNA is the most common type of biopsy used for salivary gland cancer.      -  Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue that doesnt look normal.      -  Surgery : If cancer cannot be diagnosed from the sample of tissue removed during an FNA biopsy or an incisional biopsy
column17: the mass may be removed and checked for signs of cancer.                 Because salivary gland cancer can be hard to diagnose
column18: patients should ask to have the tissue samples checked by a pathologist who has experience in diagnosing salivary gland cancer.;Diagnosing salivary gland cancer involves a comprehensive approach. It typically starts with a thorough physical examination of the head and neck area
column19: followed by imaging tests such as MRI or CT scans to assess the extent and location of the tumor. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy or core needle biopsy is often performed to extract cells from the suspicious mass for microscopic examination by a pathologist. Additional tests may include blood tests to evaluate tumor markers and rule out other conditions. In some cases
column20: specialized imaging techniques like PET scans or salivary gland scintigraphy may be recommended to further evaluate the extent of the disease. A definitive diagnosis is usually confirmed through a surgical biopsy
column21: where a portion of the tumor is removed and analyzed under a microscope.;0.005;381.0;112.0;0.291;0.047;0.153;0.746;-0.048;-0.151;0.057

column1: 339;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is galactosemia inherited ?;This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern
column2: which means both copies of the gene in each cell have mutations. The parents of an individual with an autosomal recessive condition each carry one copy of the mutated gene
column3: but they typically do not show signs and symptoms of the condition.;Yes
column4: galactosemia is an inherited disorder caused by a genetic mutation that leads to the body's inability to properly metabolize the sugar galactose. This mutation is passed down from parents to children through their genes
column5: and individuals who inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) will have galactosemia. The inheritance pattern of galactosemia is autosomal recessive
column6: meaning that both copies of the gene must be mutated in order for the disorder to manifest.;0.067;44.0;69.0;0.391;0.13;0.207;0.569;0.197;0.302;0.094

column1: 340;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Breast Reconstruction;Summary : If you need a mastectomy
column2: you have a choice about whether or not to have surgery to rebuild the shape of the breast. Instead of breast reconstruction
column3: you could choose to wear a breast form that replaces the breast
column4: wear padding inside your bra
column5: or do nothing. All of these options have pros and cons. What is right for one woman may not be right for another.    Breast reconstruction may be done at the same time as the mastectomy
column6: or it may be done later on. If radiation therapy is part of the treatment plan
column7: your doctor may suggest waiting until after radiation therapy.    If you're thinking about breast reconstruction
column8: talk to a plastic surgeon before the mastectomy
column9: even if you plan to have your reconstruction later on.    A surgeon can reconstruct the breast in many ways. Some women choose to have breast implants
column10: which are filled with saline or silicone gel. Another method uses tissue taken from another part of your body. The plastic surgeon can take skin
column11: muscle
column12: and fat from your lower abdomen
column13: back
column14: or buttocks.    The type of reconstruction that is best for you depends on your age
column15: body type
column16: and the type of cancer surgery that you had. A plastic surgeon can help you decide.    NIH: National Cancer Institute;Breast reconstruction is a surgical procedure that aims to restore the shape and appearance of the breast after mastectomy
column17: a surgery to remove breast tissue
column18: typically performed due to breast cancer. The goal of breast reconstruction is to create a breast mound that resembles the natural breast in size
column20: and symmetry. There are various techniques available for breast reconstruction
column21: including implant-based reconstruction
column22: autologous reconstruction (using the patient's own tissue)
column23: and a combination of both. Reconstruction can be performed immediately after mastectomy or at a later stage. Factors such as the extent of the mastectomy
column24: the patient's overall health
column25: and personal preferences influence the choice of reconstruction technique. Breast reconstruction can have a positive impact on a woman's physical and emotional well-being
column26: helping to improve self-esteem and body image after breast cancer treatment.;0.017;198.0;117.0;0.289;0.042;0.171;0.756;0.06;-0.009;0.127

column1: 341;gemini-pro;considerations;What to do for What I need to know about Kidney Failure and How Its Treated ?;"Eating healthy foods can help you keep up your energy and strength. All dialysis and transplant centers have a dietitian. The dietitian helps people with kidney failure learn about healthy food choices. You should talk with your centers dietitian to make a meal plan.
The best diet for you will depend on which kidney failure treatment you choose after talking with your doctor.
- Hemodialysis      - Limit how much liquid and water you drink. Fluid can build up in your body between hemodialysis sessions. Also
column2: many foods contain water. The extra fluid in your body can cause swelling and high blood pressure. Extra fluid in your body makes your heart work harder.

column1: -      - Limit sodium
column2: or salt. Watch out for sodium in frozen foods and prepared meals. You can also find sodium in canned foods
column3: hot dogs
column4: and fast food. Sodium makes you thirsty
column5: which makes you drink more water and other liquids than you should.    - Read more in the National Kidney Disease Education Program (NKDEP) fact sheet Sodium.    - Limit potassium. Potassium is found in many fruits and vegetables such as potatoes
column6: tomatoes
column7: oranges
column8: and bananas. Too much potassium can make your heart beat unevenly. Hemodialysis does not remove potassium from your body well.    - Read more in the NKDEP fact sheet Potassium.    - Eat protein-rich foods such as meat
column9: fish
column10: and eggs. Hemodialysis removes protein from your body.    - Read more in the NKDEP fact sheet Protein.    - Limit phosphorus. Phosphorus helps your bones
column11: blood vessels
column12: and muscles work.    - However
column13: too much phosphorus can make your bones weak. Limiting phosphorus can be hard. Foods that contain phosphorus
column14: such as meat and milk
column15: also contain protein that you need. You should be careful to eat enough protein
column16: yet not so much that you get too much phosphorus. You can avoid other foods that contain phosphorus
column17: such as cola
column20: and nuts.    - Read more in the NKDEP fact sheet Phosphorus.    - Find healthy ways to add calories to your diet. Calories are found in all foods and give your body energy. column31: Eat Right to Feel Right on Hemodialysis.    - Peritoneal dialysis      - Drink as much water and other liquids as you need. If you are holding too much fluid or too little fluid

column1: -      - You may need to eat more potassium-rich foods. Peritoneal dialysis removes potassium from your body. column1: -      - Eat protein-rich foods to repair muscle breakdown and protect against infection.    - You may need to limit your calories. The medicines you take can make you gain weight.    - Conservative management      - Limit protein to prevent the buildup of wastes in your blood.

column1: 350;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is renal tubular acidosis with deafness inherited ?;This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern

column4: renal tubular acidosis with deafness (RTAD) can be inherited. There are two main types of inherited RTAD: autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive. column1: 353;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) glycogen storage disease type VI ?;"Glycogen storage disease type VI (also known as GSDVI or Hers disease) is an inherited disorder caused by an inability to break down a complex sugar called glycogen in liver cells. A lack of glycogen breakdown interferes with the normal function of the liver.  The signs and symptoms of GSDVI typically begin in infancy to early childhood. The first sign is usually an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). Affected individuals may also have low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) or a buildup of lactic acid in the body (lactic acidosis) during prolonged periods without food (fasting).  The signs and symptoms of GSDVI tend to improve with age; most adults with this condition do not have any related health problems.";Glycogen storage disease type VI (GSD VI)

column6: growth retardation
column7: and ketosis. GSD VI can be managed with a high-protein
column8: low-carbohydrate diet
column9: frequent small meals
column10: and cornstarch or other glucose-containing snacks to prevent hypoglycemia.;0.106;103.0;92.0;0.411;0.162;0.312;0.889;0.18;0.164;0.193

column19: making it easier for bacteria to reach the bladder. Also
column20: the bowel and urethral openings are closer together in women than in men
column21: making it easier for E. coli (a bacteria that lives in the bowel) to travel from the bowel to the urethra. Many women suffer from frequent UTIs. Some women have 3 or more UTIs a year. However
column22: very few women will have frequent UTIs throughout their lives. More typically
column23: a woman will have a period of 1 or 2 years with frequent UTIs. After this period
column24: the UTIs may stop or happen less often. Older women are more likely to get UTIs because the bladder muscles weaken and make it hard to fully empty the bladder. This causes urine to stay in the bladder. When urine stays in the bladder too long
column25: it makes an infection more likely. UTIs in Men Men are less likely than women to have a first UTI. But once a man has a UTI
column26: he is likely to have another. Bacteria from a UTI can spread to the prostate. Once there
column27: the bacteria can hide deep inside prostate tissue. Prostate infections are hard to cure because antibiotics may not be able to reach the infected prostate tissue. Activities That Can Increase Risk - Having sex. Sexual activity can move bacteria from the bowel or vaginal cavity to the urethral opening. Urinating after sex lowers the risk of infection.  - Using a catheter to urinate. A catheter is a tube placed in the urethra and bladder to help people empty the bladder. The catheter can make a direct path for bacteria to reach the bladder.  - Using certain birth controls. Diaphragms can bring bacteria with them when they are placed. column1: 357;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Narcolepsy ?;There is no cure for narcolepsy. In 1999

column3: the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved a drug called modafinil for the treatment of EDS. Two classes of antidepressant drugs have proved effective in controlling cataplexy in many patients: tricyclics (including imipramine
column4: desipramine
column5: clomipramine
column6: and protriptyline) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (including fluoxetine and sertraline). Drug therapy should be supplemented by behavioral strategies. For example
column7: many people with narcolepsy take short
column8: regularly scheduled naps at times when they tend to feel sleepiest. Improving the quality of nighttime sleep can combat EDS and help relieve persistent feelings of fatigue. Among the most important common-sense measures people with narcolepsy can take to enhance sleep quality are actions such as maintaining a regular sleep schedule
column9: and avoiding alcohol and caffeine-containing beverages before bedtime. The drug Xyrem (sodium oxybate or gamma hydroxybutyrate
column10: also known as GHB) was approved in July 2002 for treating cataplexy and in November 2005 for EDS in people who have narcolepsy. Due to safety concerns associated with the use of this drug
column11: the distribution of Xyrem is tightly restricted.;Narcolepsy
column12: a chronic sleep disorder
column13: can be managed through a combination of lifestyle adjustments
column14: medications
column15: and behavioral therapies. Lifestyle modifications involve maintaining a regular sleep schedule
column16: avoiding caffeine and alcohol
column17: and creating a conducive sleep environment. Medications
column18: such as stimulants like modafinil or methylphenidate
column19: can help improve wakefulness during the day and reduce excessive daytime sleepiness. Additionally
column20: sodium oxybate may be prescribed to help with nighttime sleep and reduce cataplexy

column1: 358;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) vitiligo ?;"Vitiligo is a condition that causes patchy loss of skin coloring (pigmentation). The average age of onset of vitiligo is in the mid-twenties
column2: but it can appear at any age. It tends to progress over time
column3: with larger areas of the skin losing pigment. Some people with vitiligo also have patches of pigment loss affecting the hair on their scalp or body.  Researchers have identified several forms of vitiligo. Generalized vitiligo (also called nonsegmental vitiligo)
column4: which is the most common form
column5: involves loss of pigment (depigmentation) in patches of skin all over the body. Depigmentation typically occurs on the face
column6: neck
column7: and scalp
column8: and around body openings such as the mouth and genitals. Sometimes pigment is lost in mucous membranes
column9: such as the lips. Loss of pigmentation is also frequently seen in areas that tend to experience rubbing
column10: impact
column11: or other trauma
column12: such as the hands
column13: arms
column14: and places where bones are close to the skin surface (bony prominences). Another form called segmental vitiligo is associated with smaller patches of depigmented skin that appear on one side of the body in a limited area; this occurs in about 10 percent of affected individuals.  Vitiligo is generally considered to be an autoimmune disorder. Autoimmune disorders occur when the immune system attacks the body's own tissues and organs. In people with vitiligo the immune system appears to attack the pigment cells (melanocytes) in the skin. About 15 to 25 percent of people with vitiligo are also affected by at least one other autoimmune disorder
column15: particularly autoimmune thyroid disease
column16: rheumatoid arthritis
column17: type 1 diabetes
column20: Addison disease
column21: or systemic lupus erythematosus.  In the absence of other autoimmune conditions
column22: vitiligo does not affect general health or physical functioning. However
column23: concerns about appearance and ethnic identity are significant issues for many affected individuals.";Vitiligo is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by the loss of pigment in patches of skin
column24: resulting in white or lighter patches on the skin. The condition is caused by the destruction of melanocytes
column25: the cells responsible for producing melanin
column26: the pigment that gives skin its color. Vitiligo can affect people of all ages
column28: and genders
column29: and can occur on any part of the body
column30: although it most commonly affects areas exposed to the sun
column31: such as the face
column32: hands
column33: and arms. The exact cause of vitiligo is unknown
column34: but it is thought to be related to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment options for vitiligo vary depending on the individual and the extent of the condition
column35: and may include topical or oral medications

column1: 362;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to familial hemiplegic migraine ?;Mutations in the CACNA1A
column2: ATP1A2
column3: SCN1A
column4: and PRRT2 genes have been found to cause familial hemiplegic migraine. The first three genes provide instructions for making proteins that are involved in the transport of charged atoms (ions) across cell membranes. The movement of these ions is critical for normal signaling between nerve cells (neurons) in the brain and other parts of the nervous system. The function of the protein produced from the PRRT2 gene is unknown
column5: although studies suggest it interacts with a protein that helps control signaling between neurons.  Communication between neurons depends on chemicals called neurotransmitters
column6: which are released from one neuron and taken up by neighboring neurons. Researchers believe that mutations in the CACNA1A
column7: ATP1A2
column8: and SCN1A genes can upset the balance of ions in neurons
column9: which disrupts the normal release and uptake of certain neurotransmitters in the brain. Although the mechanism is unknown
column10: researchers speculate that mutations in the PRRT2 gene
column11: which reduce the amount of PRRT2 protein
column12: also disrupt normal control of neurotransmitter release. The resulting changes in signaling between neurons lead people with familial hemiplegic migraine to develop these severe headaches.  There is little evidence that mutations in the CACNA1A
column13: ATP1A2
column14: SCN1A
column15: and PRRT2 genes play a role in common migraines
column16: which affect millions of people each year. Researchers are searching for additional genetic changes that may underlie rare types of migraine
column17: such as familial hemiplegic migraine
column18: as well as the more common forms of migraine.;Familial hemiplegic migraine (FHM) is a rare subtype of migraine with aura characterized by hemiparesis or other focal neurological symptoms that precede or accompany the headache. FHM is caused by mutations in three genes: CACNA1A
column20: and SCN1A. CACNA1A encodes the alpha-1A subunit of the voltage-gated calcium channel Cav2.1
column21: which is expressed in neurons and smooth muscle cells. ATP1A2 encodes the alpha-2 subunit of the sodium-potassium ATPase pump
column22: which is responsible for maintaining the sodium and potassium gradients across cell membranes. SCN1A encodes the alpha-1 subunit of the voltage-gated sodium channel Nav1.1
column23: which is expressed in neurons and is responsible for the initiation and propagation of action potentials. Mutations in these genes can lead to changes in the function of these ion channels
column24: resulting in neuronal hyperexcitability and the development of migraine attacks.;0.03;220.0;121.0;0.322;0.1;0.181;0.806;0.022;0.041;0.0

column1: 364;gemini-pro;symptoms;What are the symptoms of McCune Albright syndrome ?;"What are the signs and symptoms of McCune Albright syndrome? People with McCune Albright syndrome (MAS) may have symptoms related to bones
column2: the endocrine system
column3: and/or skin. The symptoms can range from mild to severe. Bone symptoms may include: Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia: This is when normal bone is replaced by softer
column4: fibrous tissue. Polyostotic means the abnormal areas may occur in many bones; often they are confined to one side of the body. Replacement of bone with fibrous tissue may lead to fractures
column5: uneven growth
column6: and deformity. When it occurs in skull and jaw it can result in uneven growth of the face. This may also occur in the long bones; uneven growth of leg bones may cause limping. Abnormal curvature of the spine (scoliosis) Cancer: Bone lesions may become cancerous
column7: but this happens in less than 1% of people with MAS. Endocrine symptoms may include: Early puberty: Girls with MAS usually reach puberty early. They often have menstrual bleeding by age 2 (as early as 4-6 months in some)
column8: many years before characteristics such as breast enlargement and pubic hair growth are evident. This early onset of menstruation is believed to be caused by excess estrogen
column9: a female sex hormone produced by cysts that develop in one of the ovaries. Less commonly
column10: boys with MAS may also experience early puberty. Enlarged thyroid gland: The thyroid gland may become enlarged (a condition called a goiter) or develop masses called nodules. About half of affected individuals produce excessive amounts of thyroid hormone (hyperthyroidism)
column11: resulting in a fast heart rate
column12: high blood pressure
column13: weight loss
column14: tremors
column15: sweating
column16: and other symptoms. Increased production of growth hormone: The pituitary gland may produce too much growth hormone. This can result in acromegaly
column17: a condition characterized by large hands and feet
column19: and distinctive facial features that are often described as ""coarse."" Cushings syndrome: Rarely
column20: individuals with MAS produce too much of the hormone cortisol in the adrenal glands. Cushing's syndrome causes weight gain in the face and upper body
column21: slowed growth in children
column22: fragile skin
column23: fatigue
column24: and other health problems. Skin symptoms may include: Cafe-au-lait spots: Individuals with MAS usually have light brown patches of skin called cafe-au-lait spots. Like the bone lesions

column1: 367;gemini-pro;treatment;how can botulism be treated?;The respiratory failure and paralysis that occur with severe botulism may require a patient to be on a breathing machine (ventilator) for weeks or months

column4: antitoxin can prevent worsening and shorten recovery time. Physicians may try to remove contaminated food still in the gut by inducing vomiting or by using enemas. Wounds should be treated

column1: 368;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Diabetes ?;Studies have shown that most people with prediabetes develop type 2 diabetes within a few years
column2: unless they change their lifestyle. Most people with prediabetes dont have any symptoms. Your doctor can test your blood to find out if your blood glucose levels are higher than normal. Losing weightat least 5 to 10 percent of your starting weightcan prevent or delay diabetes or even reverse prediabetes. Thats 10 to 20 pounds for someone who weighs 200 pounds. You can lose weight by cutting the amount of calories and fat you consume and by being physically active at least 30 to 60 minutes every day. Physical activity also helps your body use the hormone insulin properly. Your body needs insulin to use glucose for energy. Medicine can help control the amount of glucose in your blood. Ask your doctor if medicine to control glucose is right for you. Learn more about prediabetes here.;Diabetes is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by elevated blood sugar levels. There are two main types of diabetes: type 1 and type 2. In type 1 diabetes
column3: the body's immune system attacks and destroys the beta cells in the pancreas
column4: which produce insulin. Insulin is a hormone that helps glucose
column5: or sugar
column6: enter cells for energy. Without insulin
column7: glucose builds up in the blood and can lead to serious complications. In type 2 diabetes
column8: the body does not produce enough insulin or does not use insulin well. This can also lead to high blood sugar levels and complications.;0.016;148.0;92.0;0.302;0.027;0.151;0.617;-0.055;-0.146;0.036
