column1: 384;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Prosthetic joint infection ?;A prosthetic joint infection (PJI) is a rare complication of joint replacement surgery
column2: also known as arthroplasty.  Arthroplasty is done to help relieve pain and restore function in a severely diseased joint
column3: such as a knee
column4: hip or shoulder.  Approximately 0.5 to 1 percent of people with replacement joints develop a PJI.  Infections can occur early in the course of recovery from joint replacement surgery (within the first two months) or much later.  Signs and symptoms of PJI include fever
column5: chills
column6: drainage from the surgical site
column7: and increasing redness
column8: tenderness
column9: swelling and pain of the affected joint.  Prosthetic joint infections are often hard to treat because of the development of a structure called a biofilm within the joint. A biofilm develops when bacteria adhere to the solid surface of the artificial joint. The biofilm can act as a kind of shield to some of the bacteria
column10: making it difficult for the bacteria to be found and destroyed by the body's defenses or by antibiotic medications. An infected joint replacement usually requires surgery to remove the artificial parts and potent antibiotics to kill the bacteria.;Prosthetic joint infection (PJI) is a severe complication following joint replacement surgery
column11: characterized by the presence of microorganisms within the prosthetic joint and surrounding tissues. PJI can be caused by a variety of bacteria
column12: including Staphylococcus aureus
column13: coagulase-negative staphylococci

column15: swelling
column16: redness
column17: and warmth around the affected joint. PJI can lead to significant morbidity

column1: 385;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Prostate Cancer ?;Scientists continue to look at new ways to prevent
column2: treat
column3: and diagnose prostate cancer. Research has already led to a number of advances in these areas. Dietary Research Several studies are under way to explore the causes of prostate cancer. Some researchers think that diet may affect a man's chances of developing prostate cancer. For example
column4: some studies show that prostate cancer is more common in populations that consume a high-fat diet
column5: particularly animal fat
column6: and in populations with diets that lack certain nutrients. Research on Testosterone Some research suggests that high levels of testosterone may increase a man's risk of prostate cancer. The difference in prostate cancer risk among racial groups could be related to high testosterone levels
column7: but it also could result from diet or other lifestyle factors. Genetic Research Researchers are studying changes in genes that may increase the risk for developing prostate cancer. Some studies are looking at the genes of men who were diagnosed with prostate cancer at a relatively young age
column8: such as less than 55 years old
column9: and the genes of families who have several members with the disease. Other studies are trying to identify which genes
column10: or arrangements of genes
column11: are most likely to lead to prostate cancer. Much more work is needed
column12: however
column13: before scientists can say exactly how genetic changes relate to prostate cancer. Prevention Research Several studies have explored ways to prevent prostate cancer. In October 2008
column14: initial results of a study on the use of the dietary supplements vitamin E and selenium found that they did not provide any benefit in reducing the number of new cases of the disease. A few studies suggest that a diet that regularly includes tomato-based foods may help protect men from prostate cancer
column15: but there are no studies that conclusively prove this hypothesis. According to results of a study that was re-analyzed in 2013
column16: men who took finasteride
column17: a drug that affects male hormone levels
column18: reduced their chances of getting prostate cancer by nearly 30 percent compared to men who took a placebo. Unlike earlier findings from this study
column19: this new analysis showed no increased risk of late stage disease due to use of finasteride. Stopping Prostate Cancer from Returning Scientists are also looking at ways to stop prostate cancer from returning in men who have already been treated for the disease. These approaches use drugs such as finasteride
column20: flutamide
column21: nilutamide
column22: and LH-RH agonists that manipulate hormone levels. In 2010
column23: the FDA approved a therapeutic cancer vaccine
column24: Provenge
column25: for use in some men with metastatic prostate cancer. Provenge may provide a 4-month improvement in overall survival compared with a placebo vaccine. Other similar vaccine therapies are in development. Research on New Blood Tests Some researchers are working to develop new blood tests to detect the antibodies that the immune system produces to fight prostate cancer. When used along with PSA testing
column26: the antibody tests may provide more accurate results about whether or not a man has prostate cancer. Researching New Approaches to Treatment Through research
column27: doctors are trying to find new
column28: more effective ways to treat prostate cancer. Cryosurgery -- destroying cancer by freezing it -- is under study as an alternative to surgery and radiation therapy. To avoid damaging healthy tissue
column29: the doctor places an instrument known as a cryoprobe in direct contact with the tumor to freeze it. Doctors are studying new ways of using radiation therapy and hormonal therapy
column30: too. Studies have shown that hormonal therapy given after radiation therapy can help certain men whose cancer has spread to nearby tissues. Scientists are also testing the effectiveness of chemotherapy and biological therapy for men whose cancer does not respond
column31: or stops responding
column32: to hormonal therapy. They are also exploring new ways to schedule and combine various treatments. For example
column33: they are studying hormonal therapy to find out if using it to shrink the tumor before a man has surgery or radiation might be a useful approach. For men with early stage prostate cancer
column34: researchers are also comparing treatment with watchful waiting. The results of this work will help doctors know whether to treat early stage prostate cancer immediately or only later on
column35: if symptoms occur or worsen.;"There are numerous ongoing research and clinical trials dedicated to advancing the understanding and treatment of Prostate Cancer. These investigations encompass various aspects of the disease

column1: - Novel therapeutic approaches: Studies are exploring targeted therapies that selectively inhibit the growth and spread of prostate cancer cells. These therapies may involve monoclonal antibodies
column2: small molecule inhibitors
column3: and immunotherapies that enhance the immune system's ability to recognize and attack cancer cells.

column1: - Improved screening and diagnostic methods: Research aims to develop more accurate and reliable screening tools for early detection of prostate cancer. This includes the investigation of biomarkers
column2: genetic testing
column3: and imaging techniques to identify individuals at higher risk of the disease.

column1: - Personalized medicine: Clinical trials are evaluating the use of genetic profiling and molecular analysis to tailor treatment strategies to the specific characteristics of each patient's cancer. This approach aims to enhance treatment effectiveness and reduce side effects by matching therapies to the unique molecular makeup of the tumor.

- Minimizing treatment side effects: Research efforts are focused on developing treatments that minimize the adverse effects associated with prostate cancer therapy. Studies are investigating strategies to reduce urinary incontinence
column2: erectile dysfunction
column3: and other side effects commonly experienced during or after treatment.

column1: - Improving outcomes for advanced disease: Clinical trials are evaluating new treatment modalities and combinations for patients with advanced or metastatic prostate cancer. These studies aim to prolong survival
column2: improve quality of life

column1: 391;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to pseudohypoaldosteronism type 1 ?;"Mutations in one of four different genes involved in sodium regulation cause autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive PHA1. column2: SCNN1B
column3: or SCNN1G genes cause autosomal recessive PHA1. Each of these three genes provides instructions for making one of the pieces (subunits) of a protein complex called the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). column4: such as the presence of the hormone aldosterone
column5: the mineralocorticoid receptor increases the number and activity of these proteins at the cell membrane of certain kidney cells. One of these proteins is ENaC

column1: 399;gemini-pro;susceptibility;Who is at risk for Overweight and Obesity? ?;"Being overweight or obese isn't a cosmetic problem. These conditions greatly raise your risk for other health problems.
Overweight and Obesity-Related Health Problems in Adults
Coronary Heart Disease
As your body mass index rises
column2: so does your risk for coronary heart disease (CHD). CHD is a condition in which a waxy substance called plaque (plak) builds up inside the coronary arteries. These arteries supply oxygen-rich blood to your heart.

column1: Plaque can narrow or block the coronary arteries and reduce blood flow to the heart muscle. This can cause angina (an-JI-nuh or AN-juh-nuh) or a heart attack. (Angina is chest pain or discomfort.)
Obesity also can lead to heart failure. This is a serious condition in which your heart can't pump enough blood to meet your body's needs.
High Blood Pressure
Blood pressure is the force of blood pushing against the walls of the arteries as theheart pumps blood. If this pressure rises and stays high over time
column2: it can damage the body in many ways.

column1: Your chances of having high blood pressure are greater if you're overweight or obese.
Stroke
Being overweight or obese can lead to a buildup of plaque in your arteries. Eventually
column2: an area of plaque can rupture
column3: causing a blood clot to form.

column1: If the clot is close to your brain
column2: it can block the flow of blood and oxygen to your brain and cause a stroke. The risk of having a stroke rises as BMI increases.

column1: Type 2 Diabetes
Diabetes is a disease in which the body's blood glucose
column2: or blood sugar
column3: level is too high. Normally
column4: the body breaks down food into glucose and then carries it to cells throughout the body. The cells use a hormone called insulin to turn the glucose into energy.

column1: In type 2 diabetes
column2: the body's cells don't use insulin properly. At first
column3: the body reacts by making more insulin. Over time
column4: however
column5: the body can't make enough insulin to control its blood sugar level.

column1: Diabetes is a leading cause of early death
column2: CHD
column3: stroke
column4: kidney disease
column5: and blindness. Most people who have type 2 diabetes are overweight.

column1: Abnormal Blood Fats
If you're overweight or obese
column2: you're at increased risk of having abnormal levels of blood fats. These include high levels of triglycerides and LDL (""bad"") cholesterol and low levels of HDL (""good"") cholesterol.

column1: Abnormal levels of these blood fats are a risk factor for CHD. For more information about triglycerides and LDL and HDL cholesterol
column2: go to the Health Topics High Blood Cholesterol article.

column1: Metabolic Syndrome
Metabolic syndrome is the name for a group of risk factors that raises your risk for heart disease and other health problems
column2: such as diabetes and stroke.

column1: You can develop any one of these risk factors by itself
column2: but they tend to occur together. A diagnosis of metabolic syndrome is made if you have at least three of the following risk factors:

column1: A large waistline. This is called abdominal obesity or ""having an apple shape."" Having extra fat in the waist area is a greater risk factor for CHD than having extra fat in other parts of the body
column2: such as on the hips.

column1: A higher than normal triglyceride level (or you're on medicine to treat high triglycerides).
A lower than normal HDL cholesterol level (or you're on medicine to treat low HDL cholesterol).
Higher than normal blood pressure (or you're on medicine to treat high blood pressure).
Higher than normal fasting blood sugar (or you're on medicine to treat diabetes).
Cancer
Being overweight or obese raises your risk for colon
column2: breast
column3: endometrial
column4: and gallbladder cancers.

column1: Osteoarthritis
Osteoarthritis is a common joint problem of the knees
column2: hips
column3: and lower back. The condition occurs if the tissue that protects the joints wears away. Extra weight can put more pressure and wear on joints
column4: causing pain.

column1: Sleep Apnea
Sleep apnea is a common disorder in which you have one or more pauses in breathing or shallow breaths while you sleep.
A person who has sleep apnea may have more fat stored around the neck. This can narrow the airway
column2: making it hard to breathe.

column1: Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome
Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is a breathing disorder that affects some obese people. In OHS
column2: poor breathing results in too much carbon dioxide (hypoventilation) and too little oxygen in the blood (hypoxemia).

column1: OHS can lead to serious health problems and may even cause death.
Reproductive Problems
Obesity can cause menstrual issues and infertility in women.
Gallstones
Gallstones are hard pieces of stone-like material that form in the gallbladder. They're mostly made of cholesterol. Gallstones can cause stomach or back pain.
People who are overweight or obese are at increased risk of having gallstones. Also
column2: being overweight may result in an enlarged gallbladder that doesn't work well.

column1: Overweight and Obesity-Related Health Problems in Children and Teens
Overweight and obesity also increase the health risks for children and teens. Type2 diabetes once was rare in American children
column2: but an increasing number of children are developing the disease.

column1: Also
column2: overweight children are more likely to become overweight or obese as adults
column3: with the same disease risks.";Individuals with a genetic predisposition
column4: certain medical conditions
column5: specific dietary habits
column6: and sedentary lifestyles are at an increased risk of overweight and obesity. Genetic factors can influence body weight and metabolism
column7: while medical conditions such as Cushing's syndrome
column8: hypothyroidism
column9: and certain medications can contribute to weight gain. Consuming a diet high in processed foods
column10: added sugars
column11: and unhealthy fats
column12: coupled with inadequate physical activity
column13: can lead to an imbalance between calorie intake and energy expenditure
column14: promoting weight gain. Furthermore
column15: factors like age
column16: gender
column17: socioeconomic status
column18: and psychological factors can also influence an individual's risk of developing overweight or obesity.;0.0;784.0;94.0;0.15;0.027;0.105;0.419;-0.224;-0.349;-0.096

column1: 402;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Alagille syndrome ?;In more than 90 percent of cases

column3: called NOTCH2. The JAG1 and NOTCH2 genes provide instructions for making proteins that fit together to trigger interactions called Notch signaling between neighboring cells during embryonic development. column6: heart

column13: eyes
column14: and skeletal system. Mutations in either JAG1 or NOTCH2 disrupt this signaling

column1: 403;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Bart-Pumphrey syndrome ?;Bart-Pumphrey syndrome is caused by mutations in the GJB2 gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called gap junction beta 2

column1: 413;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Marfan Syndrome ?;"Your doctor will diagnose Marfan syndrome based on your medical and family histories
column2: a physical exam
column3: and test results. He or she also will consult a set of guidelines called Ghent criteria
column4: which are used to diagnose Marfan syndrome.

column1: Marfan syndrome can be hard to diagnose. This is because its signs
column2: or traits
column3: are the same as or similar to the signs of other connective tissue disorders.

column1: If you're diagnosed with Marfan syndrome
column2: all of your first-degree relatives (for example
column3: parents
column4: siblings
column5: and children) also should be checked for the disorder. This is because
column6: even in families
column7: the outward traits of Marfan syndrome may vary quite a bit.

column1: Specialists Involved
Your family doctor or another type of doctor
column2: such as an orthopedist (bone specialist)
column3: may notice certain traits that suggest Marfan syndrome.

column1: If so
column2: your doctor will likely refer you to a geneticist or cardiologist. A geneticist is hereditary disease expert. A cardiologist is a heart specialist. These two types of specialists often have the most experience working with people who have Marfan syndrome.

column1: A geneticist will ask for medical information about you and your family. He or she will examine you and perhaps other members of your family. The geneticist also will coordinate your visits with other doctors
column2: including a cardiologist
column3: an ophthalmologist (eye specialist)
column4: and an orthopedist.

column1: After reviewing the medical findings
column2: the geneticist will determine whether you have Marfan syndrome.

column1: Medical and Family Histories
Your doctor will ask about your medical history and your family's medical history. For example
column2: your doctor may ask whether:

column1: You've had heart disease
column2: eye problems
column3: or problems with your spine. These complications are common in people who have Marfan syndrome.

column1: You have shortness of breath
column2: palpitations
column3: or chest pain. These are common symptoms of heart or lung problems linked to Marfan syndrome.

column1: Any of your family members have Marfan syndrome
column2: have died from heart problems
column3: or have died suddenly.

column1: Physical Exam
During the physical exam
column2: your doctor will look for Marfan syndrome traits. For example
column3: he or she may check the curve of your spine and the shape of your feet. Your doctor also will listen to your heart and lungs with a stethoscope.

column1: Diagnostic Tests
Your doctor may recommend one or more of the following tests to help diagnose Marfan syndrome.
Echocardiography
Echocardiography (EK-o-kar-de-OG-ra-fee)
column2: or echo
column3: is a painless test that uses sound waves to create pictures of your heart and blood vessels.

column1: This test shows the size and shape of your heart and the diameter of your aorta or other blood vessels. (The aorta is the main artery that carries oxygen-rich blood to your body.) Echo also shows how well your heart's chambers and valves are working.
For people who have Marfan syndrome
column2: echo mainly is used to check the heart's valves and aorta.

column1: Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Computed Tomography Scans
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is a test that uses radio waves and magnets to create detailed pictures of your organs and tissues. Computed tomography (CT) uses an x-ray machine to take clear
column2: detailed pictures of your organs.

column1: MRI and CT scans are used to check your heart valves and aorta. These scans also are used to check for dural ectasia
column2: a nervous system complication of Marfan syndrome.

column1: Slit-Lamp Exam
For this test
column2: an ophthalmologist (eye specialist) will use a microscope with a light to check your eyes. A slit-lamp exam can find out whether you have a dislocated lens
column3: cataracts
column4: or a detached retina.

column1: Genetic Testing
In general
column2: genetic testing involves blood tests to detect changes in genes. However
column3: because many different genetic changes can cause Marfan syndrome
column4: no single blood test can diagnose the condition.

column1: Ghent Criteria
Because no single test can diagnose Marfan syndrome
column2: doctors use a set of guidelines called Ghent criteria to help diagnose the condition. The Ghent criteria are divided into major criteria and minor criteria. Sometimes genetic testing is part of this evaluation.

column1: Major criteria include traits that are common in people who have Marfan syndrome. Minor criteria include traits that are common in many people. Doctors use a scoring system based on the number and type of Ghent criteria present to diagnose Marfan syndrome.
Talk with your doctor about which traits you have and your likelihood of having Marfan syndrome.";"Marfan syndrome diagnosis involves a comprehensive evaluation that includes physical examination
column2: medical history
column3: imaging studies
column4: and genetic testing:

column1: 1. **Physical Examination:**
- Assess body proportions
column2: checking for elongated limbs
column3: fingers
column4: and toes (arachnodactyly).

column1: - Look for skeletal abnormalities like pectus excavatum (sunken chest) or pectus carinatum (protruding chest).
- Examine the eyes for lens dislocation or ectopia lentis.
2. **Medical History:**
- Inquire about family history of Marfan syndrome or related conditions.
- Ask about symptoms such as chest pain
column2: shortness of breath
column3: or joint pain.

column1: 3. **Imaging Studies:**
- Echocardiography to evaluate the heart
column2: checking for aortic root dilation or mitral valve prolapse.

column1: - Slit-lamp eye examination to assess lens position and integrity.
- Skeletal X-rays to look for scoliosis
column2: kyphosis
column3: or other bone abnormalities.

column1: 4. **Genetic Testing:**
- Molecular genetic testing can identify mutations in the FBN1 gene
column2: which is responsible for Marfan syndrome in most cases.";0.001;662.0;136.0;0.25;0.038;0.149;0.781;-0.193;-0.214;-0.175

column1: 415;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to prekallikrein deficiency ?;Prekallikrein deficiency is caused by mutations in the KLKB1 gene
column2: which provides instructions for making a protein called prekallikrein. This protein
column3: when converted to an active form called plasma kallikrein in the blood
column4: is involved in the early stages of blood clotting. Plasma kallikrein plays a role in a process called the intrinsic coagulation pathway (also called the contact activation pathway). This pathway turns on (activates) proteins that are needed later in the clotting process. Blood clots protect the body after an injury by sealing off damaged blood vessels and preventing further blood loss.  The KLKB1 gene mutations that cause prekallikrein deficiency reduce or eliminate functional plasma kallikrein
column5: which likely impairs the intrinsic coagulation pathway. Researchers suggest that this lack (deficiency) of functional plasma kallikrein protein does not generally cause any symptoms because another process called the extrinsic coagulation pathway (also known as the tissue factor pathway) can compensate for the impaired intrinsic coagulation pathway.;Prekallikrein deficiency is a rare autosomal dominant genetic disorder caused by mutations in the KLKB1 gene. The KLKB1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called prekallikrein

column9: and impaired wound healing. Additionally

column1: 416;gemini-pro;stages;What are the stages of Childhood Liver Cancer ?;"Key Points
- After childhood liver cancer has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the liver or to other parts of the body.     - There are two grouping systems for childhood liver cancer.    - There are four PRETEXT and POSTTEXT groups:         - PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group I     - PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group II     - PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group III     - PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group IV        - There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.    - Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.

column1: After childhood liver cancer has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the liver or to other parts of the body.

column1: The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the liver
column2: to nearby tissues or organs
column3: or to other parts of the body is called staging. In childhood liver cancer
column4: the PRETEXT and POSTTEXT groups are used instead of stage to plan treatment. The results of the tests and procedures done to detect
column5: diagnose
column6: and find out whether the cancer has spread are used to determine the PRETEXT and POSTTEXT groups.

column1: There are two grouping systems for childhood liver cancer.

Two grouping systems are used for childhood liver cancer:         - The PRETEXT group describes the tumor before the patient has treatment.    - The POSTTEXT group describes the tumor after the patient has treatment.
There are four PRETEXT and POSTTEXT groups:
The liver is divided into 4 sections. The PRETEXT and POSTTEXT groups depend on which sections of the liver have cancer.     PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group I     In group I
column2: the cancer is found in one section of the liver. Three sections of the liver that are next to each other do not have cancer in them.       PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group II     In group II
column3: cancer is found in one or two sections of the liver. Two sections of the liver that are next to each other do not have cancer in them.       PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group III     In group III
column4: one of the following is true:            -  Cancer is found in three sections of the liver and one section does not have cancer.     - Cancer is found in two sections of the liver and two sections that are not next to each other do not have cancer in them.              PRETEXT and POSTTEXT Group IV     In group IV
column5: cancer is found in all four sections of the liver.

column1: There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.
Cancer can spread through tissue
column2: the lymph system
column3: and the blood:         - Tissue. The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.     - Lymph system. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system. The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.     - Blood. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood. The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.

column1: Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.
When cancer spreads to another part of the body
column2: it is called metastasis. Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.         - Lymph system. The cancer gets into the lymph system
column3: travels through the lymph vessels
column4: and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.    - Blood. The cancer gets into the blood
column5: travels through the blood vessels
column6: and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.        The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor. For example
column7: if childhood liver cancer spreads to the lung
column8: the cancer cells in the lung are actually liver cancer cells. The disease is metastatic liver cancer
column9: not lung cancer.";Childhood Liver Cancer is classified into four stages. Stage I: The tumor is located entirely within the liver and has not spread to any other organs. Stage II: The tumor has spread to blood vessels or other structures within the liver
column10: but has not spread to other organs. Stage III: The tumor has spread to other organs in the abdomen
column11: such as the stomach
column12: intestines
column13: or lymph nodes. Stage IV: The tumor has spread to organs outside the abdomen
column14: such as the lungs
column15: bones

column1: * **Antimicrobial therapy:** Regular use of antibiotics to prevent and treat infections.

column1: 425;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Sarcoidosis ?;"Your doctor will diagnose sarcoidosis based on your medical history
column2: a physical exam
column3: and test results. He or she will look for granulomas (inflamed lumps) in your organs. Your doctor also will try to rule out other possible causes of your symptoms.

column1: Medical History
Your doctor may ask you detailed questions about your medical history. For example
column2: he or she may ask whether you:

column1: Have a family history of sarcoidosis.
Have had any jobs that may have raised your risk for the disease.
Have ever been exposed to inhaled beryllium metal. (This type of metal is used to make aircrafts and weapons.)
Have had contact with organic dust from birds or hay.
Exposure to beryllium metal and organic dust can cause inflamed lumps in your lungs that look like the granulomas from sarcoidosis. However
column2: these lumps are signs of other conditions.

column1: Physical Exam
Your doctor will check you for signs and symptoms of sarcoidosis. Signs and symptoms may include red bumps on your skin; swollen lymph nodes; an enlarged liver
column2: spleen
column3: or salivary glands; or redness in your eyes. Your doctor also will check for other causes of your symptoms.

column1: Your doctor may listen to your lungs and heart. Abnormal breathing or heartbeat sounds could be a sign that sarcoidosis is affecting your lungs or heart.
Diagnostic Tests
You may have tests to confirm a diagnosis and to find out how sarcoidosis is affecting you. Tests include a chest x ray
column2: lung function tests
column3: biopsy
column4: and other tests to assess organ damage.

column1: Chest X Ray
A chest x ray is a painless test that creates pictures of the structures inside your chest
column2: such as your heart and lungs. The test may show granulomas or enlarged lymph nodes in your chest. About 95 percent of people who have sarcoidosis have abnormal chest xrays.

column1: Lung Function Tests
Lung function tests measure how much air you can breathe in and out
column2: how fast you can breathe air out
column3: and how well your lungs deliver oxygen to your blood. These tests can show whether sarcoidosis is affecting your lungs.

column1: Biopsy
Your doctor may do a biopsy to confirm a diagnosis or rule out other causes of your symptoms. A biopsy involves taking a small sample of tissue from one of your affected organs.
Usually
column2: doctors try to biopsy the organs that are easiest to access. Examples include the skin
column3: tear glands
column4: or the lymph nodes that are just under the skin.

column1: If this isn't possible
column2: your doctor may use a positron emission tomography (PET) scan to pinpoint areas for biopsy. For this test
column3: a small amount of radioactive substance is injected into a vein
column4: usually in your arm.

column1: The substance
column2: which releases energy
column3: travels through the blood and collects in organs or tissues. Special cameras detect the energy and convert it into three-dimensional (3D) pictures.

column1: If lung function tests or a chest x ray shows signs of sarcoidosis in your lungs
column2: your doctor may do a bronchoscopy (bron-KOS-ko-pee) to get a small sample of lung tissue.

column1: During this procedure
column2: a thin
column3: flexible tube is passed through your nose (or sometimes your mouth)
column4: down your throat
column5: and into the airways to reach your lung tissue. (For more information
column6: go to the Health Topics Bronchoscopy article.)

column1: Other Tests To Assess Organ Damage
You also may have other tests to assess organ damage and find out whether you need treatment. For example
column2: your doctor may recommend blood tests and/or an EKG (electrocardiogram).

column1: If youre diagnosed with sarcoidosis
column2: you should see an ophthalmologist (eye specialist)
column3: even if you dont have eye symptoms. In sarcoidosis
column4: eye damage can occur without symptoms.";Sarcoidosis is a complex multisystem disorder characterized by the formation of granulomas
column5: small inflammatory lesions
column6: in various organs. A definitive diagnosis of sarcoidosis requires a combination of clinical findings
column7: imaging studies
column8: and biopsy results. Typically
column9: a detailed medical history and physical examination are performed to assess symptoms and identify potential clues. Imaging techniques
column10: such as chest X-rays or CT scans
column11: can reveal characteristic findings in the lungs or other affected organs. A biopsy of affected tissue
column12: often obtained through bronchoscopy or lymph node sampling
column13: is essential for confirming the diagnosis. Histopathological examination of the biopsy specimen allows pathologists to identify the presence of non-caseating granulomas
column14: a hallmark of sarcoidosis. Additional tests
column15: including blood tests
column16: lung function tests
column17: and cardiac evaluations
column18: may be conducted to assess the extent and severity of the disease and rule out other conditions with similar symptoms.;0.002;568.0;127.0;0.273;0.055;0.174;0.709;-0.035;-0.134;0.064

column1: 426;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Retinal Disorders ?;The retina is a layer of tissue in the back of your eye that senses light and sends images to your brain. In the center of this nerve tissue is the macula. It provides the sharp
column2: central vision needed for reading
column3: driving and seeing fine detail.    Retinal disorders affect this vital tissue. They can affect your vision
column4: and some can be serious enough to cause blindness. Examples are       - Macular degeneration - a disease that destroys your sharp
column5: central vision    - Diabetic eye disease    - Retinal detachment - a medical emergency
column6: when the retina is pulled away from the back of the eye    - Retinoblastoma - cancer of the retina. It is most common in young children.    - Macular pucker - scar tissue on the macula    - Macular hole - a small break in the macula that usually happens to people over 60    - Floaters - cobwebs or specks in your field of vision       NIH: National Eye Institute;Retinal disorders are a group of conditions that affect the retina
column7: the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye. These disorders can cause a range of symptoms
column8: including blurred vision
column9: floaters
column10: flashes of light
column11: and vision loss. Some common retinal disorders include macular degeneration
column12: diabetic retinopathy
column13: retinal detachment
column14: retinitis pigmentosa
column15: and uveitis. Treatment for retinal disorders depends on the specific condition and may include medication
column16: laser therapy
column17: surgery
column18: or a combination of treatments. Early diagnosis and treatment are essential to preserving vision and preventing further damage to the retina.;0.023;130.0;81.0;0.361;0.069;0.222;0.682;0.09;0.05;0.129

column1: 427;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to GLUT1 deficiency syndrome ?;"GLUT1 deficiency syndrome is caused by mutations in the SLC2A1 gene. This gene provides instructions for producing a protein called the glucose transporter protein type 1 (GLUT1). The GLUT1 protein is embedded in the outer membrane surrounding cells
column2: where it transports a simple sugar called glucose into cells from the blood or from other cells for use as fuel.  In the brain
column3: the GLUT1 protein is involved in moving glucose
column4: which is the brain's main energy source
column5: across the blood-brain barrier. The blood-brain barrier acts as a boundary between tiny blood vessels (capillaries) and the surrounding brain tissue; it protects the brain's delicate nerve tissue by preventing many other types of molecules from entering the brain. The GLUT1 protein also moves glucose between cells in the brain called glia
column6: which protect and maintain nerve cells (neurons).  SLC2A1 gene mutations reduce or eliminate the function of the GLUT1 protein. Having less functional GLUT1 protein reduces the amount of glucose available to brain cells
column7: which affects brain development and function.";GLUT1 deficiency syndrome
column8: also known as glucose transporter type 1 deficiency
column9: is caused by genetic changes in the SLC2A1 gene
column10: which encodes the facilitative glucose transporter 1 (GLUT1) protein responsible for transporting glucose across the blood-brain barrier and into various other cells. These genetic alterations can include point mutations
column11: insertions
column12: deletions
column13: or rearrangements
column14: resulting in impaired function or complete loss of the GLUT1 protein. Some common mutations associated with GLUT1 deficiency syndrome include missense mutations that alter the amino acid sequence of the protein
column15: leading to reduced glucose transport activity
column16: and nonsense mutations that result in truncated or non-functional GLUT1 proteins. Other mutations can affect the regulatory elements of the SLC2A1 gene
column17: influencing the expression levels or stability of the GLUT1 protein. These genetic changes lead to impaired glucose metabolism
column18: particularly in the brain and red blood cells
column19: causing the clinical manifestations and neurological symptoms observed in individuals with GLUT1 deficiency syndrome.;0.049;147.0;140.0;0.368;0.115;0.276;0.869;0.182;0.177;0.183

column1: 428;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis ?;Familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis is a disorder in which the immune system produces too many activated immune cells (lymphocytes) called T cells
column2: natural killer cells
column3: B cells
column4: and macrophages (histiocytes). Excessive amounts of immune system proteins called cytokines are also produced. This overactivation of the immune system causes fever and damages the liver and spleen
column5: resulting in enlargement of these organs.  Familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis also destroys blood-producing cells in the bone marrow
column6: a process called hemophagocytosis. As a result
column7: affected individuals have low numbers of red blood cells (anemia) and a reduction in the number of blood cells involved in clotting (platelets). A reduction in platelets may cause easy bruising and abnormal bleeding.  The brain may also be affected in familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. As a result
column8: affected individuals may experience irritability
column9: delayed closure of the bones of the skull in infants
column10: neck stiffness
column11: abnormal muscle tone
column12: impaired muscle coordination
column13: paralysis
column14: blindness
column15: seizures
column16: and coma. In addition to neurological problems
column17: familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis can cause abnormalities of the heart
column19: and other organs and tissues. Affected individuals also have an increased risk of developing cancers of blood-forming cells (leukemia and lymphoma).  Signs and symptoms of familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis usually become apparent during infancy
column20: although occasionally they appear later in life. They usually occur when the immune system launches an exaggerated response to an infection
column21: but may also occur in the absence of infection. Without treatment
column22: most people with familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis survive only a few months.;Familial hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (FHL) is a rare
column23: life-threatening genetic disorder characterized by an overactive immune response that leads to the destruction of healthy cells and tissues. It is caused by mutations in genes involved in the regulation of immune function
column24: resulting in the accumulation of activated immune cells called histiocytes and lymphocytes in various organs
column25: particularly the liver
column28: and lymph nodes. This accumulation leads to tissue damage
column29: organ dysfunction
column30: and a range of clinical manifestations
column31: including fever
column32: hepatosplenomegaly
column33: cytopenias
column34: and central nervous system involvement. FHL can occur in both children and adults and is often associated with other genetic conditions such as Chediak-Higashi syndrome and Griscelli syndrome. Treatment typically involves immunosuppressive therapy
column35: hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
column36: or a combination of both. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing life-threatening complications.;0.019;223.0;130.0;0.291;0.067;0.128;0.705;-0.031;-0.005;-0.06

column6: proper hydration

column1: 430;gemini-pro;prevention;How to prevent What I need to know about My Child's Urinary Tract Infection ?;"You can take the following steps to help prevent your child from getting a UTI:

- Teach your child not to hold in urine and to go to the bathroom whenever your child feels the urge.  - Teach your child how to properly clean himself or herself after using the bathroom to keep bacteria from entering the urinary tract.  - Have your child wear loose-fitting clothes. Tight clothes can trap moisture
column2: which allows bacteria to grow.  - Buy your child cotton underwear. Cotton lets in air to dry the area.  - If your child has constipation
column3: talk with a health care provider about the best treatment options.";Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are common in children
column4: especially girls. Symptoms can include cloudy or foul-smelling urine
column5: frequent urination
column6: urgency to urinate
column7: pain or burning during urination. Here are some tips to prevent UTIs in your child: Encourage your child to drink plenty of fluids
column8: especially water. This helps to flush out bacteria from the bladder. Have your child urinate frequently
column9: especially after activities that involve sitting or holding in urine for long periods of time. Help your child practice good hygiene by washing their hands before eating and after using the bathroom. Avoid using harsh soaps or douches
column10: which can irritate the urethra and make it more susceptible to infection. If your child has a history of UTIs
column11: talk to your doctor about preventive antibiotics.;0.056;93.0;122.0;0.297;0.089;0.155;0.764;0.16;0.22;0.098

column1: 431;gemini-pro;prevention;How to prevent Bronchiectasis ?;"To prevent bronchiectasis
column2: it's important to prevent the lung infections and lung damage that can cause it.

column1: Childhood vaccines for measles and whooping cough prevent infections related to these illnesses. These vaccines also reduce complications from these infections
column2: such as bronchiectasis.

column1: Avoiding toxic fumes
column2: gases
column3: smoke
column4: and other harmful substances also can help protect your lungs.

column1: Proper treatment of lung infections in children also may help preserve lung function and prevent lung damage that can lead to bronchiectasis.
Stay alert to keep children (and adults) from inhaling small objects (such as pieces of toys and food that might stick in a small airway). If you think you
column2: your child
column3: or someone else has inhaled a small object
column4: seek prompt medical care.

column1: In some cases
column2: treating the underlying cause of bronchiectasis can slow or prevent its progression.";Prevention of bronchiectasis primarily involves addressing underlying conditions that can lead to the development of the disease. These include: 1. Maintaining proper hygiene: Regularly washing hands
column3: covering coughs and sneezes
column4: and avoiding contact with individuals with respiratory infections can help prevent the spread of infectious agents that can cause bronchiectasis. 2. Vaccination: Vaccinations against respiratory pathogens
column5: such as measles
column6: whooping cough
column7: and influenza
column8: can help protect against infections that can contribute to the development of bronchiectasis. 3. Managing underlying conditions: Properly managing conditions like cystic fibrosis
column9: asthma
column10: and immune deficiencies can help prevent or slow the progression of bronchiectasis. 4. Smoking cessation: Smoking is a major risk factor for bronchiectasis. Quitting smoking can significantly reduce the risk of developing the condition. 5. Early diagnosis and treatment of respiratory infections: Prompt diagnosis and treatment of respiratory infections can help prevent the development of chronic infections and subsequent bronchiectasis.;0.051;132.0;138.0;0.337;0.091;0.181;0.785;0.175;0.153;0.194

column1: 433;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) prion disease ?;"Prion disease represents a group of conditions that affect the nervous system in humans and animals. In people

column3: causing changes in memory
column4: personality

column7: leading to death within a few months to several years.";Prion diseases are a group of rare

column1: 435;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Nephrotic Syndrome in Adults ?;"Urine samples are taken to diagnose people suspected of having nephrotic syndrome.

column1: The presence of albumin in the urine can be detected with a dipstick test performed on a urine sample. column1: Once nephrotic syndrome is diagnosed

column1: 439;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Muscular Dystrophy ?;The muscular dystrophies (MD) are a group of more than 30 genetic diseases characterized by progressive weakness and degeneration of the skeletal muscles that control movement. Some forms of MD are seen in infancy or childhood

column6: a protein involved in maintaining the integrity of muscle. Onset is between 3 and 5 years and the disorder progresses rapidly. Most boys are unable to walk by age 12
column7: and later need a respirator to breathe. Girls in these families have a 50 percent chance of inheriting and passing the defective gene to their children. Boys with Becker MD (very similar to but less severe than Duchenne MD) have faulty or not enough dystrophin. Facioscapulohumeral MD usually begins in the teenage years. It causes progressive weakness in muscles of the face
column8: arms
column9: legs
column10: and around the shoulders and chest. It progresses slowly and can vary in symptoms from mild to disabling. Myotonic MD is the disorder's most common adult form and is typified by prolonged muscle spasms
column11: cataracts
column12: cardiac abnormalities
column13: and endocrine disturbances. Individuals with myotonic MD have long
column14: thin faces
column15: drooping eyelids
column16: and a swan-like neck.;Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic muscle diseases that cause progressive muscle weakness and degeneration. Muscular dystrophies are caused by mutations in genes that encode proteins essential for muscle function. These mutations can lead to the production of defective proteins or a complete lack of these proteins. The absence or dysfunction of these proteins disrupts the structure and function of muscle fibers

column1: 450;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to autosomal dominant hypocalcemia ?;"Autosomal dominant hypocalcemia is primarily caused by mutations in the CASR gene; these cases are known as type 1. A small percentage of cases

column5: which is produced from the GNA11 gene

column7: CaSR stimulates G11 to send signals to block processes that increase the amount of calcium in the blood.  Mutations in the CASR or GNA11 gene lead to overactivity of the respective protein. The altered CaSR protein is more sensitive to calcium
column8: meaning even low levels of calcium can trigger it to stimulate G11 signaling. Similarly
column9: the altered G11 protein continues to send signals to prevent calcium increases
column10: even when levels in the blood are very low. As a result
column11: calcium levels in the blood remain low
column12: causing hypocalcemia. Calcium plays an important role in the control of muscle movement
column13: and a shortage of this molecule can lead to cramping or twitching of the muscles. Impairment of the processes that increase calcium can also disrupt the normal regulation of other molecules

column1: 453;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Norrie disease ?;Mutations in the NDP gene cause Norrie disease.  The NDP gene provides instructions for making a protein called norrin. Norrin participates in the Wnt cascade

column4: and the development of other body systems.  In order to initiate the Wnt cascade

column6: resulting in the signs and symptoms of Norrie disease.;Norrie disease is a rare X-linked genetic disorder primarily affecting males and is caused by mutations in the NDP gene. The NDP gene encodes a protein called Norrin
column7: which plays a crucial role in the development of retinal blood vessels. Mutations in this gene disrupt the normal production or function of Norrin
column8: leading to abnormal development and degeneration of blood vessels in the retina. These changes result in progressive vision impairment and can eventually lead to blindness. The genetic alterations associated with Norrie disease primarily involve pathogenic variants within the NDP gene
column9: including missense
column10: nonsense
column11: frameshift
column12: and splicing mutations. These mutations impair the structure
column13: stability
column14: or function of the Norrin protein
column15: ultimately leading to the characteristic retinal abnormalities observed in individuals with Norrie disease.;0.058;106.0;111.0;0.275;0.111;0.203;0.817;0.15;0.151;0.145

column1: 458;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) cap myopathy ?;Cap myopathy is a disorder that primarily affects skeletal muscles
column2: which are muscles that the body uses for movement. People with cap myopathy have muscle weakness (myopathy) and poor muscle tone (hypotonia) throughout the body
column3: but they are most severely affected in the muscles of the face
column4: neck
column5: and limbs. The muscle weakness
column6: which begins at birth or during childhood

column8: crawling
column9: standing
column10: and walking. They may fall frequently
column11: tire easily
column12: and have difficulty running
column13: climbing stairs
column14: or jumping. In some cases
column15: the muscles used for breathing are affected
column16: and life-threatening breathing difficulties can occur.  People with cap myopathy may have a high arch in the roof of the mouth (high-arched palate)
column17: severely drooping eyelids (ptosis)
column18: and a long face. Some affected individuals develop an abnormally curved lower back (lordosis) or a spine that curves to the side (scoliosis).  The name cap myopathy comes from characteristic abnormal cap-like structures that can be seen in muscle cells when muscle tissue is viewed under a microscope. The severity of cap myopathy is related to the percentage of muscle cells that have these caps. Individuals in whom 70 to 75 percent of muscle cells have caps typically have severe breathing problems and may not survive childhood
column19: while those in whom 10 to 30 percent of muscle cells have caps have milder symptoms and can live into adulthood.;Cap myopathy
column20: also known as muscle weakness disorder

column22: pain
column23: and stiffness. Cap myopathy can be caused by a variety of factors

column27: and certain medications. Symptoms of cap myopathy can include muscle weakness
column28: pain
column29: and stiffness
column30: as well as difficulty breathing
column31: swallowing
column32: and walking. Diagnosis of cap myopathy typically involves a physical exam
column33: blood tests
column35: and muscle biopsies. Treatment for cap myopathy depends on the underlying cause and can include medications

column1: 459;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency inherited ?;"How is dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency inherited? Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. This means that in affected individuals
column2: both copies of the DPYD gene in each cell (one inherited from each parent) have mutations. The mutations that cause DPD deficiency vary widely in severity; therefore
column3: some people with 2 mutated copies of the gene may have signs and symptoms of the condition
column4: while others may be asymptomatic. However
column5: all individuals with 2 mutations are at risk for toxic reactions to fluoropyrimidine drugs. Individuals who carry one mutated copy of the disease-causing gene (including most parents of affected individuals) are referred to as carriers. Carriers typically do not have signs and symptoms of the condition. However
column6: people with one mutated copy of the DPYD gene may still experience toxic reactions to fluoropyrimidine drugs. When 2 carriers for the same autosomal recessive condition have children
column7: each child has a 25% (1 in 4) risk to have the condition
column8: a 50% (1 in 2) risk to be a carrier like each parent
column9: and a 25% risk to not have the condition and not be a carrier. A child of one carrier parent has a 50% risk to also be a carrier.";Yes
column10: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) deficiency is primarily inherited in an autosomal recessive manner
column11: meaning that both copies of the gene encoding the enzyme must carry mutations in order for the deficiency to manifest. In this type of inheritance
column12: both parents carry one copy of the mutated gene
column13: but they are unaffected (carriers). When both parents are carriers
column14: there is a 25% chance with each pregnancy that their child will inherit two copies of the mutated gene and have DPD deficiency.;0.038;184.0;73.0;0.478;0.119;0.391;0.834;0.166;0.034;0.302

column1: 464;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to familial hypobetalipoproteinemia ?;Most cases of FHBL are caused by mutations in the APOB gene. This gene provides instructions for making two versions of the apolipoprotein B protein: a short version called apolipoprotein B-48 and a longer version known as apolipoprotein B-100. Both of these proteins are components of lipoproteins
column2: which transport fats and cholesterol in the blood.  Most APOB gene mutations that lead to FHBL cause both versions of apolipoprotein B to be abnormally short. The severity of the condition largely depends on the length of these two versions of apolipoprotein B. Severely shortened versions cannot partner with lipoproteins and transport fats and cholesterol. Proteins that are only slightly shortened retain some function but partner less effectively with lipoproteins. Generally
column3: the signs and symptoms of FHBL are worse if both versions of apolipoprotein B are severely shortened. Mild or no signs and symptoms result when the proteins are only slightly shortened. All of these protein changes lead to a reduction of functional apolipoprotein B. As a result
column4: the transportation of dietary fats and cholesterol is decreased or absent. A decrease in fat transport reduces the body's ability to absorb fats and fat-soluble vitamins from the diet.  Although APOB gene mutations are responsible for most cases of FHBL
column5: mutations in a few other genes account for a small number of cases. Some people with FHBL do not have identified mutations in any of these genes. Changes in other
column6: unidentified genes are likely involved in this condition.;Familial hypobetalipoproteinemia (FHBL) is a rare inherited disorder characterized by low levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the blood. This is caused by mutations in genes involved in the production or regulation of apolipoprotein B (apoB)
column7: a protein essential for the assembly and secretion of LDL particles. Some common genetic changes associated with FHBL include mutations in the APOB gene
column8: which encodes apoB
column9: and mutations in the PCSK9 gene
column10: which encodes proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK9)
column11: a protein involved in the regulation of LDL cholesterol levels. These mutations can lead to decreased production or impaired function of apoB or PCSK9
column12: resulting in reduced LDL cholesterol levels and an increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease.;0.03;225.0;106.0;0.328;0.086;0.203;0.77;-0.004;-0.017;0.006

column7: chipmunks

column13: trauma

column1: 467;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Lung Cancer ?;Lung cancer is one of the most common cancers in the world. It is a leading cause of cancer death in men and women in the United States. Cigarette smoking causes most lung cancers. The more cigarettes you smoke per day and the earlier you started smoking
column2: the greater your risk of lung cancer. High levels of pollution
column3: radiation and asbestos exposure may also increase risk.     Common symptoms of lung cancer include       - A cough that doesn't go away and gets worse over time    - Constant chest pain    - Coughing up blood    - Shortness of breath
column4: wheezing
column5: or hoarseness    - Repeated problems with pneumonia or bronchitis    - Swelling of the neck and face    - Loss of appetite or weight loss    - Fatigue       Doctors diagnose lung cancer using a physical exam
column6: imaging
column7: and lab tests. Treatment depends on the type
column8: stage
column9: and how advanced it is. Treatments include surgery
column10: chemotherapy
column11: radiation therapy
column12: and targeted therapy. Targeted therapy uses substances that attack cancer cells without harming normal cells.    NIH: National Cancer Institute;Lung cancer is a malignant lung tumor characterized by uncontrolled cell growth in tissues of the lung. This uncontrolled growth can lead to the formation of cancerous tumors that can obstruct airways and spread to other parts of the body. Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide
column13: and is primarily caused by tobacco smoking
column14: which accounts for approximately 80-90% of cases. Other risk factors include exposure to secondhand smoke
column15: radon gas
column16: asbestos
column17: and certain occupational carcinogens. Symptoms of lung cancer often include a persistent cough
column20: fatigue
column21: unintended weight loss
column22: and coughing up blood or rust-colored sputum. Early detection and prompt treatment are crucial for improving the chances of survival.;0.065;151.0;110.0;0.309;0.104;0.17;0.779;0.075;0.044;0.102

column1: 468;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome ?;8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome is a blood cancer that involves different types of blood cells. Blood cells are divided into several groups (lineages) based on the type of early cell from which they are descended. Two of these lineages are myeloid cells and lymphoid cells. Individuals with 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome can develop both myeloid cell cancer and lymphoid cell cancer.  The condition can occur at any age. It usually begins as a myeloproliferative disorder
column2: which is characterized by a high number of white blood cells (leukocytes). Most affected individuals also have an excess of myeloid cells known as eosinophils (eosinophilia).  In addition to a myeloproliferative disorder
column3: many people with 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome develop lymphoma
column4: which is a form of blood cancer that involves lymphoid cells. The cancerous lymphoid cells grow and divide in lymph nodes
column5: forming a tumor that enlarges the lymph nodes. In most cases of 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome
column6: the cancerous cells are lymphoid cells called T cells. Lymphoma can develop at the same time as the myeloproliferative disorder or later.  In most people with 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome
column7: the myeloproliferative disorder develops into a fast-growing blood cancer called acute myeloid leukemia.  The rapid myeloid and lymphoid cell production caused by these cancers results in enlargement of the spleen and liver (splenomegaly and hepatomegaly
column8: respectively). Most people with 8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome have symptoms such as fatigue or night sweats. Some affected individuals have no symptoms
column9: and the condition is discovered through routine blood tests.;8p11 myeloproliferative syndrome is a rare genetic disorder caused by an abnormality on chromosome 8
column10: specifically the deletion of a small region called 8p11. This deletion results in the overexpression of several genes in the region
column11: including FGFR1
column12: which is involved in cell growth and proliferation. This overexpression leads to the development of myeloproliferative neoplasms
column13: a group of blood cancers characterized by an overproduction of blood cells such as red blood cells
column14: white blood cells
column15: and platelets. The syndrome is typically diagnosed in children and young adults and can manifest with various symptoms including fatigue
column16: weakness
column17: splenomegaly (enlarged spleen)
column20: and leukocytosis (high white blood cell count). Treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy
column21: targeted therapy

column1: 471;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Knee Injuries and Disorders ?;Your knee joint is made up of bone
column2: cartilage
column3: ligaments and fluid. Muscles and tendons help the knee joint move. When any of these structures is hurt or diseased
column4: you have knee problems. Knee problems can cause pain and difficulty walking.    Knee problems are very common
column5: and they occur in people of all ages. Knee problems can interfere with many things
column6: from participation in sports to simply getting up from a chair and walking. This can have a big impact on your life.    The most common disease affecting the knee is osteoarthritis. The cartilage in the knee gradually wears away
column7: causing pain and swelling.    Injuries to ligaments and tendons also cause knee problems. A common injury is to the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). You usually injure your ACL by a sudden twisting motion. ACL and other knee injuries are common sports injuries.    Treatment of knee problems depends on the cause. In some cases your doctor may recommend knee replacement.    NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases;Knee injuries and disorders encompass a wide range of conditions affecting the knee joint

column1: 477;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Pancreatic Cancer ?;"New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.

This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials. It may not mention every new treatment being studied. Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.     Biologic therapy     Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer. Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost
column2: direct
column3: or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer. This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.

column1: Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.
For some patients
column2: taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice. Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process. Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.   Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials. Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.   Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future. Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments
column3: they often answer important questions and help move research forward.

column1: Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.

column1: Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment. Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better. There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.   Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country. See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials. These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.";"Pancreatic cancer research is actively pursuing several promising avenues to develop effective treatments and improve patient outcomes. Here's an overview of some ongoing research efforts:
- Targeted Therapy: Researchers are exploring targeted therapies that block specific molecules involved in the growth and spread of pancreatic cancer. Drugs like PARP inhibitors
column2: WEE1 inhibitors
column3: and KRAS G12C inhibitors are being evaluated in clinical trials to determine their efficacy in treating pancreatic cancer.

column1: - Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy approaches aim to harness the body's immune system to fight pancreatic cancer. Clinical trials are investigating immune checkpoint inhibitors
column2: adoptive cell therapy (CAR T-cell therapy)
column3: and oncolytic viruses to stimulate an antitumor immune response.

column1: - Combination Therapies: Combining different treatment modalities
column2: such as chemotherapy
column3: targeted therapy
column4: and immunotherapy
column5: is being explored to enhance treatment outcomes. Clinical trials are evaluating various combinations to determine the most effective and tolerable approaches for pancreatic cancer patients.

column1: - Early Detection: Research efforts are focused on developing non-invasive screening methods for early detection of pancreatic cancer. Liquid biopsies
column2: which analyze circulating tumor cells or DNA in the blood
column3: are being investigated to improve early diagnosis and monitoring of pancreatic cancer.

column1: - Pancreatic Cancer Vaccines: Research is being conducted to develop vaccines that target specific antigens associated with pancreatic cancer. These vaccines aim to stimulate the immune system to recognize and attack pancreatic cancer cells.
- Novel Treatment Strategies: Researchers are exploring new treatment approaches
column2: including gene therapy
column3: stem cell therapy
column4: and nanomedicine
column5: to target pancreatic cancer cells more precisely and minimize side effects.";0.028;300.0;238.0;0.233;0.043;0.167;0.489;-0.06;-0.048;-0.075

Medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) can be included in moderation as they are absorbed more easily. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) supplements are often prescribed to help improve the function of the deficient enzyme. In severe cases

column3: it's important to note that there is currently no cure for this condition

column3: I have information about African American Health. African Americans experience significant health disparities compared to other racial and ethnic groups in the United States. These disparities are rooted in historical and ongoing systemic racism
column4: as well as social and economic factors. African Americans are more likely to suffer from chronic conditions such as heart disease

column12: community-based interventions

column1: 487;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) severe congenital neutropenia ?;Severe congenital neutropenia is a condition that causes affected individuals to be prone to recurrent infections. People with this condition have a shortage (deficiency) of neutrophils
column2: a type of white blood cell that plays a role in inflammation and in fighting infection. The deficiency of neutrophils
column3: called neutropenia
column4: is apparent at birth or soon afterward. It leads to recurrent infections beginning in infancy
column5: including infections of the sinuses
column6: lungs
column7: and liver. Affected individuals can also develop fevers and inflammation of the gums (gingivitis) and skin. Approximately 40 percent of affected people have decreased bone density (osteopenia) and may develop osteoporosis
column8: a condition that makes bones progressively more brittle and prone to fracture. In people with severe congenital neutropenia
column9: these bone disorders can begin at any time from infancy through adulthood.  Approximately 20 percent of people with severe congenital neutropenia develop cancer of the blood-forming tissue (leukemia) or a disease of the blood and bone marrow (myelodysplastic syndrome) during adolescence.  Some people with severe congenital neutropenia have additional health problems such as seizures
column10: developmental delay
column11: or heart and genital abnormalities.;Severe congenital neutropenia (SCN) is a rare
column12: inherited blood disorder characterized by a severely low number of neutrophils
column13: a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in defending the body against bacterial and fungal infections. This deficiency makes individuals with SCN highly susceptible to recurrent and severe infections
column14: often starting in infancy or early childhood. The severity of SCN can vary
column15: with some individuals experiencing life-threatening infections

column1: 490;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Glioblastoma ?;Is genetic testing available for glioblastoma? Genetic testing is not available for many people with glioblastoma since most of these tumors occur sporadically (by chance) and are not caused by a genetic mutation. However
column2: genetic testing is an option for people with an inherited condition that predisposes to glioblastoma such as neurofibromatosis type 1
column3: Turcot syndrome and Li Fraumeni syndrome. Carrier testing for at-risk relatives and prenatal testing are possible if the disease-causing mutation in the family is known. The Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) is a centralized online resource for information about genetic tests. It provides a list of laboratories performing genetic testing for neurofibromatosis type 1
column4: Turcot syndrome and Li Fraumeni syndrome. The intended audience for the GTR is health care providers and researchers. Patients and consumers with specific questions about a genetic test should contact a health care provider or a genetics professional. How is glioblastoma diagnosed? Glioblastoma is typically diagnosed based on a physical exam that identifies characteristic symptoms and various imaging studies such as computed tomography (CT) and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). A CT scan is an imaging method that uses x-rays to create pictures of cross-sections of the body
column5: while an MRI scan uses powerful magnets and radio waves to create pictures of the brain and surrounding nerve tissues. These imaging studies will also provide information regarding the size of the tumor and which parts of the brain are affected. Surgical removal of the tumor or a small biopsy may confirm the diagnosis.;Glioblastoma
column6: the most aggressive type of brain cancer
column7: requires a comprehensive diagnostic approach. Initial evaluation typically involves a neurological examination and medical history. Brain imaging techniques
column8: such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast
column9: play a crucial role in detecting and characterizing the tumor. Additional tests may include a biopsy
column10: where a small tissue sample is extracted from the tumor for pathological examination. Molecular analysis
column11: such as genetic sequencing
column12: can provide insights into specific genetic alterations driving the tumor's growth
column13: aiding in diagnosis and guiding personalized treatment decisions.;0.009;223.0;79.0;0.269;0.037;0.149;0.681;-0.052;-0.163;0.061

column1: 493;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Alport syndrome ?;What causes Alport syndrome? Alport syndrome may be caused by mutations in either the COL4A3

column4: which plays an important role in the glomeruli of the kidneys. Glomeruli are clusters of specialized blood vessels that remove water and waste products from the blood and create urine. Mutations in the genes mentioned above result in abnormalities of the type IV collagen in glomeruli
column5: which prevents the kidneys from properly filtering the blood. As a result
column6: blood and protein pass into the urine. Over time
column7: the kidneys become scarred and many people with Alport syndrome develop kidney failure. Type IV collagen is also an important component of the organ of Corti

column9: which can lead to hearing loss. In addition
column10: type IV collagen plays a role in the eye
column11: where it helps maintain the shape of the lens and the normal color of the retina. Mutations found in Alport syndrome may affect the shape of the lenses and the color of the retina.;Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins essential for maintaining the structure and function of the kidneys and hearing. column12: sensorineural hearing loss
column13: and eye abnormalities. The most common genetic cause of Alport syndrome is mutations in the COL4A5 gene
column14: which encodes the alpha-5 chain of type IV collagen. Mutations in this gene lead to the production of abnormal type IV collagen
column15: a major component of the basement membranes of the kidneys
column16: inner ear
column17: and eyes. This abnormal collagen leads to structural defects and impaired function of these tissues
