column1: 497;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Renal Artery Stenosis ?;"A health care provider can diagnose RAS by listening to the abdomen with a stethoscope and performing imaging tests. When blood flows through a narrow artery
column2: it sometimes makes a whooshing sound
column3: called a bruit. The health care provider may place a stethoscope on the front or the side of the abdomen to listen for this sound. The absence of this sound
column4: however
column5: does not exclude the possibility of RAS.

column1: In some cases
column2: RAS is found when a person has a test for another reason. For example
column3: a health care provider may find RAS during a coronary angiogram for diagnosis of heart problems. A coronary angiogram is a procedure that uses a special dye
column4: called contrast medium
column5: and x rays to see how blood flows through the heart.

column1: The following imaging tests are used to diagnose RAS:
- Duplex ultrasound. Duplex ultrasound combines traditional ultrasound with Doppler ultrasonography. Traditional ultrasound uses a device
column2: called a transducer
column3: that bounces safe
column4: painless sound waves off organs to create an image of their structure. Doppler ultrasonography records sound waves reflected off of moving objects
column5: such as blood
column6: to measure their speed and other aspects of how they flow. The procedure is performed in a health care providers office
column7: outpatient center
column8: or hospital by a specially trained technician
column9: and the images are interpreted by a radiologista doctor who specializes in medical imaging. Anesthesia is not needed. The images can show blockage in the renal artery or blood moving through nearby arteries at a lower-than-normal speed. Ultrasound is noninvasive and low cost.  - Catheter angiogram. A catheter angiogram
column10: also called a traditional angiogram
column11: is a special kind of x ray in which a thin
column12: flexible tube called a catheter is threaded through the large arteries
column13: often from the groin
column14: to the artery of interestin this case
column15: the renal artery. The procedure is performed in a hospital or outpatient center by a radiologist. Anesthesia is not needed though a sedative may be given to lessen anxiety during the procedure. Contrast medium is injected through the catheter so the renal artery shows up more clearly on the x ray. Catheter angiogram is the gold standard for diagnosing RAS due to the high quality of the image produced. In addition
column16: severe RAS can be treated during the same visit. However
column17: a catheter angiogram is an invasive procedure
column18: and a person may have side effects from the sedative or contrast medium or may have bleeding or injury to the artery from the catheter. The procedure is also more expensive than other imaging tests.  - Computerized tomographic angiography (CTA) scan. CTA scans use a combination of x rays and computer technology to create images. The procedure is performed in an outpatient center or hospital by an x-ray technician
column19: and the images are interpreted by a radiologist. Anesthesia is not needed. Contrast medium is injected into a vein in the persons arm to better see the structure of the arteries. CTA scans require the person to lie on a table that slides into a tunnel-shaped device where the x rays are taken. CTA scans are less invasive than catheter angiograms and take less time. However
column20: the risks from the x-ray radiation still exist
column21: and the test often requires more contrast medium than a catheter angiogram
column22: so it may not be recommended for a person with poor kidney function.  - Magnetic resonance angiogram (MRA). MRA uses radio waves and magnets to produce detailed pictures of the bodys internal organs and soft tissues without using x rays. The procedure is performed in an outpatient center or hospital by an x-ray technician
column23: and the images are interpreted by a radiologist. Anesthesia is not needed though light sedation may be used for people with a fear of confined spaces. Contrast medium may be injected into a vein in the persons arm to better see the structure of the arteries. With most MRA scans
column24: the person lies on a table that slides into a tunnel-shaped device that may be open ended or closed at one end; some newer machines are designed to allow the person to lie in a more open space. In addition to providing high-quality images noninvasively
column25: MRA can provide a functional assessment of blood flow and organ function. However
column26: the use of contrast medium for an MRA is not advised for people with poor kidney function because of the risk of complications to the skin and other organs if the kidneys do not remove the contrast medium well enough.";"Arteriosclerosis is the hardening and loss of elasticity of arteries
column27: primarily caused by the buildup of plaque
column28: which consists of cholesterol
column29: fat
column30: calcium
column31: and fibrous tissue. The condition can be diagnosed through various methods:

column1: 1. Physical Examination:
A healthcare provider can physically examine your arteries for signs of hardening or stiffness. They may feel for a pulse in your arteries and check for any irregularities in your heartbeat.
2. Blood Pressure Measurement:
High blood pressure is a common sign of arteriosclerosis. Your healthcare provider will measure your blood pressure to check for elevated levels.
3. Blood Test:
A blood test can measure the level of certain substances in your blood
column2: such as cholesterol
column3: triglycerides
column4: and glucose. High levels of these substances can indicate an increased risk of arteriosclerosis.

column1: 4. Imaging Tests:
Imaging tests
column2: such as X-rays
column3: CT scans
column4: and MRI
column5: can help visualize your arteries and detect any abnormalities
column6: such as narrowing or plaque buildup.

column1: 5. Angiography:

This procedure involves inserting a catheter into an artery and injecting a contrast material. X-ray images are then taken to visualize the interior of the artery and identify any areas of narrowing or plaque buildup.
6. Stress Test:

A stress test involves exercising on a treadmill or stationary bike while your heart rate and blood pressure are monitored. This test can help identify areas of the artery that are narrowed or blocked
column2: causing chest pain or shortness of breath.

column1: 7. Pulse Oximetry:
Pulse oximetry measures the amount of oxygen in your blood. Low oxygen levels may indicate poor circulation due to arteriosclerosis.
8. Echocardiogram:

This ultrasound procedure evaluates your heart's structure and function. It can help identify any abnormalities caused by arteriosclerosis.";0.003;639.0;261.0;0.23;0.022;0.122;0.456;-0.104;-0.151;-0.059

column1: 513;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Polycythemia Vera ?;"Polycythemia vera (POL-e-si-THEE-me-ah VAY-rah or VE-rah)
column2: or PV
column3: is a rare blood disease in which your body makes too many red blood cells.

column1: The extra red blood cells make your blood thicker than normal. As a result
column2: blood clots can form more easily. These clots can block blood flow through your arteries and veins
column3: which can cause a heart attack or stroke.

column1: Thicker blood also doesn't flow as quickly to your body as normal blood. Slowed blood flow prevents your organs from getting enough oxygen
column2: which can cause serious problems
column3: such as angina (an-JI-nuh or AN-juh-nuh) and heart failure. (Angina is chest pain or discomfort.)

column1: Overview
Red blood cells carry oxygen to all parts of your body. They also remove carbon dioxide (a waste product) from your body's cells and carry it to the lungs to be exhaled.

Red blood cells are made in your bone marrowa sponge-like tissue inside the bones. White blood cells and platelets (PLATE-lets) also are made in your bone marrow. White blood cells help fight infection. Platelets stick together to seal small cuts or breaks on blood vessel walls and stop bleeding.
If you have PV
column2: your bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. It also can make too many white blood cells and platelets.

column1: A mutation
column2: or change
column3: in the body's JAK2 gene is the major cause of PV. This gene makes a protein that helps the body produce blood cells. What causes the change in the JAK2 gene isn't known. PV generally isn't inheritedthat is
column4: passed from parents to children through genes.

column1: PV develops slowly and may not cause symptoms for years. The disease often is found during routine blood tests done for other reasons.
When signs and symptoms are present
column2: they're the result of the thick blood that occurs with PV. This thickness slows the flow of oxygen-rich blood to all parts of your body. Without enough oxygen
column3: many parts of your body won't work normally.

column1: For example
column2: slower blood flow deprives your arms
column3: legs
column4: lungs
column5: and eyes of the oxygen they need. This can cause headaches
column6: dizziness
column7: itching
column8: and vision problems
column9: such as blurred or double vision.

column1: Outlook
PV is a serious
column2: chronic (ongoing) disease that can be fatal if not diagnosed and treated. PV has no cure
column3: but treatments can help control the disease and its complications.

column1: PV is treated with procedures
column2: medicines
column3: and other methods. You may need one or more treatments to manage the disease.";Polycythemia vera (PV) is a rare blood cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. column1: 517;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Cancer--Living with Cancer;Summary : Cancer is common. Half of all men and a third of women will get a diagnosis of cancer in their lifetime. Many people with cancer do survive. Millions of Americans alive today have a history of cancer.    For most people with cancer
column2: living with the disease is the biggest challenge they have ever faced. It can change your routines
column3: roles and relationships. It can cause money and work problems. The treatment can change the way you feel and look. Learning more about ways you can help yourself may ease some of your concerns. Support from others is important.    All cancer survivors should have follow-up care. Knowing what to expect after cancer treatment can help you and your family make plans
column4: lifestyle changes
column5: and important decisions.    NIH: National Cancer Institute;Living with cancer poses unique challenges that require a comprehensive approach to care. Beyond medical treatment
column6: emotional and psychological well-being play a vital role. Maintaining a positive mindset
column7: engaging in self-care practices
column8: and seeking support from loved ones
column9: healthcare professionals
column10: and support groups can help individuals cope with the emotional toll of cancer. Additionally
column11: focusing on healthy lifestyle choices
column12: including a balanced diet
column13: regular exercise
column14: and adequate sleep

column1: 523;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Cowden syndrome ?;"Changes involving at least four genes
column2: PTEN
column3: SDHB
column4: SDHD
column5: and KLLN
column6: have been identified in people with Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome.  Most cases of Cowden syndrome and a small percentage of cases of Cowden-like syndrome result from mutations in the PTEN gene. The protein produced from the PTEN gene is a tumor suppressor
column7: which means that it normally prevents cells from growing and dividing (proliferating) too rapidly or in an uncontrolled way. Mutations in the PTEN gene prevent the protein from regulating cell proliferation effectively
column8: leading to uncontrolled cell division and the formation of hamartomas and cancerous tumors. The PTEN gene likely has other important functions within cells; however
column9: it is unclear how mutations in this gene cause the other features of Cowden syndrome
column10: such as macrocephaly and intellectual disability.  Other cases of Cowden syndrome and Cowden-like syndrome result from changes involving the KLLN gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called killin. Like the protein produced from the PTEN gene
column11: killin probably acts as a tumor suppressor. The genetic change that causes Cowden syndrome and Cowden-like syndrome is known as promoter hypermethylation. The promoter is a region of DNA near the gene that controls gene activity (expression). Hypermethylation occurs when too many small molecules called methyl groups are attached to the promoter region. The extra methyl groups reduce the expression of the KLLN gene
column12: which means that less killin is produced. A reduced amount of killin may allow abnormal cells to survive and proliferate inappropriately
column13: which can lead to the formation of tumors.  A small percentage of people with Cowden syndrome or Cowden-like syndrome have variations in the SDHB or SDHD gene. These genes provide instructions for making parts of an enzyme called succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)
column14: which is important for energy production in the cell. This enzyme also plays a role in signaling pathways that regulate cell survival and proliferation. Variations in the SDHB or SDHD gene alter the function of the SDH enzyme. Studies suggest that the defective enzyme may allow cells to grow and divide unchecked
column15: leading to the formation of hamartomas and cancerous tumors. However
column16: researchers are uncertain whether the identified SDHB and SDHD gene variants are directly associated with Cowden syndrome and Cowden-like syndrome. Some of the variants described above have also been identified in people without the features of these conditions.  When Cowden syndrome and Cowden-like syndrome are not related to changes in the PTEN
column17: SDHB
column20: the cause of the conditions is unknown.";Cowden syndrome is caused by mutations in the PTEN tumor suppressor gene
column21: located on chromosome 10q23.31. This gene encodes a protein called phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN)
column22: which plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth
column23: proliferation
column24: and apoptosis. Mutations in PTEN lead to an overgrowth of cells
column25: resulting in the development of benign hamartomas and an increased risk of certain types of cancer
column28: and endometrial cancers. Additionally
column29: individuals with Cowden syndrome may exhibit macrocephaly (large head circumference)
column30: intellectual disability

column1: 525;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) familial HDL deficiency ?;"Familial HDL deficiency is a condition characterized by low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in the blood. HDL is a molecule that transports cholesterol and certain fats called phospholipids through the bloodstream from the body's tissues to the liver. Once in the liver
column2: cholesterol and phospholipids are redistributed to other tissues or removed from the body. HDL is often referred to as ""good cholesterol"" because high levels of this substance reduce the chances of developing heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) disease. People with familial HDL deficiency may develop cardiovascular disease at a relatively young age
column3: often before age 50.  Severely reduced levels of HDL in the blood is a characteristic feature of a related disorder called Tangier disease. People with Tangier disease have additional signs and symptoms
column4: such as disturbances in nerve function; enlarged
column5: orange-colored tonsils; and clouding of the clear covering of the eye (corneal clouding). However
column6: people with familial HDL deficiency do not have these additional features.";"Familial HDL deficiency is a rare genetic disorder characterized by extremely low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol in the blood. HDL cholesterol
column7: often referred to as ""good cholesterol
column8: plays a crucial role in removing excess cholesterol from the body and transporting it back to the liver for elimination. This deficiency can lead to an increased risk of developing cardiovascular diseases
column9: such as heart attacks and strokes
column10: due to the accumulation of cholesterol in the arteries. Familial HDL deficiency can be caused by mutations in several genes involved in HDL metabolism
column11: with each mutation leading to a specific type of the disorder. Management typically involves lifestyle modifications
column12: such as a healthy diet
column13: regular exercise
column14: and weight control
column15: along with medications to lower triglycerides and increase HDL levels
column16: though genetic therapies are being explored as potential future treatments.";0.124;144.0;126.0;0.346;0.163;0.291;0.765;0.186;0.151;0.219

column1: 529;gemini-pro;stages;What are the stages of Merkel Cell Carcinoma ?;"Key Points
- After Merkel cell carcinoma has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.    - There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.    - Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.    - The following stages are used for Merkel cell carcinoma:          - Stage 0 (carcinoma in situ)     - Stage IA     - Stage IB     - Stage IIA     - Stage IIB     - Stage IIC     - Stage IIIA     - Stage IIIB     - Stage IV

column1: After Merkel cell carcinoma has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.

column1: The process used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body is called staging. The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease. It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.    The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process:         -   CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body
column2: taken from different angles. The pictures are made by a computer linked to an x-ray machine. A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen may be used to check for primary small cell lung cancer
column3: or to find Merkel cell carcinoma that has spread. A CT scan of the head and neck may also be used to find Merkel cell carcinoma that has spread to the lymph nodes. This procedure is also called computed tomography
column4: computerized tomography
column5: or computerized axial tomography.    -   MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet
column6: radio waves
column7: and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body. This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).    -   PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body. A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein. The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body. Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.    -  Lymph node biopsy : There are two main types of lymph node biopsy used to stage Merkel cell carcinoma.               -  Sentinel lymph node biopsy : The removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery. The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor. It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor. A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor. The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes. The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed. A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells. If cancer cells are not found
column8: it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.      -  Lymph node dissection : A surgical procedure in which the lymph nodes are removed and a sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer. For a regional lymph node dissection
column9: some of the lymph nodes in the tumor area are removed. For a radical lymph node dissection
column10: most or all of the lymph nodes in the tumor area are removed. This procedure is also called lymphadenectomy.             -   Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue. The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope. This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.

column1: There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.
Cancer can spread through tissue
column2: the lymph system
column3: and the blood:         - Tissue. The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.     - Lymph system. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system. The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.     - Blood. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood. The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.

column1: Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.
When cancer spreads to another part of the body
column2: it is called metastasis. Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.         - Lymph system. The cancer gets into the lymph system
column3: travels through the lymph vessels
column4: and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.    - Blood. The cancer gets into the blood
column5: travels through the blood vessels
column6: and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.        The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor. For example
column7: if Merkel cell carcinoma spreads to the liver
column8: the cancer cells in the liver are actually cancerous Merkel cells. The disease is metastatic Merkel cell carcinoma
column9: not liver cancer.

column1: The following stages are used for Merkel cell carcinoma:
Stage 0 (carcinoma in situ)    In stage 0
column2: the tumor is a group of abnormal cells that remain in the place where they first formed and have not spread. These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread to lymph nodes or distant parts of the body.       Stage IA    In stage IA
column3: the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller at its widest point and no cancer is found when the lymph nodes are checked under a microscope.       Stage IB    In stage IB
column4: the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller at its widest point and no swollen lymph nodes are found by a physical exam or imaging tests.       Stage IIA    In stage IIA
column5: the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters and no cancer is found when the lymph nodes are checked under a microscope.       Stage IIB    In stage IIB
column6: the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters and no swollen lymph nodes are found by a physical exam or imaging tests.       Stage IIC    In stage IIC
column7: the tumor may be any size and has spread to nearby bone
column8: muscle
column9: connective tissue
column10: or cartilage. It has not spread to lymph nodes or distant parts of the body.       Stage IIIA    In stage IIIA
column11: the tumor may be any size and may have spread to nearby bone
column12: muscle
column13: connective tissue
column14: or cartilage. Cancer is found in the lymph nodes when they are checked under a microscope.       Stage IIIB    In stage IIIB
column15: the tumor may be any size and may have spread to nearby bone
column16: muscle
column17: connective tissue
column18: or cartilage. Cancer has spread to the lymph nodes near the tumor and is found by a physical exam or imaging test. The lymph nodes are removed and cancer is found in the lymph nodes when they are checked under a microscope. There may also be a second tumor
column19: which is either:            - Between the primary tumor and nearby lymph nodes; or     - Farther away from the center of the body than the primary tumor is.              Stage IV    In stage IV
column20: the tumor may be any size and has spread to distant parts of the body
column21: such as the liver
column22: lung
column23: bone
column24: or brain.";"Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) is a rare and aggressive skin cancer that arises from Merkel cells
column25: specialized touch receptor cells found in the skin. The stages of MCC are determined by the extent of the tumor's growth and spread. The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) staging system for MCC is as follows:

column1: **Stage 0:** The tumor is confined to the epidermis
column2: the outermost layer of the skin.

column1: **Stage I:** The tumor is localized to the skin and is less than 2 centimeters (cm) in diameter.
**Stage II:** The tumor is localized to the skin and is between 2 cm and 5 cm in diameter
column2: or there are multiple tumors
column3: each less than 2 cm in diameter.

column1: **Stage IIIA:** The tumor has spread to nearby lymph nodes
column2: but not to distant sites.

column1: **Stage IIIB:** The tumor has spread to distant sites
column2: such as the lungs
column3: liver
column4: or bone.

column1: **Stage IV:** The tumor is recurrent

column1: 532;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Dermatomyositis ?;How is dermatomyositis treated? While there is no cure for dermatomyositis

column1: 537;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) primary myelofibrosis ?;Primary myelofibrosis is a condition characterized by the buildup of scar tissue (fibrosis) in the bone marrow
column2: the tissue that produces blood cells. Because of the fibrosis
column3: the bone marrow is unable to make enough normal blood cells. The shortage of blood cells causes many of the signs and symptoms of primary myelofibrosis.  Initially
column4: most people with primary myelofibrosis have no signs or symptoms. Eventually
column5: fibrosis can lead to a reduction in the number of red blood cells
column6: white blood cells
column7: and platelets. A shortage of red blood cells (anemia) often causes extreme tiredness (fatigue) or shortness of breath. A loss of white blood cells can lead to an increased number of infections
column8: and a reduction of platelets can cause easy bleeding or bruising.  Because blood cell formation (hematopoiesis) in the bone marrow is disrupted
column9: other organs such as the spleen or liver may begin to produce blood cells. This process
column10: called extramedullary hematopoiesis
column11: often leads to an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly) or an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). People with splenomegaly may feel pain or fullness in the abdomen
column12: especially below the ribs on the left side. Other common signs and symptoms of primary myelofibrosis include fever
column13: night sweats
column14: and bone pain.  Primary myelofibrosis is most commonly diagnosed in people aged 50 to 80 but can occur at any age.;Primary myelofibrosis (PMF)
column15: also known as chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis
column16: is a rare type of blood cancer that affects the bone marrow. It is characterized by the formation of fibrous tissue in the bone marrow
column17: which leads to scarring and thickening. This scarring can interfere with the production of blood cells
column20: and other symptoms. PMF is a chronic disease that can progress over time
column21: and there is no cure. Treatment options aim to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.;0.012;197.0;77.0;0.323;0.066;0.236;0.661;0.063;-0.029;0.156

column1: 539;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) MPV17-related hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome ?;MPV17-related hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome is an inherited disorder that can cause liver disease and neurological problems. column12: which can lead to open sores and scarring on the cornea
column13: resulting in impaired vision. The cause of these additional features is unknown.;MPV17-related hepatocerebral mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome is a rare

column1: 542;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Thalassemia ?;Thalassemias are inherited blood disorders. If you have one

column14: Lung
column15: and Blood Institute;Thalassemia is a group of inherited blood disorders that reduce the production of hemoglobin

column1: 562;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose What I need to know about Hirschsprung Disease ?;"HD is diagnosed based on symptoms and test results.

column1: X rays

column2: the doctor may fill it with barium liquid. Barium liquid is inserted into the large intestine through the anus.

column1: If HD is the problem

column1: Manometry
During manometry
column2: the doctor inflates a small balloon inside the rectum. Normally
column3: the rectal muscles will relax. If the muscles dont relax
column4: HD may be the problem. This test is most often done in older children and adults.

column1: Biopsy

column13: and tumors. Laboratory tests can help find the cause. The kind of treatment depends on why you have low blood sugar.    NIH: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases;Hypoglycemia is a condition in which the blood sugar (glucose) level falls too low. Glucose is the body's main source of energy
column14: and without it

column17: taking too much insulin or other diabetes medications
column19: and exercising too much. Symptoms of hypoglycemia can include sweating
column20: shaking
column21: hunger
column22: dizziness
column23: confusion

column1: 573;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Hypopharyngeal Cancer ?;"New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.
Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.
Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.
For some patients
column2: taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice. Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process. Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.   Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials. Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.   Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future. Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments
column3: they often answer important questions and help move research forward.

column1: Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.

column1: Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment. Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better. There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.   Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country. See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials. These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.";"Clinical trials are exploring various treatment strategies for hypopharyngeal cancer
column2: such as:

column1: - Targeted therapy: Drugs that target specific molecules involved in cancer growth and spread
column2: such as EGFR or VEGF inhibitors.

column1: - Immunotherapy: Enhancing the body's immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells. This includes immune checkpoint inhibitors
column2: adoptive cell therapy
column3: and cancer vaccines.

column1: - Radiation therapy techniques: Advanced radiation therapy techniques
column2: such as intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) and image-guided radiation therapy (IGRT)
column3: to deliver precise radiation doses while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissues.

column1: - Novel chemotherapy agents: Developing new chemotherapy drugs and combinations to improve treatment effectiveness and reduce side effects.
- Multimodal approaches: Combining different treatment modalities
column2: such as surgery
column3: radiation therapy
column4: chemotherapy
column5: and targeted therapy
column6: to achieve better outcomes.

column1: - Minimally invasive surgical techniques: Exploring less invasive surgical approaches
column2: such as transoral robotic surgery
column3: to remove tumors while preserving surrounding structures.";0.012;234.0;140.0;0.167;0.024;0.137;0.404;-0.163;-0.135;-0.194

column1: 580;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Ultrasound;Summary : Ultrasound is a type of imaging. It uses high-frequency sound waves to look at organs and structures inside the body. Health care professionals use it to view the heart
column2: blood vessels
column3: kidneys
column4: liver
column5: and other organs. During pregnancy
column6: doctors use ultrasound to view the fetus. Unlike x-rays
column7: ultrasound does not expose you to radiation.    During an ultrasound test
column8: you lie on a table. A special technician or doctor moves a device called a transducer over part of your body. The transducer sends out sound waves
column9: which bounce off the tissues inside your body. The transducer also captures the waves that bounce back. The ultrasound machine creates images from the sound waves.;Ultrasound
column10: also known as sonography
column11: is a non-invasive medical imaging technique that uses high-frequency sound waves to produce real-time images of the body's internal organs
column12: tissues
column13: and blood vessels. It utilizes a transducer to emit sound waves into the body
column14: which bounce off tissues and structures and return to the transducer. The reflected sound waves are then processed and converted into images that can be viewed on a monitor. Ultrasound is commonly used for various medical purposes
column15: including prenatal imaging
column16: abdominal and pelvic organ evaluation
column17: cardiac assessments
column19: and musculoskeletal examinations. It is a versatile and widely accessible imaging modality due to its safety
column20: portability
column21: and ability to provide real-time visualization of body structures.;0.086;97.0;107.0;0.342;0.103;0.247;0.79;0.152;0.191;0.11

column1: 581;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Angina ?;"Treatments for angina include lifestyle changes
column2: medicines
column3: medical procedures
column4: cardiac rehabilitation (rehab)
column5: and other therapies. The main goals of treatment are to:

column1: Reduce pain and discomfort and how often it occurs
Prevent or lower your risk for heart attack and death by treating your underlying heart condition
Lifestyle changes and medicines may be the only treatments needed if your symptoms are mild and aren't getting worse. If lifestyle changes and medicines don't control angina
column2: you may need medical procedures or cardiac rehab.

column1: Unstable angina is an emergency condition that requires treatment in a hospital.
Lifestyle Changes
Making lifestyle changes can help prevent episodes of angina. You can:
Slow down or take rest breaks if physical exertion triggers angina.
Avoid large meals and rich foods that leave you feeling stuffed if heavy meals trigger angina.
Try to avoid situations that make you upset or stressed if emotional stress triggers angina. Learn ways to handle stress that can't be avoided.

You also can make lifestyle changes that help lower your risk for coronary heart disease. One of the most important changes is to quit smoking. Smoking can damage and tighten blood vessels and raise your risk for CHD. Talk with your doctor about programs and products that can help you quit. Also
column2: try to avoid secondhand smoke.

column1: If you have trouble quitting smoking on your own
column2: consider joining a support group. Many hospitals
column3: workplaces
column4: and community groups offer classes to help people quit smoking.

column1: For more information about how to quit smoking
column2: go to the Diseases and Conditions Index (DCI) Smoking and Your Heart article and the National Heart
column3: Lung
column4: and Blood Institutes (NHLBIs) ""Your Guide to a Healthy Heart.""

column1: Following a healthy diet is another important lifestyle change. A healthy diet can prevent or reduce high blood pressure and high blood cholesterol and help you maintain a healthy weight.
A healthy diet includes a variety of fruits and vegetables (including beans and peas). It also includes whole grains
column2: lean meats
column3: poultry without skin
column4: seafood
column5: and fat-free or low-fat milk and dairy products. A healthy diet also is low in sodium (salt)
column6: added sugars
column7: solid fats
column8: and refined grains.

column1: For more information about following a healthy diet
column2: go to the NHLBIs Your Guide to Lowering Your Blood Pressure With DASH and the U.S. Department of Agricultures ChooseMyPlate.gov Web site. Both resources provide general information about healthy eating.

column1: Other important lifestyle changes include:
Being physically active. Check with your doctor to find out how much and what kinds of activity are safe for you. For more information
column2: go to the DCI Physical Activity and Your Heart article.

column1: Maintaining a healthy weight. If youre overweight or obese
column2: work with your doctor to create a reasonable weight-loss plan. Controlling your weight helps you control CHD risk factors.

column1: Taking all medicines as your doctor prescribes
column2: especially if you have diabetes.

column1: Medicines
Nitrates are the medicines most commonly used to treat angina. They relax and widen blood vessels. This allows more blood to flow to the heart
column2: while reducing the hearts workload.

column1: Nitroglycerin (NI-tro-GLIS-er-in) is the most commonly used nitrate for angina. Nitroglycerin that dissolves under your tongue or between your cheek and gum is used to relieve angina episodes.
Nitroglycerin pills and skin patches are used to prevent angina episodes. However
column2: pills and skin patches act too slowly to relieve pain during an angina attack.

column1: Other medicines also are used to treat angina
column2: such as beta blockers
column3: calcium channel blockers
column4: ACE inhibitors
column5: oral antiplatelet medicines
column6: or anticoagulants (blood thinners). These medicines can help:

column1: Lower blood pressure and cholesterol levels
Slow the heart rate
Relax blood vessels
Reduce strain on the heart
Prevent blood clots from forming
People who have stable angina may be advised to get annual flu shots.
Medical Procedures
If lifestyle changes and medicines don't control angina
column2: you may need a medical procedure to treat the underlying heart disease. Both angioplasty (AN-jee-oh-plas-tee) and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) are commonly used to treat heart disease.

column1: Angioplasty opens blocked or narrowed coronary arteries. During angioplasty
column2: a thin tube with a balloon or other device on the end is threaded through a blood vessel to the narrowed or blocked coronary artery.

column1: Once in place
column2: the balloon is inflated to push the plaque outward against the wall of the artery. This widens the artery and restores blood flow.

column1: Angioplasty can improve blood flow to your heart and relieve chest pain. A small mesh tube called a stent usually is placed in the artery to help keep it open after the procedure.
During CABG
column2: healthy arteries or veins taken from other areas in your body are used to bypass (that is
column3: go around) your narrowed coronary arteries. Bypass surgery can improve blood flow to your heart
column4: relieve chest pain
column5: and possibly prevent a heart attack.

column1: You will work with your doctor to decide which treatment is better for you.
Cardiac Rehabilitation
Your doctor may recommend cardiac rehab for angina or after angioplasty
column2: CABG
column3: or a heart attack. Cardiac rehab is a medically supervised program that can help improve the health and well-being of people who have heart problems.

column1: The cardiac rehab team may include doctors
column2: nurses
column3: exercise specialists
column4: physical and occupational therapists
column5: dietitians or nutritionists
column6: and psychologists or other mental health specialists.

column1: Rehab has two parts:
Exercise training. This part helps you learn how to exercise safely
column2: strengthen your muscles
column3: and improve your stamina. Your exercise plan will be based on your personal abilities
column4: needs
column5: and interests.

column1: Education
column2: counseling
column3: and training. This part of rehab helps you understand your heart condition and find ways to reduce your risk for future heart problems. The rehab team will help you learn how to adjust to a new lifestyle and deal with your fears about the future.

column1: For more information about cardiac rehab
column2: go to the DCI Cardiac Rehabilitation article.

column1: Enhanced External Counterpulsation Therapy
Enhanced external counterpulsation (EECP) therapy is helpful for some people who have angina. Large cuffs
column2: similar to blood pressure cuffs
column3: are put on your legs. The cuffs are inflated and deflated in sync with your heartbeat.

column1: EECP therapy improves the flow of oxygen-rich blood to your heart muscle and helps relieve angina. You typically get 35 1-hour treatments over 7 weeks.";Angina

column1: 587;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Wilson Disease ?;"A health care provider may use several tests and exams to diagnose Wilson disease
column2: including the following:

column1: - medical and family history  - physical exam  - blood tests  - urine tests  - liver biopsy  - imaging tests
Health care providers typically see the same symptoms of Wilson disease in other conditions
column2: and the symptoms of Wilson disease do not occur together often
column3: making the disease difficult to diagnose.

column1: Medical and Family History
A health care provider may take a medical and family history to help diagnose Wilson disease.
Physical Exam
A physical exam may help diagnose Wilson disease. During a physical exam
column2: a health care provider usually

column1: - examines a patients body  - uses a stethoscope to listen to sounds related to the abdomen
A health care provider will use a special light called a slit lamp to look for Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes.
Blood Tests
A nurse or technician will draw blood samples at a health care providers office or a commercial facility and send the samples to a lab for analysis. A health care provider may

- perform liver enzyme or function testsblood tests that may indicate liver abnormalities.  - check copper levels in the blood. Since the copper is deposited into the organs and is not circulating in the blood
column2: most people with Wilson disease have a lower-than-normal level of copper in the blood. In cases of acute liver failure caused by Wilson disease
column3: the level of blood copper is often higher than normal.  - check the level of ceruloplasmina protein that carries copper in the bloodstream. Most people with Wilson disease have a lower-than-normal ceruloplasmin level.  - conduct genetic testing. A health care provider may recommend genetic testing in cases of a known family history of Wilson disease.

column1: Urine Tests

24-hour urine collection. A patient will collect urine at home in a special container provided by a health care providers office or a commercial facility. A health care provider sends the sample to a lab for analysis. A 24-hour urine collection will show increased copper in the urine in most patients who have symptoms due to Wilson disease.
Liver Biopsy

A liver biopsy is a procedure that involves taking a small piece of liver tissue for examination with a microscope for signs of damage or disease. The health care provider may ask the patient to stop taking certain medications temporarily before the liver biopsy. He or she may also ask the patient to fasteat or drink nothingfor 8 hours before the procedure.
During the procedure
column2: the patient lies on a table
column3: right hand resting above the head. The health care provider applies a local anesthetic to the area where he or she will insert the biopsy needle. If needed
column4: a health care provider will also give sedatives and pain medication. The health care provider uses the needle to take a small piece of liver tissue. He or she may use ultrasound
column5: computerized tomography scans
column6: or other imaging techniques to guide the needle. After the biopsy
column7: the patient must lie on the right side for up to 2 hours and is monitored an additional 2 to 4 hours before being sent home.

column1: A pathologista doctor who specializes in diagnosing diseasesexamines the liver tissue in a lab. The test can show cirrhosis of the liver. Sometimes the liver biopsy will show copper buildup in the liver cells; however
column2: the results can vary because the copper does not always deposit evenly into the liver. Therefore
column3: health care providers often find it more useful to analyze a piece of liver tissue for copper content. Most patients with Wilson disease have high levels of copper in the liver tissue when compared with carriers or with people who do not have Wilson disease.

column1: More information is provided in the NIDDK health topic
column2: Liver Biopsy.

column1: Imaging Tests
A health care provider may order imaging tests to evaluate brain abnormalities in patients who have nervous system symptoms often seen with Wilson disease
column2: or in patients diagnosed with Wilson disease. Health care providers do not use brain imaging tests to diagnose Wilson disease
column3: though certain findings may suggest the patient has the disease.

column1: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). An MRI is a test that takes pictures of the bodys internal organs and soft tissues without using x rays. A specially trained technician performs the procedure in an outpatient center or a hospital
column2: and a radiologista doctor who specializes in medical imaginginterprets the images. The patient does not need anesthesia
column3: though people with a fear of confined spaces may receive light sedation
column4: taken by mouth. An MRI may include the injection of a special dye
column5: called contrast medium. With most MRI machines
column6: the patient will lie on a table that slides into a tunnel-shaped device that may be open ended or closed at one end. Some machines allow the patient to lie in a more open space. The technician will take a sequence of images from different angles to create a detailed picture of the brain. During sequencing
column7: the patient will hear loud mechanical knocking and humming noises. MRI can show if other diseases or conditions are causing the patients neurological symptoms.

column1: Computerized tomography (CT) scan. A CT scan uses a combination of x rays and computer technology to create images. For a CT scan
column2: a health care provider may give the patient a solution to drink and an injection of contrast medium. CT scans require the patient to lie on a table that slides into a tunnel-shaped device where a technician takes the x rays. An x-ray technician performs the procedure in an outpatient center or a hospital. A radiologist interprets the images. The patient does not need anesthesia. A CT scan can show if other diseases or conditions are causing the patients neurological symptoms.";Wilson disease is diagnosed through a combination of blood tests
column3: urine tests
column4: liver biopsy
column5: and genetic testing. Blood tests measure levels of copper and ceruloplasmin
column6: a protein that binds to copper. Urine tests measure the amount of copper excreted in the urine. A liver biopsy can show signs of copper accumulation and damage to the liver. Genetic testing can identify mutations in the ATP7B gene
column7: which is responsible for copper metabolism. A definitive diagnosis of Wilson disease requires the presence of both high levels of copper in the liver and a mutation in the ATP7B gene.;0.0;816.0;84.0;0.15;0.058;0.106;0.758;-0.07;-0.244;0.113

column1: 593;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Hashimoto thyroiditis ?;Hashimoto thyroiditis is thought to result from a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Some of these factors have been identified
column2: but many remain unknown.  Hashimoto thyroiditis is classified as an autoimmune disorder
column3: one of a large group of conditions that occur when the immune system attacks the body's own tissues and organs. In people with Hashimoto thyroiditis
column4: white blood cells called lymphocytes accumulate abnormally in the thyroid
column5: which can damage it. The lymphocytes make immune system proteins called antibodies that attack and destroy thyroid cells. When too many thyroid cells become damaged or die
column6: the thyroid can no longer make enough hormones to regulate body functions. This shortage of thyroid hormones underlies the signs and symptoms of Hashimoto thyroiditis. However
column7: some people with thyroid antibodies never develop hypothyroidism or experience any related signs or symptoms.  People with Hashimoto thyroiditis have an increased risk of developing other autoimmune disorders
column8: including vitiligo
column9: rheumatoid arthritis
column10: Addison disease
column11: type 1 diabetes
column12: multiple sclerosis
column13: and pernicious anemia.  Variations in several genes have been studied as possible risk factors for Hashimoto thyroiditis. Some of these genes are part of a family called the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex. The HLA complex helps the immune system distinguish the body's own proteins from proteins made by foreign invaders (such as viruses and bacteria). Other genes that have been associated with Hashimoto thyroiditis help regulate the immune system or are involved in normal thyroid function. Most of the genetic variations that have been discovered are thought to have a small impact on a person's overall risk of developing this condition.  Other
column14: nongenetic factors also play a role in Hashimoto thyroiditis. These factors may trigger the condition in people who are at risk
column15: although the mechanism is unclear. Potential triggers include changes in sex hormones (particularly in women)

column1: 597;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Gastritis ?;"Health care providers treat gastritis with medications to
- reduce the amount of acid in the stomach  - treat the underlying cause
Reduce the Amount of Acid in the Stomach
The stomach lining of a person with gastritis may have less protection from acidic digestive juice. Reducing acid can promote healing of the stomach lining. Medications that reduce acid include
- antacids
column2: such as Alka-Seltzer
column3: Maalox
column4: Mylanta
column5: Rolaids
column6: and Riopan. Many brands use different combinations of three basic saltsmagnesium
column7: aluminum
column8: and calciumalong with hydroxide or bicarbonate ions to neutralize stomach acid. Antacids
column9: however
column10: can have side effects. Magnesium salt can lead to diarrhea
column11: and aluminum salt can cause constipation. Magnesium and aluminum salts are often combined in a single product to balance these effects. Calcium carbonate antacids
column12: such as Tums
column13: Titralac
column14: and Alka-2
column15: can cause constipation.  - H2 blockers
column16: such as cimetidine (Tagamet HB)
column17: famotidine (Pepcid AC)
column19: and ranitidine (Zantac 75). H2 blockers decrease acid production. They are available in both over-the-counter and prescription strengths.  - proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) include omeprazole (Prilosec
column20: Zegerid)
column21: lansoprazole (Prevacid)
column22: dexlansoprazole (Dexilant)
column23: pantoprazole (Protonix)
column24: rabeprazole (AcipHex)
column25: and esomeprazole (Nexium). PPIs decrease acid production more effectively than H2 blockers. All of these medications are available by prescription. Omeprazole and lansoprazole are also available in over-the-counter strength.

column1: Treat the Underlying Cause
Depending on the cause of gastritis
column2: a health care provider may recommend additional treatments.

column1: - Treating H. pylori infection with antibiotics is important
column2: even if a person does not have symptoms from the infection. Curing the infection often cures the gastritis and decreases the chance of developing complications
column3: such as peptic ulcer disease
column4: MALT lymphoma
column5: and gastric cancer.  - Avoiding the cause of reactive gastritis can provide some people with a cure. For example
column6: if prolonged NSAID use is the cause of the gastritis
column7: a health care provider may advise the patient to stop taking the NSAIDs
column8: reduce the dose
column9: or change pain medications.  - Health care providers may prescribe medications to prevent or treat stress gastritis in a patient who is critically ill or injured. Medications to protect the stomach lining include sucralfate (Carafate)
column10: H2 blockers
column11: and PPIs. Treating the underlying illness or injury most often cures stress gastritis.  - Health care providers may treat people with pernicious anemia due to autoimmune atrophic gastritis with vitamin B12 injections.";"Gastritis treatments vary depending on the underlying cause. Common treatments include:

column1: * Antacids: These medications neutralize stomach acid and can provide relief from heartburn
column2: indigestion
column3: and pain.

column1: * Histamine-2 receptor antagonists (H2RAs): These medications reduce stomach acid production.
* Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs): These medications block stomach acid production and are more effective than H2RAs.
* Antibiotics: These medications are used to treat gastritis caused by bacterial infection
column2: such as H. pylori.

column1: * Prokinetics: These medications help to move food and fluids through the stomach and intestines more quickly.
* Lifestyle changes: Avoiding spicy
column2: fatty
column3: or acidic foods
column4: quitting smoking
column5: and reducing alcohol consumption can help to reduce symptoms of gastritis.";0.007;350.0;103.0;0.316;0.085;0.195;0.713;-0.129;-0.325;0.081

column1: 599;gemini-pro;outlook;What is the outlook for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome ?;The outcome for individuals with TOS varies according to type. The majority of individuals with TOS will improve with exercise and physical therapy. Vascular TOS

column5: surgery may be necessary to relieve the compression on the nerves and blood vessels. After surgery
column6: most people experience significant improvement in their symptoms and are able to return to their normal activities. However
column7: some people may experience persistent symptoms or develop complications
column8: such as nerve damage or blood clots. Overall
column9: the outlook for thoracic outlet syndrome is generally good with early diagnosis and appropriate treatment.;0.014;38.0;107.0;0.286;0.031;0.286;0.412;0.166;0.287;0.048

column1: 601;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to methemoglobinemia
column2: beta-globin type ?;"Methemoglobinemia
column3: beta-globin type is caused by mutations in the HBB gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called beta-globin. Beta-globin is one of four components (subunits) that make up hemoglobin. In adults
column4: hemoglobin normally contains two subunits of beta-globin and two subunits of another protein called alpha-globin. Each of these protein subunits is bound to an iron-containing molecule called heme; each heme contains an iron molecule in its center that can bind to one oxygen molecule. For hemoglobin to bind to oxygen
column5: the iron within the heme molecule needs to be in a form called ferrous iron (Fe2+). The iron within the heme can change to another form of iron called ferric iron (Fe3+)
column6: which cannot bind oxygen. Hemoglobin that contains ferric iron is known as methemoglobin.  HBB gene mutations that cause methemoglobinemia
column7: beta-globin type change the structure of beta-globin and promote the heme iron to change from ferrous to ferric. The ferric iron cannot bind oxygen and causes cyanosis and the brown appearance of blood.";Methemoglobinemia
column8: beta-globin type
column9: is a rare inherited blood disorder characterized by the presence of an abnormal form of hemoglobin
column10: known as hemoglobin M (HbM). This abnormal hemoglobin has a reduced ability to carry oxygen
column11: leading to a lack of oxygen delivery to the body's tissues. The genetic changes associated with methemoglobinemia
column12: beta-globin type
column13: involve mutations in the HBB gene
column14: which provides instructions for making the beta-globin protein
column15: a component of hemoglobin. These mutations can result in the production of an unstable or dysfunctional beta-globin protein
column16: leading to the formation of HbM and the development of methemoglobinemia.;0.055;155.0;82.0;0.429;0.102;0.302;0.781;0.192;0.065;0.323

column1: 602;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to ovarian cancer ?;"Cancers occur when a buildup of mutations in critical genesthose that control cell growth and division or repair damaged DNAallow cells to grow and divide uncontrollably to form a tumor. Most cases of ovarian cancer are sporadic; in these cases the associated genetic changes are acquired during a person's lifetime and are present only in certain cells in the ovary. These changes
column2: which are called somatic mutations
column3: are not inherited. Somatic mutations in the TP53 gene occur in almost half of all ovarian cancers. The protein produced from this gene is described as a tumor suppressor because it helps keep cells from growing and dividing too fast or in an uncontrolled way. Most of these mutations change single protein building blocks (amino acids) in the p53 protein
column4: which reduces or eliminates the protein's tumor suppressor function. Because the altered protein is less able to regulate cell growth and division
column5: a cancerous tumor may develop. Somatic mutations in many other genes have also been found in ovarian cancer cells.  In hereditary ovarian cancer
column6: the associated genetic changes are passed down within a family. These changes
column7: classified as germline mutations
column8: are present in all the body's cells. In people with germline mutations
column9: other inherited and somatic gene changes
column10: together with environmental and lifestyle factors
column11: also influence whether a woman will develop ovarian cancer.  Germline mutations are involved in more than one-fifth of ovarian cancer cases. Between 65 and 85 percent of these mutations are in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene. These gene mutations are described as ""high penetrance"" because they are associated with a high risk of developing ovarian cancer
column12: breast cancer
column13: and several other types of cancer in women. Compared to a 1.6 percent lifetime risk of developing ovarian cancer for women in the total population
column14: the lifetime risk in women with a BRCA1 gene mutation is 40 to 60 percent
column15: and the lifetime risk in women with a BRCA2 gene mutation is 20 to 35 percent. Men with mutations in these genes also have an increased risk of developing several forms of cancer. The proteins produced from the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are tumor suppressors that are involved in fixing damaged DNA
column16: which helps to maintain the stability of a cell's genetic information. Mutations in these genes impair DNA repair
column17: allowing potentially damaging mutations to persist in DNA. As these defects accumulate
column18: they can trigger cells to grow and divide without control or order to form a tumor.  A significantly increased risk of ovarian cancer is also a feature of certain rare genetic syndromes
column19: including a disorder called Lynch syndrome. Lynch syndrome is most often associated with mutations in the MLH1 or MSH2 gene and accounts for between 10 and 15 percent of hereditary ovarian cancers. Other rare genetic syndromes may also be associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer. The proteins produced from the genes associated with these syndromes act as tumor suppressors. Mutations in any of these genes can allow cells to grow and divide unchecked
column20: leading to the development of a cancerous tumor. Like BRCA1 and BRCA2
column21: these genes are considered ""high penetrance"" because mutations greatly increase a person's chance of developing cancer. In addition to ovarian cancer
column22: mutations in these genes increase the risk of several other types of cancer in both men and women.  Germline mutations in dozens of other genes have been studied as possible risk factors for ovarian cancer. These genes are described as ""low penetrance"" or ""moderate penetrance"" because changes in each of these genes appear to make only a small or moderate contribution to overall ovarian cancer risk. Some of these genes provide instructions for making proteins that interact with the proteins produced from the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes. Others act through different pathways. Researchers suspect that the combined influence of variations in these genes may significantly impact a person's risk of developing ovarian cancer.  In many families
column23: the genetic changes associated with hereditary ovarian cancer are unknown. Identifying additional genetic risk factors for ovarian cancer is an active area of medical research.  In addition to genetic changes
column24: researchers have identified many personal and environmental factors that contribute to a woman's risk of developing ovarian cancer. These factors include age
column25: ethnic background
column26: and hormonal and reproductive factors. A history of ovarian cancer in closely related family members is also an important risk factor
column27: particularly if the cancer occurred in early adulthood.";"Ovarian cancer is a complex and heterogeneous disease with various genetic alterations contributing to its development and progression. Some key genetic changes associated with ovarian cancer include:

column1: 1. **BRCA1 and BRCA2 Mutations:** Inherited mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are the most well-known genetic risk factors for ovarian cancer. These genes play a vital role in DNA repair
column2: and mutations in these genes impair the ability of cells to repair DNA damage
column3: leading to genomic instability and increased susceptibility to cancer.

column1: 2. **TP53 Mutations:** TP53 is a tumor suppressor gene responsible for regulating cell growth and preventing uncontrolled cell division. Mutations in TP53 are commonly found in ovarian cancer
column2: leading to loss of its tumor-suppressing function and promoting cancer cell growth and survival.

column1: 3. **Copy Number Alterations:** Changes in the number of copies of specific genes or chromosomal regions are common in ovarian cancer. These alterations can result in the amplification of oncogenes
column2: driving excessive cell growth and proliferation
column3: or the deletion of tumor suppressor genes
column4: compromising their ability to control cell growth and prevent tumor formation.

column1: 4. **Microsatellite Instability:** Microsatellite instability (MSI) refers to alterations in the length of repetitive DNA sequences called microsatellites. MSI is observed in a subset of ovarian cancers and is associated with defective DNA mismatch repair mechanisms. MSI can lead to mutations in various genes
column2: contributing to cancer development and progression.

column1: 5. **Epigenetic Alterations:** Epigenetic changes
column2: such as DNA methylation and histone modifications
column3: can also play a role in ovarian cancer. Aberrant DNA methylation patterns can lead to the silencing of tumor suppressor genes
column4: while abnormal histone modifications can alter gene expression and promote cancer cell growth and survival.

column1: 6. **Other Genetic Alterations:** Numerous other genetic changes have been identified in ovarian cancer
column2: including mutations in genes involved in cell cycle regulation
column3: DNA damage response
column4: angiogenesis
column5: and metastasis. These alterations contribute to the complex molecular landscape of ovarian cancer and provide potential targets for therapeutic intervention.";0.041;678.0;309.0;0.287;0.098;0.164;0.747;0.024;-0.016;0.062

column1: 603;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Angina ?;"The most important issues to address when you go to the doctor with chest pain are:
What's causing the chest pain
Whether you're having or are about to have a heart attack
Angina is a symptom of an underlying heart problem
column2: usually coronary heart disease (CHD). The type of angina pain you have can be a sign of how severe the CHD is and whether it's likely to cause a heart attack.

column1: If you have chest pain
column2: your doctor will want to find out whether it's angina. He or she also will want to know whether the angina is stable or unstable. If it's unstable
column3: you may need emergency medical treatment to try to prevent a heart attack.

column1: To diagnose chest pain as stable or unstable angina
column2: your doctor will do a physical exam
column3: ask about your symptoms
column4: and ask about your risk factors for and your family history of CHD or other heart diseases.

column1: Your doctor also may ask questions about your symptoms
column2: such as:

column1: What brings on the pain or discomfort and what relieves it?
What does the pain or discomfort feel like (for example
column2: heaviness or tightness)?

column1: How often does the pain occur?
Where do you feel the pain or discomfort?
How severe is the pain or discomfort?
How long does the pain or discomfort last?
Diagnostic Tests and Procedures
If your doctor thinks that you have unstable angina or that your angina is related to a serious heart condition
column2: he or she may recommend one or more tests.

column1: EKG (Electrocardiogram)
An EKG is a simple
column2: painless test that detects and records the hearts electrical activity. The test shows how fast the heart is beating and its rhythm (steady or irregular). An EKG also records the strength and timing of electrical signals as they pass through the heart.

column1: An EKG can show signs of heart damage due to CHD and signs of a previous or current heart attack. However
column2: some people who have angina have normal EKGs.

column1: Stress Testing
During stress testing
column2: you exercise to make your heart work hard and beat fast while heart tests are done. If you cant exercise
column3: you may be given medicine to make your heart work hard and beat fast.

column1: When your heart is working hard and beating fast
column2: it needs more blood and oxygen. Plaque-narrowed arteries can't supply enough oxygen-rich blood to meet your heart's needs.

column1: A stress test can show possible signs and symptoms of CHD
column2: such as:

column1: Abnormal changes in your heart rate or blood pressure
Shortness of breath or chest pain
Abnormal changes in your heart rhythm or your heart's electrical activity
As part of some stress tests
column2: pictures are taken of your heart while you exercise and while you rest. These imaging stress tests can show how well blood is flowing in various parts of your heart. They also can show how well your heart pumps blood when it beats.

column1: Chest X Ray
A chest x ray takes pictures of the organs and structures inside your chest
column2: such as your heart
column3: lungs
column4: and blood vessels.

column1: A chest x ray can reveal signs of heart failure. It also can show signs of lung disorders and other causes of symptoms not related to CHD. However
column2: a chest x ray alone is not enough to diagnose angina or CHD.

column1: Coronary Angiography and Cardiac Catheterization
Your doctor may recommend coronary angiography (an-jee-OG-ra-fee) if he or she suspects you have CHD. This test uses dye and special x rays to show the inside of your coronary arteries.
To get the dye into your coronary arteries
column2: your doctor will use a procedure called cardiac catheterization (KATH-e-ter-ih-ZA-shun).

column1: A thin
column2: flexible tube called a catheter is put into a blood vessel in your arm
column3: groin (upper thigh)
column4: or neck. The tube is threaded into your coronary arteries
column5: and the dye is released into your bloodstream.

column1: Special x rays are taken while the dye is flowing through your coronary arteries. The dye lets your doctor study the flow of blood through your heart and blood vessels.
Cardiac catheterization usually is done in a hospital. You're awake during the procedure. It usually causes little or no pain
column2: although you may feel some soreness in the blood vessel where your doctor inserts the catheter.

column1: Computed Tomography Angiography

Computed tomography (to-MOG-rah-fee) angiography (CTA) uses dye and special x rays to show blood flow through the coronary arteries. This test is less invasive than coronary angiography with cardiac catheterization.
For CTA
column2: a needle connected to an intravenous (IV) line is put into a vein in your hand or arm. Dye is injected through the IV line during the scan. You may have a warm feeling when this happens. The dye highlights your blood vessels on the CT scan pictures.

column1: Sticky patches called electrodes are put on your chest. The patches are attached to an EKG machine to record your heart's electrical activity during the scan.
The CT scanner is a large machine that has a hollow
column2: circular tube in the middle. You lie on your back on a sliding table. The table slowly slides into the opening of the machine.

column1: Inside the scanner
column2: an x-ray tube moves around your body to take pictures of different parts of your heart. A computer puts the pictures together to make a three-dimensional (3D) picture of the whole heart.

column1: Blood Tests
Blood tests check the levels of certain fats
column2: cholesterol
column3: sugar
column4: and proteins in your blood. Abnormal levels may show that you have risk factors for CHD.

column1: Your doctor may recommend a blood test to check the level of a protein called C-reactive protein (CRP) in your blood. Some studies suggest that high levels of CRP in the blood may increase the risk for CHD and heart attack.

Your doctor also may recommend a blood test to check for low levels of hemoglobin (HEE-muh-glow-bin) in your blood. Hemoglobin is an iron-rich protein in red blood cells. It helps the blood cells carry oxygen from the lungs to all parts of your body. If your hemoglobin level is low
column2: you may have a condition called anemia (uh-NEE-me-uh).";Diagnosing angina typically involves a comprehensive evaluation that includes a detailed medical history
column3: physical examination
column4: and various diagnostic tests. The healthcare provider will inquire about the patient's symptoms
column5: such as chest pain or discomfort
column6: its characteristics
column7: frequency
column8: and duration. They will also assess the patient's risk factors for coronary artery disease
column9: including age
column10: gender
column11: family history
column12: smoking
column13: hypertension
column14: high cholesterol
column15: diabetes
column16: and obesity. Physical examination may involve listening to the heart and lungs for abnormal sounds and checking blood pressure. Diagnostic tests may include an electrocardiogram (ECG) to detect abnormal heart rhythms or signs of ischemia
column17: a stress test to evaluate the heart's response to physical exertion
column18: an echocardiogram to assess the heart's structure and function
column19: and coronary angiography to visualize the coronary arteries and identify any blockages or narrowing.;0.0;926.0;118.0;0.217;0.04;0.123;0.688;-0.082;-0.195;0.033

column11: also known as Focal Glomerulosclerosis
column12: is a rare genetic disorder that affects the kidneys. Common symptoms include excessive thirst
column13: frequent urination
column14: unexplained swelling in the hands
column15: feet
column16: and face

column1: 605;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Childhood Brain Tumors ?;Brain tumors are abnormal growths inside the skull. They are among the most common types of childhood cancers. Some are benign tumors
column2: which aren't cancer. They can still be serious. Malignant tumors are cancerous.    Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors can cause headaches and other symptoms. However
column3: other conditions can also cause the same symptoms. Check with a doctor if your child has any of the following problems:       - Morning headache or headache that goes away after vomiting    - Frequent nausea and vomiting    - Vision
column4: hearing
column5: and speech problems    - Loss of balance or trouble walking    - Unusual sleepiness    - Personality changes    - Seizures    - Increased head size in infants       The symptoms are not the same in every child.    Doctors use physical and neurological exams
column6: lab tests
column7: and imaging to diagnose brain tumors. Most childhood brain tumors are diagnosed and removed in surgery.    Treatment for children is sometimes different than for an adult. Long-term side effects are an important issue. The options also depend on the type of tumor and where it is. Removal of the tumor is often possible. If not
column8: radiation
column9: chemotherapy
column10: or both may be used.    NIH: National Cancer Institute;Childhood brain tumors are abnormal growths of cells that start in the brain. They are the most common solid tumors in children
column11: and they can occur at any age. The most common types of childhood brain tumors are medulloblastoma
column12: astrocytoma
column13: and ependymoma. Symptoms of childhood brain tumors can include headache
column14: nausea
column15: vomiting
column16: seizures
column17: vision problems
column18: and balance problems. Treatment for childhood brain tumors typically involves surgery

Treatment for hemangioendothelioma may depend on the type of hemangioendothelioma present in the affected individual and the risk of recurrence or metastases. In most reported cases

column8: epithelioid hemangioendothelioma
column9: and composite hemangioendothelioma (with the exception of 1 case treated with interferon). Most individuals with pseudomyogenic hemangioendothelioma have been treated with simple excision
column10: but a few individuals have also received post-surgical radiotherapy (RT). With regard to kaposiform hemangioendothelioma
column11: some large lesions cannot be completely removed and may cause fatal complications due to the associated KasabachMerritt syndrome. In these cases

The authors stated that the effectiveness of definitive RT in the treatment of hemangioendothelioma in their study implies that radiation may be an acceptable alternative when surgical resection will compromise function or cosmetic result. column1: 611;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) short QT syndrome ?;"Short QT syndrome is a condition that can cause a disruption of the heart's normal rhythm (arrhythmia). In people with this condition

column4: the part of the heartbeat known as the QT interval is abnormally short.  If untreated

column6: from dizziness and fainting (syncope) to cardiac arrest and sudden death. These signs and symptoms can occur any time from early infancy to old age. This condition may explain some cases of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS)
column7: which is a major cause of unexplained death in babies younger than 1 year. However
column8: some people with short QT syndrome never experience any health problems associated with the condition.";Short QT syndrome is a rare heart condition characterized by an unusually short QT interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG). column9: and a shorter interval means that the heart rate is faster. Short QT syndrome can be caused by genetic mutations or certain medications
column10: and it can increase the risk of sudden cardiac arrest
column11: a potentially fatal heart rhythm disturbance. Symptoms may include palpitations
column12: chest pain
column13: shortness of breath
column14: and fainting. Treatment typically involves lifestyle changes
column15: medications
column16: and in some cases

614;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Traumatic Brain Injury ?;Traumatic brain injury (TBI) happens when a bump, blow, jolt, or other head injury causes damage to the brain. Every year, millions of people in the U.S. suffer brain injuries. More than half are bad enough that people must go to the hospital. The worst injuries can lead to permanent brain damage or death. Half of all TBIs are from motor vehicle accidents. Military personnel in combat zones are also at risk.    Symptoms of a TBI may not appear until days or weeks following the injury. A concussion is the mildest type. It can cause a headache or neck pain, nausea, ringing in the ears, dizziness, and tiredness. People with a moderate or severe TBI may have those, plus other symptoms:       - A headache that gets worse or does not go away    - Repeated vomiting or nausea    - Convulsions or seizures    - Inability to awaken from sleep    - Slurred speech    - Weakness or numbness in the arms and legs    - Dilated eye pupils       Health care professionals use a neurological exam and imaging tests to assess TBI. Serious traumatic brain injuries need emergency treatment. Treatment and outcome depend on how severe the injury is. TBI can cause a wide range of changes affecting thinking, sensation, language, or emotions. TBI can be associated with post-traumatic stress disorder. People with severe injuries usually need rehabilitation.     NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke;Traumatic brain injury (TBI), often referred to as a head injury or concussion, is a disruption in the normal function of the brain that can be caused by a bump, blow, or jolting to the head. It can range from mild, with brief changes in mental status or consciousness, to severe with an extended period of unconsciousness or coma. TBIs may result in a wide range of temporary or permanent problems with cognitive, physical, and emotional functioning.;0.012;206.0;69.0;0.284;0.075;0.168;0.818;0.048;-0.091;0.191
