The symptoms of Klatskin tumors can vary depending on the size and location of the tumor, but common symptoms include abdominal pain, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), itching, weight loss, fatigue, and loss of appetite. Additionally, patients may experience dark urine, light-colored stools, and swelling in the abdomen or legs. In some cases, Klatskin tumors can also cause fever, nausea, and vomiting. If you are experiencing any of these symptoms, it is important to see a doctor for evaluation. Early diagnosis and treatment of Klatskin tumors is essential for improving the chances of a successful outcome.;0.012;249.0;107.0;0.365;0.062;0.164;0.814;-0.05;-0.185;0.088
616;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Noonan syndrome 6 ?;How might Noonan syndrome be treated? Management generally focuses on the specific signs and symptoms present in each person. Treatments for the complications of Noonan syndrome (such as cardiovascular abnormalities) are generally standard and do not differ from treatment in the general population. Developmental disabilities are addressed by early intervention programs and individualized education strategies. Treatment for serious bleeding depends upon the specific factor deficiency or platelet abnormality. Growth hormone treatment increases growth velocity. More detailed information about treatment for Noonan syndrome can be viewed on the GeneReviews Web site.;There is no specific cure for Noonan syndrome 6, but treatment can help manage the signs and symptoms. Treatment may include medications to address heart defects, growth hormone therapy to promote growth, speech therapy to improve speech and language skills, and occupational therapy to improve motor skills. Surgery may be necessary to correct heart defects or other physical abnormalities. Genetic counseling can help families understand the condition and its inheritance pattern. Regular monitoring by a healthcare team is important to track the progression of the condition and to adjust treatment as needed.;0.038;85.0;87.0;0.264;0.062;0.14;0.751;0.058;0.037;0.075
617;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Polycythemia Vera ?;Polycythemia vera (PV) doesn't have a cure. However
column2: treatments can help control the disease and its complications. PV is treated with procedures
column3: medicines
column4: and other methods. You may need one or more treatments to manage the disease.

column1: Goals of Treatment
The goals of treating PV are to control symptoms and reduce the risk of complications
column2: especially heart attack and stroke. To do this
column3: PV treatments reduce the number of red blood cells and the level of hemoglobin (an iron-rich protein) in the blood. This brings the thickness of your blood closer to normal.

column1: Blood with normal thickness flows better through the blood vessels. This reduces the chance that blood clots will form and cause a heart attack or stroke.
Blood with normal thickness also ensures that your body gets enough oxygen. This can help reduce some of the signs and symptoms of PV
column2: such as headaches
column3: vision problems
column4: and itching.

column1: Studies show that treating PV greatly improves your chances of living longer.
The goal of treating secondary polycythemia is to control its underlying cause
column2: if possible. For example
column3: if the cause is carbon monoxide exposure
column4: the goal is to find the source of the carbon monoxide and fix or remove it.

column1: Treatments To Lower Red Blood Cell Levels
Phlebotomy
Phlebotomy (fle-BOT-o-me) is a procedure that removes some blood from your body. For this procedure
column2: a needle is inserted into one of your veins. Blood from the vein flows through an airtight tube into a sterile container or bag. The process is similar to the process of donating blood.

column1: Phlebotomy reduces your red blood cell count and starts to bring your blood thickness closer to normal.
Typically
column2: a pint (1 unit) of blood is removed each week until your hematocrit level approaches normal. (Hematocrit is the measure of how much space red blood cells take up in your blood.)

column1: You may need to have phlebotomy done every few months.
Medicines
Your doctor may prescribe medicines to keep your bone marrow from making too many red blood cells. Examples of these medicines include hydroxyurea and interferon-alpha.
Hydroxyurea is a medicine generally used to treat cancer. This medicine can reduce the number of red blood cells and platelets in your blood. As a result
column2: this medicine helps improve your blood flow and bring the thickness of your blood closer to normal.

column1: Interferon-alpha is a substance that your body normally makes. It also can be used to treat PV. Interferon-alpha can prompt your immune system to fight overactive bone marrow cells. This helps lower your red blood cell count and keep your blood flow and blood thickness closer to normal.
Radiation Treatment
Radiation treatment can help suppress overactive bone marrow cells. This helps lower your red blood cell count and keep your blood flow and blood thickness closer to normal.
However
column2: radiation treatment can raise your risk of leukemia (blood cancer) and other blood diseases.

column1: Treatments for Symptoms
Aspirin can relieve bone pain and burning feelings in your hands or feet that you may have as a result of PV. Aspirin also thins your blood
column2: so it reduces the risk of blood clots.

column1: Aspirin can have side effects
column2: including bleeding in the stomach and intestines. For this reason
column3: take aspirin only as your doctor recommends.

column1: If your PV causes itching
column2: your doctor may prescribe medicines to ease the discomfort. Your doctor also may prescribe ultraviolet light treatment to help relieve your itching.

column1: Other ways to reduce itching include:
Avoiding hot baths. Cooler water can limit irritation to your skin.
Gently patting yourself dry after bathing. Vigorous rubbing with a towel can irritate your skin.
Taking starch baths. Add half a box of starch to a tub of lukewarm water. This can help soothe your skin.
Experimental Treatments

Researchers are studying other treatments for PV. An experimental treatment for itching involves taking low doses of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). This type of medicine is used to treat depression. In clinical trials
column2: SSRIs reduced itching in people who had PV.

column1: Imatinib mesylate is a medicine that's approved for treating leukemia. In clinical trials
column2: this medicine helped reduce the need for phlebotomy in people who had PV. This medicine also helped reduce the size of enlarged spleens.

column1: Researchers also are trying to find a treatment that can block or limit the effects of an abnormal JAK2 gene. (A mutation
column2: or change
column3: in the JAK2 gene is the major cause of PV.)";Polycythemia Vera (PV) is a blood cancer characterized by an excess of red blood cells
column4: white blood cells
column5: and platelets in the blood. The primary treatment for PV aims to reduce the number of blood cells and prevent complications such as blood clots

column7: and strokes. The most common treatment option is phlebotomy

column1: 628;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Sarcoidosis ?;"Espaol
Sarcoidosis (sar-koy-DO-sis) is a disease of unknown cause that leads to inflammation. This disease affects your bodys organs.
Normally
column2: your immune system defends your body against foreign or harmful substances. For example
column3: it sends special cells to protect organs that are in danger.

column1: These cells release chemicals that recruit other cells to isolate and destroy the harmful substance. Inflammation occurs during this process. Once the harmful substance is gone
column2: the cells and the inflammation go away.

column1: In people who have sarcoidosis
column2: the inflammation doesn't go away. Instead
column3: some of the immune system cells cluster to form lumps called granulomas (gran-yu-LO-mas) in various organs in your body.

column1: Overview
Sarcoidosis can affect any organ in your body. However
column2: it's more likely to affect some organs than others. The disease usually starts in the lungs
column3: skin
column4: and/or lymph nodes (especially the lymph nodes in your chest).

column1: Also
column2: the disease often affects the eyes and liver. Although less common
column3: sarcoidosis can affect the heart and brain
column4: leading to serious complications.

column1: If many granulomas form in an organ
column2: they can affect how the organ works. This can cause signs and symptoms. Signs and symptoms vary depending on which organs are affected. Many people who have sarcoidosis have no signs or symptoms or mild ones.

column1: Lofgren's syndrome is a classic set of signs and symptoms that is typical in some people who have sarcoidosis. Lofgren's syndrome may cause fever
column2: enlarged lymph nodes
column3: arthritis (usually in the ankles)
column4: and/or erythema nodosum (er-ih-THE-ma no-DO-sum).

column1: Erythema nodosum is a rash of red or reddish-purple bumps on your ankles and shins. The rash may be warm and tender to the touch.

Treatment for sarcoidosis varies depending on which organs are affected. Your doctor may prescribe topical treatments and/or medicines to treat the disease. Not everyone who has sarcoidosis needs treatment.
Outlook
The outlook for sarcoidosis varies. Many people recover from the disease with few or no long-term problems.
More than half of the people who have sarcoidosis have remission within 3 years of diagnosis. Remission means the disease isn't active
column2: but it can return.

column1: Two-thirds of people who have the disease have remission within 10 years of diagnosis. People who have Lofgren's syndrome usually have remission. Relapse (return of the disease) 1 or more years after remission occurs in less than 5 percent of patients.
Sarcoidosis leads to organ damage in about one-third of the people diagnosed with the disease. Damage may occur over many years and involve more than one organ. Rarely
column2: sarcoidosis can be fatal. Death usually is the result of problems with the lungs
column3: heart
column4: or brain.

column1: Poor outcomes are more likely in people who have advanced disease and show little improvement from treatment.
Certain people are at higher risk for poor outcomes from chronic (long-term) sarcoidosis. This includes people who have lung scarring
column2: heart or brain complications
column3: or lupus pernio (LU-pus PUR-ne-o). Lupus pernio is a serious skin condition that sarcoidosis may cause.

column1: Research is ongoing for new and better treatments for sarcoidosis.";Sarcoidosis is a multi-system inflammatory disorder characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas
column2: which are small collections of inflammatory cells
column3: in various organs and tissues of the body. It commonly affects the lungs
column4: but can also involve the skin
column5: lymph nodes
column6: liver
column7: spleen
column8: eyes
column9: and heart. The cause of sarcoidosis is unknown
column10: but it is thought to be related to an overactive immune response to an unknown trigger
column11: possibly an infection or environmental factor. Symptoms of sarcoidosis vary depending on the organs affected
column12: but may include fatigue
column13: shortness of breath
column14: cough
column15: skin rashes
column16: joint pain
column17: and swollen lymph nodes. Treatment for sarcoidosis is typically aimed at reducing inflammation and suppressing the overactive immune response

column1: 633;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) inclusion body myopathy with early-onset Paget disease and frontotemporal dementia ?;Inclusion body myopathy with early-onset Paget disease and frontotemporal dementia (IBMPFD) is a condition that can affect the muscles

column1: 634;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Angioplasty;Summary : If you have coronary artery disease
column2: the arteries in your heart are narrowed or blocked by a sticky material called plaque. Angioplasty is a procedure to restore blood flow through the artery.    You have angioplasty in a hospital. The doctor threads a thin tube through a blood vessel in the arm or groin up to the involved site in the artery. The tube has a tiny balloon on the end. When the tube is in place
column3: the doctor inflates the balloon to push the plaque outward against the wall of the artery. This widens the artery and restores blood flow.    Doctors may use angioplasty to       - Reduce chest pain caused by reduced blood flow to the heart    - Minimize damage to heart muscle from a heart attack       Many people go home the day after angioplasty
column4: and are able to return to work within a week of coming home.    NIH: National Heart
column5: Lung
column6: and Blood Institute;Angioplasty is a minimally invasive procedure used to widen narrowed or blocked blood vessels. It involves inserting a thin
column7: flexible tube (catheter) with a tiny balloon at its tip into the narrowed artery. The balloon is then inflated
column8: compressing the plaque against the artery walls and increasing blood flow. Angioplasty is often performed in conjunction with stenting
column9: where a small mesh tube (stent) is inserted to keep the artery open. It is commonly used to treat coronary artery disease
column10: peripheral artery disease
column11: and renal artery stenosis. Angioplasty can improve blood flow
column12: relieve symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath
column13: and reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke. However
column14: it is essential to note that angioplasty is not a cure for the underlying condition causing the narrowing
column15: and lifestyle changes and medications may be necessary to manage the condition long-term.;0.037;129.0;128.0;0.307;0.073;0.182;0.787;0.173;0.169;0.174

column1: 637;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Factor V Leiden thrombophilia ?;Factor V Leiden thrombophilia is an inherited disorder that results in an increased risk of developing abnormal blood clots. Factor V Leiden is the name of a specific gene mutation in the F5 gene. This gene plays a critical role in the normal formation of blood clots in response to an injury. People can inherit one or two copies of the factor V Leiden gene mutation. Those who inherit one copy are called heterozygotes. People who inherit two copies of the mutation
column2: one from each parent
column3: are called homozygotes. Having the factor V Leiden mutation increases your risk for developing a clot in your legs called a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). It also increases your risk of developing a clot that travels through the bloodstream and lodges in the lungs
column4: called a pulmonary embolism (PE).;Factor V Leiden thrombophilia is a genetic disorder that increases the risk of developing blood clots. It is caused by a mutation in the factor V gene
column5: which leads to the production of an abnormal form of factor V protein. Factor V is a protein that plays a role in the blood clotting process. The abnormal form of factor V protein is more resistant to being broken down
column6: which can lead to the formation of blood clots. People with Factor V Leiden thrombophilia have an increased risk of developing blood clots in the veins
column7: especially in the legs and lungs. They also have an increased risk of developing blood clots during pregnancy
column8: after surgery

column1: 638;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Age-related Macular Degeneration ?;Dry AMD has three stages -- early AMD
column2: intermediate AMD
column3: and advanced dry AMD. All of these may occur in one or both eyes. People with early dry AMD have either several small drusen or a few medium-sized drusen. Drusen are yellow deposits under the retina which often are found in people over age 50. People with early AMD have no symptoms and no vision loss. People with intermediate dry AMD have either many medium-sized drusen or one or more large drusen. Some people see a blurred spot in the center of their vision. More light may be needed for reading and other tasks. In addition to drusen
column4: people with advanced dry AMD have a breakdown of light-sensitive cells and supporting tissue in the macula. This breakdown can cause a blurred spot in the center of your vision. Over time
column5: the blurred spot may get bigger and darker
column6: taking more of your central vision. You may have difficulty reading or recognizing faces until they are very close to you.;Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a common eye condition that affects the macula
column7: the central part of the retina responsible for sharp central vision. AMD is the leading cause of vision loss in people over 50 and is characterized by the deterioration of the macula

column15: obesity
column16: and high blood pressure. There are two main types of AMD: dry AMD
column17: which is a slow
column20: which is a more severe form characterized by abnormal blood vessel growth in the macula

column1: 639;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Chronic fatigue syndrome ?;How might chronic fatigue syndrome be treated? Treatment options for chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) are limited.[9440] Treatment is largely supportive and is focused on the specific symptoms present in each individual. In most cases
column2: symptoms of CFS lessen over time. Many therapies have been tried
column3: but only cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and graded exercise therapy reportedly appear to produce meaningful benefit. CBT typically involves a series of one-hour sessions designed to alter beliefs and behaviors that might delay recovery. Graded exercise therapy can be beneficial because prolonged lack of exercise may worsen the symptoms of the condition and should be discouraged.[9440] Gradual introduction of regular aerobic exercise
column4: such as walking
column5: swimming
column6: cycling
column7: or jogging
column8: under close medical supervision may reduce fatigue and improve physical function. The goal is to have 30 minutes of light exercise five times a week. To avoid overexertion it is recommended to set a target heart rate range
column9: generally <100 beats per minute. Graded exercise should be always supervised by a physical therapist or exercise therapist. In some studies
column10: women with this condition were found to have low normal fitness on treadmill testing with no indication of heart or lung problems. Maximal testing did not result in worse fatigue or other symptoms. Because many people who have CFS are also depressed
column11: treating the depression can make it easier to cope with the problems associated with CFS. Low doses of some antidepressants may help improve sleep and relieve pain.[6269] A number of medications
column12: special diets and vitamin supplements have been evaluated in individuals with CFS
column13: but none have been proven effective. Although there have been a number of viruses that were initially reported to cause CFS
column14: additional studies have not proven this.[9440] Trials of antiviral agents have been ineffective in relieving the symptoms of CFS. Common approaches include:

column1: - Lifestyle changes: Pacing techniques to manage activities
column2: sleep hygiene
column3: stress reduction
column4: and a balanced diet can positively impact energy levels and reduce symptom severity.

column1: - Medications: Doctors may prescribe medications to address specific symptoms
column2: such as pain relievers
column3: antidepressants
column4: or stimulants
column5: but there is no cure for CFS.

column1: - Physical therapy: Supervised exercise programs can help individuals gradually increase activity levels and reduce fatigue.
- Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): This therapy helps patients develop coping mechanisms
column2: manage stress
column3: and modify negative thoughts that exacerbate fatigue.

column1: - Graded exercise therapy (GET): A specialized physical therapy program that gradually increases exercise intensity to improve stamina and reduce fatigue.";0.012;296.0;115.0;0.245;0.052;0.126;0.877;0.03;-0.09;0.154

column1: 644;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Melanoma ?;"New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.
Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website
Treatment for melanoma may cause side effects.
For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer
column2: see our Side Effects page.

column1: Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.
For some patients
column2: taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice. Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process. Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.   Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials. Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.   Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future. Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments
column3: they often answer important questions and help move research forward.

column1: Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.

column1: Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment. Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better. There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.   Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country. See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials. These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.
Follow-up tests may be needed.

Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated. Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working. Decisions about whether to continue
column2: change
column3: or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.   Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended. The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back). These tests are sometimes called follow-up tests or check-ups.";Extensive research efforts are underway to combat melanoma
column4: including clinical trials exploring various treatment strategies. Some promising areas of investigation include: 1) Immunotherapy: Scientists are developing innovative immunotherapies that harness the body's immune system to recognize and attack melanoma cells. This includes cancer vaccines
column5: immune checkpoint inhibitors
column6: and adoptive cell therapy
column7: which involves modifying a patient's own immune cells to enhance their anti-tumor activity. 2) Targeted Therapy: Researchers are identifying specific molecular targets within melanoma cells and developing drugs that selectively inhibit these targets
column8: leading to tumor cell death or growth inhibition. 3) Combination Therapies: Combining different treatment modalities
column9: such as immunotherapy and targeted therapy
column10: is being explored to improve treatment outcomes and overcome resistance. 4) Novel Drug Development: Researchers are continually seeking new and more effective drugs for treating melanoma
column11: including small molecule inhibitors
column12: antibody-drug conjugates
column13: and oncolytic viruses. 5) Early Detection and Prevention: Investigations are ongoing to develop methods for early detection of melanoma
column14: including improved imaging techniques and biomarkers
column15: as well as strategies for prevention

column1: 647;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Anal Cancer ?;"Key Points

column1: 651;gemini-pro;considerations;What to do for What I need to know about Living with Kidney Failure ?;- Kidney failure means your kidneys no longer work well enough to do their job.  - Learning about treatments for kidney failure will help you choose the one that best fits your lifestyle.  - Many people with kidney failure continue to work.  - Physical activity is an important part of staying healthy when you have kidney failure.  - You can help prevent relatives from having kidney failure by talking with them about their risk.  - Eating the right foods can help you feel better when you are on dialysis or have a kidney transplant.;Living with kidney failure requires ongoing medical management
column2: lifestyle adjustments
column3: and emotional support. Understanding your condition
column4: adhering to treatment plans
column5: managing diet and fluid intake
column6: taking prescribed medications
column7: attending regular check-ups
column8: and exploring dialysis options (if necessary) are essential. Creating a support system with family
column9: friends
column10: and healthcare professionals can provide invaluable emotional and practical assistance. Maintaining a positive outlook and seeking counseling or support groups can help you cope with the challenges and improve your overall well-being. Additionally

column1: 653;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Moyamoya Disease ?;"Moyamoya disease is a rare
column2: progressive cerebrovascular disorder caused by blocked arteries at the base of the brain in an area called the basal ganglia. The name moyamoya means puff of smoke in Japanese and describes the look of the tangle of tiny vessels formed to compensate for the blockage. Moyamoya disease was first described in Japan in the 1960s and it has since been found in individuals in the other countries around the world; its incidence is higher in Asian countries than in Europe or North America. The disease primarily affects children
column3: but it can also occur in adults. In children
column4: the first symptom of Moyamoya disease is often stroke
column5: or recurrent transient ischemic attacks (TIA
column6: commonly referred to as mini-strokes)
column7: frequently accompanied by muscular weakness or paralysis affecting one side of the body
column8: or seizures. Adults may also experience these symptoms that arise from blocked arteries
column9: but more often experience a hemorrhagic stroke due to bleeding into the brain from the abnormal brain vessels. Individuals with this disorder may have disturbed consciousness
column10: problems with speaking and understanding speech
column11: sensory and cognitive impairments
column12: involuntary movements
column13: and vision problems.About one in 10 individuals with Moyamoya disease has a close relative who is also affected; in these cases researchers think that Moyamoya disease is the result of inherited genetic abnormalities.Studies that look for the abnormal gene(s) may help reveal the biomechanisms that cause the disorder.";Moyamoya disease is a rare
column14: progressive cerebrovascular disorder characterized by progressive narrowing of the major arteries at the base of the brain
column15: resulting in insufficient blood flow to the brain. This narrowing is typically accompanied by the formation of abnormal new blood vessels
column16: known as moyamoya vessels
column17: which develop in an attempt to bypass the narrowed sections of the arteries and restore blood flow to the brain. The disease most commonly affects children and young adults
column18: with a higher prevalence in East Asian populations. Symptoms of Moyamoya disease can include transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)
column20: seizures
column21: headaches
column22: and developmental delays in children. Treatment typically involves surgical procedures to increase blood flow to the brain

column1: 654;gemini-pro;symptoms;What are the symptoms of Gordon syndrome ?;"What are the signs and symptoms of Gordon syndrome? Gordon syndrome belongs to a group of conditions known as the distal arthrogryposes
column2: which are characterized by stiffness and impaired mobility of certain joints of the lower arms and legs including the wrists
column3: elbows
column4: knees and/or ankles. The range and severity of features in affected individuals can vary. Most infants with Gordon syndrome have several fingers that are permanently fixed in a flexed position (camptodactyly)
column5: which may result in limited range of motion and compromised manual dexterity. Affected infants may also have clubfoot. Approximately 20-30% have cleft palate (incomplete closure of the roof of the mouth). Other signs and symptoms in some individuals may include a bifid uvula (abnormal splitting of the soft hanging tissue at the back of the throat); short stature; dislocation of the hip; abnormal backward curvature of the upper spine (lordosis); and/or kyphoscoliosis. In addition
column6: some affected individuals may have drooping of the eyelids (ptosis); epicanthal folds; syndactyly (webbing of the fingers and/or toes); abnormal skin patterns on the hands and feet (dermatoglyphics); and/or a short
column7: webbed neck (pterygium colli). Some affected males have undescended testes (cryptorchidism). Cognitive development is typically normal. The Human Phenotype Ontology provides the following list of signs and symptoms for Gordon syndrome. If the information is available

column1: 659;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Complex Regional Pain Syndrome ?;The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) and other institutes of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) conduct research relating to CRPS and also support additional research through grants to major medical institutions across the country. NINDS-supported scientists are studying new approaches to treat CRPS and intervene more aggressively after traumatic injury to lower the chances of developing the disorder. Researchers hope to identify specific cellular and molecular changes in sensory neurons following peripheral nerve injury to better understand the processes that underlie neuroplasticity (the brains ability to reorganize or form new nerve connections and pathways following injury or death of nerve cells). Identifying these mechanisms could provide targets for new drug therapies that could improve recovery following regeneration. Other researchers hope to better understand how CRPS develops by studying immune system activation and peripheral nerve signaling using an animal model of the disorder.;"Research into Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) is ongoing
column2: with clinical trials investigating various treatment approaches. Some notable research areas include:

column1: - **Pharmacological Interventions:** Studies are examining the efficacy of different medications
column2: such as ketamine
column3: botulinum toxin
column4: and sodium oxybate
column5: in reducing pain and improving function in CRPS patients.

column1: - **Neuromodulation Techniques:** Clinical trials are exploring the use of techniques like spinal cord stimulation
column2: deep brain stimulation
column3: and transcranial magnetic stimulation to modulate pain signals and alleviate symptoms in CRPS.

column1: - **Physical and Occupational Therapy Approaches:** Research is evaluating the effectiveness of specific physical and occupational therapy interventions in improving range of motion
column2: reducing pain
column3: and enhancing functional capacity in individuals with CRPS.

column1: - **Psychological and Behavioral Interventions:** Clinical trials are investigating the impact of psychological therapies
column2: such as cognitive-behavioral therapy and mindfulness-based interventions
column3: in managing pain
column4: improving coping skills
column5: and reducing the psychological burden associated with CRPS.

column1: - **Complementary and Alternative Medicine:** Studies are exploring the role of acupuncture
column2: herbal remedies
column3: and other complementary and alternative medicine approaches in alleviating symptoms and improving quality of life in CRPS patients.";0.008;137.0;169.0;0.118;0.007;0.086;0.418;-0.098;-0.096;-0.102

column1: 660;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Acromegaly ?;"No single treatment is effective for all patients. Treatment should be individualized

column1: If the tumor has not yet invaded surrounding nonpituitary tissues

column9: lanreotide) or dopamine agonists (e.g.

column1: 661;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Bronchitis ?;"Espaol
Bronchitis (bron-KI-tis) is a condition in which the bronchial tubes become inflamed. These tubes carry air to your lungs. (For more information about the bronchial tubes and airways
column2: go to the Diseases and Conditions Index How the Lungs Work article.)

column1: People who have bronchitis often have a cough that brings up mucus. Mucus is a slimy substance made by the lining of the bronchial tubes. Bronchitis also may cause wheezing (a whistling or squeaky sound when you breathe)
column2: chest pain or discomfort
column3: a low fever
column4: and shortness of breath.

column1: Bronchitis
Overview
The two main types of bronchitis are acute (short term) and chronic (ongoing).
Acute Bronchitis

Infections or lung irritants cause acute bronchitis. The same viruses that cause colds and the flu are the most common cause of acute bronchitis. These viruses are spread through the air when people cough. They also are spread through physical contact (for example
column2: on hands that have not been washed).

column1: Sometimes bacteria cause acute bronchitis.
Acute bronchitis lasts from a few days to 10 days. However
column2: coughing may last for several weeks after the infection is gone.

column1: Several factors increase your risk for acute bronchitis. Examples include exposure to tobacco smoke (including secondhand smoke)
column2: dust
column3: fumes
column4: vapors
column5: and air pollution. Avoiding these lung irritants as much as possible can help lower your risk for acute bronchitis.

column1: Most cases of acute bronchitis go away within a few days. If you think you have acute bronchitis
column2: see your doctor. He or she will want to rule out other
column3: more serious health conditions that require medical care.

column1: Chronic Bronchitis
Chronic bronchitis is an ongoing
column2: serious condition. It occurs if the lining of the bronchial tubes is constantly irritated and inflamed
column3: causing a long-term cough with mucus. Smoking is the main cause of chronic bronchitis.

column1: Viruses or bacteria can easily infect the irritated bronchial tubes. If this happens
column2: the condition worsens and lasts longer. As a result
column3: people who have chronic bronchitis have periods when symptoms get much worse than usual.

column1: Chronic bronchitis is a serious
column2: long-term medical condition. Early diagnosis and treatment
column3: combined with quitting smoking and avoiding secondhand smoke
column4: can improve quality of life. The chance of complete recovery is low for people who have severe chronic bronchitis.";Bronchitis is a condition in which the bronchi
column5: the airways that carry air to and from the lungs
column6: become inflamed and produce excess mucus. This can make breathing difficult and cause a cough
column7: which may produce mucus or phlegm. Bronchitis can be either acute
column8: lasting for a short period of time
column9: typically less than 3 weeks
column10: or chronic
column11: lasting for more than 3 months. Acute bronchitis is usually caused by a viral infection
column12: while chronic bronchitis is often associated with long-term exposure to irritants such as tobacco smoke or air pollution. Treatment for bronchitis depends on the cause and severity of the condition and may include medications to relieve symptoms
column13: antibiotics if a bacterial infection is present
column14: and lifestyle changes to reduce exposure to irritants.;0.01;344.0;115.0;0.355;0.067;0.178;0.77;0.081;-0.037;0.202

column1: 662;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Mucopolysaccharidosis type IIIB ?;Mucopolysaccharidosis type IIIB (MPS IIIB) is an genetic disorder that makes the body unable to break down large sugar molecules called glycosaminoglycans (GAGs
column2: formerly called mucopolysaccharides). Specifically
column3: people with this condition are unable to break down a GAG called heparan sulfate. Affected individuals can have severe neurological symptoms

column6: hyperactivity
column7: seizures
column8: deafness
column9: loss of vision
column10: and an inability to sleep for more than a few hours at a time. MPS IIIB is caused by alterations (mutations) in the NAGLU gene. This gene provides the instructions for producing an enzyme called N-alpha-acetylglucosaminidase
column11: which is needed to completely break down heparan sulfate. MPS IIIB is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. There is no specific treatment for this condition. Most people with MPS IIIB live into their teenage years
column12: and some live longer.;Mucopolysaccharidosis type IIIB (MPS IIIB)
column13: also known as Sanfilippo syndrome type B
column14: is a rare
column15: inherited metabolic disorder that primarily affects the central nervous system. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme N-acetylglucosaminidase (NAGLU)
column16: which leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) in lysosomes
column17: causing progressive damage to cells and tissues. MPS IIIB manifests with a range of symptoms

column22: skeletal abnormalities
column23: and hearing loss. Treatment for MPS IIIB is supportive and aims to manage symptoms and improve the quality of life. Enzyme replacement therapy and gene therapy are potential treatment options that are being explored.;0.066;125.0;100.0;0.335;0.105;0.18;0.782;0.208;0.169;0.246

column1: 663;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is Felty's syndrome inherited ?;"Is Felty's syndrome inherited? It has not been concluded that Felty's syndrome is an inherited condition; most individuals with Felty's syndrome have not had a history of the condition in their family. However
column2: there have been a few reports of the condition appearing to be familial. Furthermore
column3: although the condition itself may not be inherited
column4: some of the risk factors associated with Felty's syndrome may have genetic components. One study found that a family history of rheumatoid arthritis was more common in patients with Felty's syndrome and that there was a strong association with HLA-DR4 (an immune system gene common in individuals with RA). The authors also stated that there was an increased frequency of another gene as well
column5: suggesting that certain other immune system genes may interact with HLA-DR4 and contribute to individuals developing Felty's syndrome. In another report
column6: the authors described a family in which 3 siblings had Felty's syndrome. All of the siblings shared a specific haplotype (a group of immune system genes that may be inherited together). The authors stated that they believe this supports the theory that multiple genetic factors are involved in family members being predisposed to Felty's syndrome. An earlier article described a family in which the mother and 2 of her 5 children had Felty's syndrome
column7: which suggested autosomal dominant inheritance (which has not otherwise been reported).";"Is Tay-Sachs syndrome a form of Gaucher's disease?

664;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Niemann-Pick disease ?;"Niemann-Pick disease is a condition that affects many body systems. It has a wide range of symptoms that vary in severity. Niemann-Pick disease is divided into four main types: type A
column2: type B
column3: type C1
column4: and type C2. These types are classified on the basis of genetic cause and the signs and symptoms of the condition.  Infants with Niemann-Pick disease type A usually develop an enlarged liver and spleen (hepatosplenomegaly) by age 3 months and fail to gain weight and grow at the expected rate (failure to thrive). The affected children develop normally until around age 1 year when they experience a progressive loss of mental abilities and movement (psychomotor regression). Children with Niemann-Pick disease type A also develop widespread lung damage (interstitial lung disease) that can cause recurrent lung infections and eventually lead to respiratory failure. All affected children have an eye abnormality called a cherry-red spot
column5: which can be identified with an eye examination. Children with Niemann-Pick disease type A generally do not survive past early childhood.  Niemann-Pick disease type B usually presents in mid-childhood. The signs and symptoms of this type are similar to type A
column6: but not as severe. People with Niemann-Pick disease type B often have hepatosplenomegaly
column7: recurrent lung infections
column8: and a low number of platelets in the blood (thrombocytopenia). They also have short stature and slowed mineralization of bone (delayed bone age). About one-third of affected individuals have the cherry-red spot eye abnormality or neurological impairment. People with Niemann-Pick disease type B usually survive into adulthood.  The signs and symptoms of Niemann-Pick disease types C1 and C2 are very similar; these types differ only in their genetic cause. Niemann-Pick disease types C1 and C2 usually become apparent in childhood
column9: although signs and symptoms can develop at any time. People with these types usually develop difficulty coordinating movements (ataxia)
column10: an inability to move the eyes vertically (vertical supranuclear gaze palsy)
column11: poor muscle tone (dystonia)
column12: severe liver disease
column13: and interstitial lung disease. Individuals with Niemann-Pick disease types C1 and C2 have problems with speech and swallowing that worsen over time
column14: eventually interfering with feeding. Affected individuals often experience progressive decline in intellectual function and about one-third have seizures. People with these types may survive into adulthood.";Niemann-Pick disease is a rare
column15: genetic lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful substances within cells
column16: primarily affecting the spleen
column17: liver
column19: and brain. This buildup can lead to a range of symptoms
column20: including an enlarged spleen and liver
column21: yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)
column22: neurological problems
column23: respiratory issues
column24: and difficulty feeding and growing in infants. The disease is caused by mutations in genes involved in the metabolism and transport of lipids and cholesterol within cells
column25: leading to the accumulation of these substances and subsequent cellular damage. Treatment options vary depending on the type of Niemann-Pick disease
column26: but may include enzyme replacement therapy

column1: 665;gemini-pro;frequency;How many people are affected by lattice corneal dystrophy type I ?;"Lattice corneal dystrophy type I is one of the most common disorders in a group of conditions that are characterized by protein deposits in the cornea (corneal dystrophies); however

column1: 666;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase deficiency ?;"What causes carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase deficiency? Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase deficiency occurs when an enzyme
column2: called ""carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase"" (CAT)
column3: is either missing or not working properly. This enzyme's job is to help change certain fats in the food we eat into energy. It also helps to break down fat already stored in the body. Energy from fat keeps us going whenever our bodies run low of their main source of energy
column4: a type of sugar called glucose. Our bodies rely on fat for energy when we don't eat for a stretch of time - like when we miss a meal or when we sleep. When the CAT normal enzyme is missing or not working well
column5: the body cannot use fat for energy
column6: and must rely solely on glucose. Although glucose is a good source of energy
column7: there is a limited amount available. Once the glucose has been used up
column8: the body tries to use fat without success. This leads to low blood sugar
column9: called hypoglycemia
column10: and to the build up of harmful substances in the blood.";Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase (CACT) deficiency is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by an impaired transport of long-chain fatty acids (LCFA) into mitochondria for energy production. This is due to mutations in the SLC25A20 gene
column11: which encodes the CACT protein. The deficiency of CACT activity results in the accumulation of long-chain acylcarnitines in the blood and tissues
column12: leading to a variety of clinical manifestations
column13: including cardiomyopathy
column14: skeletal myopathy
column15: liver dysfunction
column16: and recurrent episodes of hypoketotic hypoglycemia. In severe cases
column17: CACT deficiency can be fatal in infancy or early childhood.;0.008;158.0;79.0;0.194;0.028;0.142;0.635;-0.092;-0.074;-0.114

column1: 667;gemini-pro;symptoms;What are the symptoms of Kidney Disease ?;"Kidney Disease Kidney disease is often called a ""silent"" disease
column2: because most people have no symptoms with early kidney disease. In fact
column3: you might feel just fine until your kidneys have almost stopped working. Do NOT wait for symptoms! If you are at risk for kidney disease
column4: talk to your health care provider about getting tested. (Watch the video to learn more about the symptoms of kidney disease. To enlarge the videos on this page
column5: click the brackets in the lower right-hand corner of the video screen. To reduce the videos
column6: press the Escape (Esc) button on your keyboard.) Symptoms of Kidney Failure Kidney failure means that damaged kidneys are filtering less than 15% of the amount of blood filtered by healthy kidneys. If kidney disease progresses to kidney failure
column7: a number of symptoms may occur. Some people experience fatigue
column8: some lose their appetite
column9: and some have leg cramps. These problems are caused by waste products that build up in the blood
column10: a condition known as uremia. Healthy kidneys remove waste products from the blood. When the kidneys stop working
column11: uremia occurs. The kidneys also make hormones and balance the minerals in the blood. When the kidneys stop working
column12: most people develop conditions that affect the blood
column13: bones
column14: nerves
column15: and skin. These problems may include itching
column16: sleep problems
column17: restless legs
column20: and depression. How Kidney Disease Is Diagnosed  Blood and urine tests are the only way to check for kidney damage or measure kidney function. It is important for you to get checked for kidney disease if you have the key risk factors
column21: which are - diabetes  - high blood pressure   - heart disease  - a family history of kidney failure.  diabetes high blood pressure heart disease a family history of kidney failure. If you are at risk
column22: ask about your kidneys at your next medical appointment. The sooner you know you have kidney disease
column23: the sooner you can get treatment to help delay or prevent kidney failure. If you have diabetes
column24: high blood pressure
column25: heart disease
column26: or a family history of kidney failure
column27: you should get a blood and urine test to check your kidneys. Talk to your provider about how often you should be tested. (Watch the video to learn more about tests for kidney disease.) Blood Test The blood test checks your GFR. GFR stands for glomerular (glow-MAIR-you-lure) filtration rate. GFR is a measure of how much blood your kidneys filter each minute. This shows how well your kidneys are working. GFR is reported as a number. -  A GFR of 60 or higher is in the normal range.   - A GFR below 60 may mean you have kidney disease. However
column28: because GFR decreases as people age
column29: other information may be needed to determine if you actually have kidney disease.  - A GFR of 15 or lower may mean kidney failure.  A GFR of 60 or higher is in the normal range. A GFR below 60 may mean you have kidney disease. However
column30: because GFR decreases as people age
column31: other information may be needed to determine if you actually have kidney disease. A GFR of 15 or lower may mean kidney failure. You can't raise your GFR
column32: but you can try to keep it from going lower. Ask your healthcare provider what you can do to keep your kidneys healthy.  Learn more about the GFR test. Urine Test The urine test looks for albumin (al-BYOO-min)
column33: a type of protein
column34: in your urine. A healthy kidney does not let albumin pass into the urine. A damaged kidney lets some albumin pass into the urine. This test has several different names. You could be told that you are being screened for ""proteinuria"" or ""albuminuria"" or ""microalbuminuria."" Or you could be told that your ""urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio"" (UACR) is being measured. If you have albumin or protein in your urine
column35: it could mean you have kidney disease. -  A urine albumin result below 30 is normal.  - A urine albumin result above 30 is not normal and may mean kidney disease. A urine albumin result below 30 is normal. A urine albumin result above 30 is not normal and may mean kidney disease. Learn more about the urine albumin test. Your healthcare provider might do additional tests to be sure.";The symptoms of kidney disease can vary depending on the stage and severity of the condition. In the early stages
column36: there may be no noticeable symptoms. As the condition progresses
column42: swelling in the hands and feet
column50: and foamy or bubbly urine. In severe cases
column51: kidney disease can lead to kidney failure

column1: 669;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia ?;Mutations in the TMPRSS6 gene cause iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called matriptase-2
column2: which helps regulate iron levels in the body. TMPRSS6 gene mutations reduce or eliminate functional matriptase-2
column3: which disrupts iron regulation and leads to a shortage of iron in the bloodstream. Iron is an essential component of hemoglobin
column4: which is the molecule in red blood cells that carries oxygen. When not enough iron is available in the bloodstream
column5: less hemoglobin is produced
column6: causing red blood cells to be abnormally small and pale. The abnormal cells cannot carry oxygen effectively to the body's cells and tissues
column7: which leads to fatigue
column8: weakness
column9: and other symptoms of anemia.;Iron-refractory iron deficiency anemia (IRIDA) is an autosomal recessive disorder attributed to mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in cellular iron homeostasis. The most prevalent genetic alteration associated with IRIDA is a mutation in the gene TMPRSS6
column10: which encodes the transmembrane protease serine 6. TMPRSS6 is involved in hepcidin regulation
column11: a hormone that controls iron absorption and recycling. Mutations in TMPRSS6 lead to excessive hepcidin production
column12: resulting in decreased iron absorption and impaired iron release from macrophages and hepatocytes. Other genetic changes linked to IRIDA include mutations in genes encoding proteins such as HFE2
column13: SLC40A1
column14: and FTH1
column15: all of which play crucial roles in iron transport
column16: regulation
column17: and cellular iron utilization. These genetic variations collectively contribute to the impaired intestinal iron absorption and ineffective erythropoiesis observed in IRIDA.;0.042;104.0;121.0;0.225;0.059;0.141;0.739;0.08;0.117;0.041

column1: 672;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Tyrosinemia type 1 ?;How might tyrosinemia type 1 be treated? There is currently no cure for tyrosinemia type 1. Individuals with this condition need to be on a special diet restricted in two amino acids
column2: tyrosine and phenylalanine
column3: throughout life. Affected individuals may also be treated with a medication called nitisinone. Early diagnosis and prompt treatment are essential for an improved prognosis. Some individuals require a liver transplant if their liver disease is already advanced before treatment begins. Detailed information on the treatment of tyrosinemia type 1 is available from GeneReviews.;Treatment for Tyrosinemia type 1 involves dietary restriction of tyrosine and phenylalanine
column4: along with medication to reduce the buildup of toxic metabolites. A specific drug called nitisinone (Orfadin) is commonly used to inhibit the enzyme that converts tyrosine to harmful metabolites. Additionally
column5: dietary changes are crucial
column6: including a low-protein diet and avoiding foods rich in tyrosine and phenylalanine
column7: such as meat
column8: poultry
column9: fish
column10: eggs
column11: dairy products
column12: nuts
column13: and certain fruits and vegetables. Supplementation with tyrosine- and phenylalanine-free amino acid mixtures is essential to ensure adequate intake of other amino acids. column5: while others may have severe motor disability
column6: moderate impaired mental development
column7: and multi-organ impairments.;The outlook for Joubert Syndrome varies depending on the severity of the condition. In milder cases
column8: individuals may have near-normal intelligence and may be able to live independently with support. In more severe cases
column9: individuals may have intellectual disability
column10: seizures
column11: and other medical problems. The average life expectancy for individuals with Joubert Syndrome is around 20 years
column12: but some individuals may live into their 40s or 50s. With early intervention and appropriate care
column13: many individuals with Joubert Syndrome can live happy and fulfilling lives.;0.032;64.0;80.0;0.299;0.061;0.206;0.685;0.086;0.046;0.124

column1: 679;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome ?;These resources address the diagnosis or management of Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome:  - Genetic Testing Registry: Pineal hyperplasia AND diabetes mellitus syndrome   These resources from MedlinePlus offer information about the diagnosis and management of various health conditions:  - Diagnostic Tests  - Drug Therapy  - Surgery and Rehabilitation  - Genetic Counseling   - Palliative Care;Currently
column2: there is no cure for Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome. Treatments are supportive and focus on minimizing symptoms and complications. column1: 681;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Ewing Sarcoma ?;"Key Points

- There are different types of treatment for children with Ewing sarcoma.    - Children with Ewing sarcoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.    - Treatment for Ewing sarcoma may cause side effects.    - Five types of standard treatment are used:         - Chemotherapy     - Radiation therapy     - Surgery     - Targeted therapy     - High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue        - New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.          - Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy        - Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.    - Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.    - Follow-up tests may be needed.

column1: There are different types of treatment for children with Ewing sarcoma.
Different types of treatments are available for children with Ewing sarcoma. Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment)
column2: and some are being tested in clinical trials. A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer. When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment
column3: the new treatment may become the standard treatment.   Because cancer in children is rare
column4: taking part in a clinical trial should be considered. Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.

column1: Children with Ewing sarcoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.
Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist
column2: a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer. The pediatric oncologist works with other health care providers who are experts in treating children with Ewing sarcoma and who specialize in certain areas of medicine. These may include the following specialists:         -  Pediatrician.    -  Surgical oncologist or orthopedic oncologist.    -  Radiation oncologist.    -  Pediatric nurse specialist.    -  Social worker.    -  Rehabilitation specialist.    -  Psychologist.

column1: Treatment for Ewing sarcoma may cause side effects.
For information about side effects that begin during treatment for cancer
column2: see our Side Effects page.    Side effects from cancer treatment that begin after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects. Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following:          - Physical problems.    - Changes in mood
column3: feelings
column4: thinking
column5: learning
column6: or memory.    -  Second cancers (new types of cancer). Patients treated for Ewing sarcoma have an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome. There is also an increased risk of sarcoma in the area treated with radiation therapy.        Some late effects may be treated or controlled. It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child. (See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.)

column1: Five types of standard treatment are used:
Chemotherapy     Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells
column2: either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing. When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle
column3: the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy). When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid
column4: an organ
column5: or a body cavity such as the abdomen
column6: the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy). Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.    Systemic chemotherapy is part of the treatment for all patients with Ewing tumors. It is often the first treatment given and lasts for about 6 to 12 months. Chemotherapy is often given to shrink the tumor before surgery or radiation therapy and to kill any tumor cells that may have spread to other parts of the body.    See Drugs Approved for Soft Tissue Sarcoma for more information.       Radiation therapy    Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses high-energy x-rays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing. There are two types of radiation therapy:            -  External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.     -  Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles
column7: seeds
column8: wires
column9: or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.           External radiation therapy is used to treat Ewing sarcoma.    Radiation therapy is used when the tumor cannot be removed by surgery or when surgery to remove the tumor will affect important body functions or the way the child will look. It may be used to make the tumor smaller and decrease the amount of tissue that needs to be removed during surgery. It may also be used to treat any tumor that remains after surgery and tumors that have spread to other parts of the body.       Surgery    Surgery is usually done to remove cancer that is left after chemotherapy or radiation therapy. When possible
column10: the whole tumor is removed by surgery. Tissue and bone that are removed may be replaced with a graft
column11: which uses tissue and bone taken from another part of the patient's body or a donor. Sometimes an implant
column12: such as artificial bone
column13: is used.    Even if the doctor removes all of the cancer that can be seen at the time of the operation
column14: chemotherapy or radiation therapy may be given after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left. Chemotherapy or radiation therapy given after surgery to lower the risk that the cancer will come back is called adjuvant therapy.        Targeted therapy     Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.     Monoclonal antibody therapy is a type of targeted therapy used in the treatment of recurrent Ewing sarcoma. It is being studied for the treatment of metastatic Ewing sarcoma. Monoclonal antibodies are made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell. These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow. The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells
column15: block their growth
column16: or keep them from spreading. Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion. They may be used alone or to carry drugs
column17: toxins
column18: or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.     New types of targeted therapy are being studied.            -  Kinase inhibitor therapy is another type of targeted therapy. Kinase inhibitors are drugs that block a protein needed for cancer cells to divide. They are being studied in the treatment of recurrent Ewing sarcoma.      -  PARP inhibitor therapy is another type of targeted therapy. PARP inhibitors are drugs that block DNA repair and may cause cancer cells to die. They are being studied in the treatment of recurrent Ewing sarcoma.              High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue     High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy to treat Ewing sarcoma and then replacing blood -forming cells destroyed by cancer treatment. Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient and are frozen and stored. After chemotherapy is completed
column19: the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion. These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells. Chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is used to treat recurrent Ewing sarcoma.

column1: New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.

This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials. It may not mention every new treatment being studied. Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.     Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy     CAR T-cell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that changes the patient's T cells (a type of immune system cell) so they will attack certain proteins on the surface of cancer cells. T cells are taken from the patient and special receptors are added to their surface in the laboratory. The changed cells are called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells. The CAR T cells are grown in the laboratory and given to the patient by infusion. The CAR T cells multiply in the patient's blood and attack cancer cells. CAR T-cell therapy is being studied in the treatment of Ewing sarcoma that has recurred.
Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.
For some patients
column2: taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice. Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process. Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.   Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials. Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.   Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future. Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments
column3: they often answer important questions and help move research forward.

column1: Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.

column1: Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment. Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better. There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.   Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country. See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials. These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.
Follow-up tests may be needed.

Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated. Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working. Decisions about whether to continue
column2: change
column3: or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.   Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended. The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back). These tests are sometimes called follow-up tests or check-ups.

column1: Treatment Options for Ewing Sarcoma
Localized Ewing Sarcoma

Standard treatments for localized Ewing sarcoma include:         -  Chemotherapy.    -  Surgery and/or radiation therapy.         These treatments and the order they are given depend on the following:         - Where in the body the tumor started.    - How large the tumor is when the cancer is diagnosed.    - Whether the tumor was completely removed by surgery.    - The child's age and general health.    - Whether the treatment will affect important body functions or the way the child will look.         Treatments being studied for localized Ewing sarcoma include:         -  High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.        Check the list of NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized Ewing sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor. For more specific results

column1: Metastatic Ewing Sarcoma

Standard treatments for metastatic Ewing sarcoma include:          -  Chemotherapy.    -  Surgery.    -  Radiation therapy.        These treatments and the order they are given depend on the following:          - Where in the body the tumor started.    - Where the tumor has spread.    - How large the tumor is.    - Whether the treatment will affect important body functions or the way the child will look.    - The child's age and general health.        Treatments being studied for metastatic Ewing sarcoma include the following:         -  Combination chemotherapy with or without targeted therapy. Radiation therapy is given to areas of bone where cancer has spread.    -  High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.        Check the list of NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with metastatic Ewing sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor. For more specific results

column1: Recurrent Ewing Sarcoma
There is no standard treatment for recurrent Ewing sarcoma but treatment options may include the following:         -  Combination chemotherapy.    -  Radiation therapy to bone tumors
column2: as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.    -  Radiation therapy that may be followed by surgery to remove tumors that have spread to the lungs.     -  High-dose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.    -  Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody.        These treatments and the order they are given depend on the following:         - Where in the body the tumor came back.    - The initial treatment given.        Treatment options being studied for recurrent Ewing sarcoma include the following:         -  Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody.     -  Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy.    - Targeted therapy with a PARP inhibitor and chemotherapy.        Check the list of NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent Ewing sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor. For more specific results

column1: 682;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Glomerular Diseases ?;"Patients with glomerular disease have significant amounts of protein in the urine

column3: particularly in some forms of glomerular disease. Urinalysis provides information about kidney damage by indicating levels of protein and red blood cells in the urine. column7: which are small filters in the kidneys that help remove waste products from the blood. Diagnosis typically involves a combination of tests
column8: including:

column1: * **Urinalysis:** This test checks for abnormal levels of protein
column2: blood
column3: and other substances in the urine
column4: which can indicate glomerular damage.

column1: * **Blood tests:** Blood tests can measure levels of creatinine
column2: urea
column3: and other substances that can be elevated in glomerular diseases. Blood tests can also be used to check for antibodies associated with certain glomerular diseases.

column1: * **Imaging tests:** Imaging tests
column2: such as ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) scans
column3: can provide detailed images of the kidneys and help identify structural abnormalities or blockages.

column1: * **Kidney biopsy:** In some cases
column2: a kidney biopsy may be necessary to obtain a sample of kidney tissue for examination under a microscope. This can help determine the specific type of glomerular disease and guide treatment decisions.";0.05;164.0;143.0;0.425;0.129;0.238;0.902;0.256;0.242;0.268

column1: 696;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Leukemia ?;There are no standard or over-the-counter tests for leukemia. Your doctor can request lab analyses for leukemia that include blood tests that check the levels and types of blood cells and look for changes in the shape of blood cells. The doctor may also look for signs of leukemia in the bone marrow or the fluid around the brain or the spinal cord;"Diagnosing Leukemia involves a comprehensive evaluation to determine the type and extent of the disease. Initial assessment includes a detailed medical history
column2: physical examination
column3: and blood tests

column5: to evaluate cell counts and abnormalities. Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy are crucial diagnostic procedures; a sample of bone marrow is extracted and examined under a microscope to assess the presence
column6: type
column7: and maturity of leukemia cells. Additional tests may include cytogenetic analysis to study chromosomal abnormalities
column8: molecular studies to identify specific genetic mutations

column1: 697;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Trisomy 17 mosaicism ?;"What causes trisomy 17 mosaicism? Trisomy 17 mosaicism can arise due to errors in cell division that occur after conception. For example
column2: at the time of conception

column5: some of the cells lose the extra chromosome 17. Alternatively
column6: the fetus may initially have had only two copies of chromosome 17
column7: but due to errors in cell division some of the cells end up with an extra copy of chromosome 17. Either of these two scenarios result in trisomy 17 mosaicism. To read more about trisomy mosaicism
column8: visit the following links from the Medical Genetics Department at the University of British Columbia in Canada. What is mosaicism?  How does trisomy mosaicism occur?";Trisomy 17 mosaicism
column9: a rare genetic condition
column10: occurs when an individual has an extra copy of chromosome 17 in some of their cells. The exact cause of this chromosomal abnormality is not fully understood
column11: but it is believed to arise from errors during cell division. These errors can happen during the formation of sperm or eggs (meiosis) or in the early stages of embryonic development (mitosis). In some cases

column4: chronic inflammation and/or prolonged compression of the airways.;Tracheobronchomalacia (TBM) is a condition characterized by the softening and weakening of the walls of the trachea and bronchi
