column1: 708;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Acromegaly ?;"Currently
column2: treatment options include surgical removal of the tumor
column3: medical therapy
column4: and radiation therapy of the pituitary.

column1: Goals of treatment are to

- reduce excess hormone production to normal levels  - relieve the pressure that the growing pituitary tumor may be exerting on the surrounding brain areas  - preserve normal pituitary function or treat hormone deficiencies  - improve the symptoms of acromegaly
Surgery
Surgery is the first option recommended for most people with acromegaly
column2: as it is often a rapid and effective treatment. The surgeon reaches the pituitary via an incision through the nose or inside the upper lip and
column3: with special tools
column4: removes the tumor tissue in a procedure called transsphenoidal surgery. This procedure promptly relieves the pressure on the surrounding brain regions and leads to a rapid lowering of GH levels. If the surgery is successful
column5: facial appearance and soft tissue swelling improve within a few days.

column1: Surgery is most successful in patients with blood GH levels below 45 ng/ml before the operation and with pituitary tumors no larger than 10 millimeters (mm) in diameter. Success depends in large part on the skill and experience of the surgeon
column2: as well as the location of the tumor. Even with the most experienced neurosurgeon
column3: the chance of a cure is small if the tumor has extended into critical brain structures or into the cavernous sinus where surgery could be risky.

column1: The success rate also depends on what level of GH is defined as a cure. The best measure of surgical success is normalization of GH and IGF-I levels. The overall rate of remission-control of the disease-after surgery ranges from 55 to 80 percent. (See For More Information to locate a board-certified neurosurgeon.)
A possible complication of surgery is damage to the surrounding normal pituitary tissue
column2: which requires lifelong use of pituitary hormone replacement. The part of the pituitary that stores antidiuretic hormonea hormone important in water balancemay be temporarily or
column3: rarely
column4: permanently damaged and the patient may require medical therapy. Other potential problems include cerebrospinal fluid leaks and
column5: rarely
column6: meningitis. Cerebrospinal fluid bathes the brain and can leak from the nose if the incision area doesnt heal well. Meningitis is a bacterial or viral infection of the meninges
column7: the outer covering of the brain.

column1: Even when surgery is successful and hormone levels return to normal
column2: people with acromegaly must be carefully monitored for years for possible recurrence of the disease. More commonly
column3: hormone levels improve
column4: but do not return to normal. Additional treatment
column5: usually medications
column6: may be required.

column1: Medical Therapy
Medical therapy is most often used if surgery does not result in a cure and sometimes to shrink large tumors before surgery. Three medication groups are used to treat acromegaly.

Somatostatin analogs (SSAs) are the first medication group used to treat acromegaly. They shut off GH production and are effective in lowering GH and IGF-I levels in 50 to 70 percent of patients. SSAs also reduce tumor size in around 0 to 50 percent of patients but only to a modest degree. Several studies have shown that SSAs are safe and effective for long-term treatment and in treating patients with acromegaly caused by nonpituitary tumors. Long-acting SSAs are given by intramuscular injection once a month.
Digestive problems-such as loose stools
column2: nausea
column3: and gas-are a side effect in about half of people taking SSAs. However
column4: the effects are usually temporary and rarely severe. About 10 to 20 percent of patients develop gallstones
column5: but the gallstones do not usually cause symptoms. In rare cases
column6: treatment can result in elevated blood glucose levels. More commonly
column7: SSAs reduce the need for insulin and improve blood glucose control in some people with acromegaly who already have diabetes.

column1: The second medication group is the GH receptor antagonists (GHRAs)
column2: which interfere with the action of GH. They normalize IGF-I levels in more than 90 percent of patients. They do not
column3: however
column4: lower GH levels. Given once a day through injection
column5: GHRAs are usually well-tolerated by patients. The long-term effects of these drugs on tumor growth are still under study. Side effects can include headaches
column6: fatigue
column7: and abnormal liver function.

column1: Dopamine agonists make up the third medication group. These drugs are not as effective as the other medications at lowering GH or IGF-I levels
column2: and they normalize IGF-I levels in only a minority of patients. Dopamine agonists are sometimes effective in patients who have mild degrees of excess GH and have both acromegaly and hyperprolactinemiatoo much of the hormone prolactin. Dopamine agonists can be used in combination with SSAs. Side effects can include nausea
column3: headache
column4: and lightheadedness.

column1: Agonist: A drug that binds to a receptor of a cell and triggers a response by the cell
column2: mimicking the action of a naturally occurring substance.   Antagonist: A chemical that acts within the body to reduce the physiological activity of another chemical substance or hormone.

column1: Radiation Therapy
Radiation therapy is usually reserved for people who have some tumor remaining after surgery and do not respond to medications. Because radiation leads to a slow lowering of GH and IGF-I levels
column2: these patients often also receive medication to lower hormone levels. The full effect of this therapy may not occur for many years.

column1: The two types of radiation delivery are conventional and stereotactic. Conventional radiation delivery targets the tumor with external beams but can damage surrounding tissue. The treatment delivers small doses of radiation multiple times over 4 to 6 weeks
column2: giving normal tissue time to heal between treatments.

column1: Stereotactic delivery allows precise targeting of a high-dose beam of radiation at the tumor from varying angles. The patient must wear a rigid head frame to keep the head still. The types of stereotactic radiation delivery currently available are proton beam
column2: linear accelerator (LINAC)
column3: and gamma knife. With stereotactic delivery
column4: the tumor must be at least 5 mm from the optic chiasm to prevent radiation damage. This treatment can sometimes be done in a single session
column5: reducing the risk of damage to surrounding tissue.

column1: All forms of radiation therapy cause a gradual decline in production of other pituitary hormones over time
column2: resulting in the need for hormone replacement in most patients. Radiation also can impair a patients fertility. Vision loss and brain injury are rare complications. Rarely
column3: secondary tumors can develop many years later in areas that were in the path of the radiation beam.";Acromegaly
column4: characterized by excessive growth hormone production
column5: is primarily managed with medications or surgical interventions. Medications commonly used include somatostatin analogues like octreotide or lanreotide
column6: which suppress growth hormone secretion. Dopamine agonists like cabergoline or bromocriptine can also be effective in reducing growth hormone levels. In cases of medication resistance or tumors causing the condition
column7: surgical removal of the pituitary tumor via transsphenoidal surgery is the preferred treatment. Radiation therapy may be employed post-surgery to prevent tumor recurrence. Additional treatments may target symptoms or complications
column8: such as managing blood pressure
column9: regulating glucose levels

column1: 709;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) color vision deficiency ?;Color vision deficiency (sometimes called color blindness) represents a group of conditions that affect the perception of color. column1: 717;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) G6PD Deficiency ?;Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is a genetic disorder that is most common in males. About 1 in 10 African American males in the United States has it. G6PD deficiency mainly affects red blood cells

column12: Mediterranean
column13: and Asian descent

column17: including fatigue

column1: 719;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome ?;Mutations in the DHCR7 gene cause Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome.  The DHCR7 gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called 7-dehydrocholesterol reductase. This enzyme is responsible for the final step in the production of cholesterol. Cholesterol is a waxy
column2: fat-like substance that is produced in the body and obtained from foods that come from animals (particularly egg yolks
column3: meat
column4: poultry
column5: fish
column6: and dairy products). Cholesterol is necessary for normal embryonic development and has important functions both before and after birth. It is a structural component of cell membranes and the protective substance covering nerve cells (myelin). Additionally
column7: cholesterol plays a role in the production of certain hormones and digestive acids.  Mutations in the DHCR7 gene reduce or eliminate the activity of 7-dehydrocholesterol reductase
column8: preventing cells from producing enough cholesterol. A lack of this enzyme also allows potentially toxic byproducts of cholesterol production to build up in the blood
column9: nervous system
column10: and other tissues. The combination of low cholesterol levels and an accumulation of other substances likely disrupts the growth and development of many body systems. It is not known
column11: however
column12: how this disturbance in cholesterol production leads to the specific features of Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome.;Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome (SLOS) is a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the DHCR7 gene
column13: which encodes an enzyme called 7-dehydrocholesterol reductase. This enzyme is involved in the biosynthesis of cholesterol
column14: a molecule that plays a vital role in various cellular processes. Mutations in the DHCR7 gene lead to a deficiency of cholesterol and an accumulation of its precursor
column15: 7-dehydrocholesterol (7-DHC). These genetic changes result in a wide range of clinical manifestations
column16: including physical abnormalities
column17: intellectual disability

column1: 720;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Childhood Brain Stem Glioma ?;"Key Points

- There are different types of treatment for children with brain stem glioma.     - Children with brain stem glioma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain tumors.    - Childhood brain stem gliomas may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.    - Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.    - Six types of standard treatment are used:         - Surgery      - Radiation therapy      - Chemotherapy      - Cerebrospinal fluid diversion     - Observation     - Targeted therapy        - New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.     - Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.    - Patients can enter clinical trials before
column2: during
column3: or after starting their cancer treatment.    - Follow-up tests may be needed.

column1: There are different types of treatment for children with brain stem glioma.
Different types of treatment are available for children with brain stem glioma. Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment)
column2: and some are being tested in clinical trials. A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer. When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment
column3: the new treatment may become the standard treatment.    Because cancer in children is rare
column4: taking part in a clinical trial should be considered. Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.

column1: Children with brain stem glioma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain tumors.
Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist
column2: a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer. The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with brain tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine. These may include the following specialists:         -  Pediatrician.    -  Neurosurgeon.    -  Neuropathologist.    -  Radiation oncologist.    -  Neuro-oncologist.    -  Neurologist.    -  Rehabilitation specialist.    -  Neuroradiologist.    -  Endocrinologist.    -  Psychologist.

column1: Childhood brain stem gliomas may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.

Childhood brain stem gliomas may cause signs or symptoms that continue for months or years. Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before diagnosis. Signs or symptoms caused by treatment may begin during or right after treatment.
Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.
These are called late effects. Late effects may include the following:         - Physical problems.    - Changes in mood
column2: feelings
column3: thinking
column4: learning
column5: or memory.    -  Second cancers (new types of cancer).        Some late effects may be treated or controlled. It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child. (See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).

column1: Six types of standard treatment are used:

Surgery      Surgery may be used to diagnose and treat childhood brain stem glioma as discussed in the General Information section of this summary.        Radiation therapy      Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses high-energy x-rays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing. There are two types of radiation therapy:             -  External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.     -  Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles
column2: seeds
column3: wires
column4: or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.             The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of the cancer being treated. External radiation therapy is used to treat DIPG. External and/or internal radiation therapy may be used to treat focal brain stem gliomas.     Several months after radiation therapy to the brain
column5: imaging tests may show changes to the brain tissue. These changes may be caused by the radiation therapy or may mean the tumor is growing. It is important to be sure the tumor is growing before any more treatment is given.       Chemotherapy      Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells
column6: either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing. When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle
column7: the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy). When chemotherapy is placed directly in the cerebrospinal fluid
column8: an organ
column9: or a body cavity such as the abdomen
column10: the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy). The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of the cancer being treated.     Because radiation therapy to the brain can affect growth and brain development in young children
column11: clinical trials are studying ways of using chemotherapy to delay or reduce the need for radiation therapy.       Cerebrospinal fluid diversion     Cerebrospinal fluid diversion is a method used to drain fluid that has built up in the brain. A shunt (long
column12: thin tube) is placed in a ventricle (fluid-filled space) of the brain and threaded under the skin to another part of the body
column13: usually the abdomen. The shunt carries extra fluid away from the brain so it may be absorbed elsewhere in the body.          Observation     Observation is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.       Targeted therapy     Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.     Some focal brain stem gliomas that cannot be removed by surgery may be treated with BRAF kinase inhibitor therapy. BRAF kinase inhibitors block the BRAF protein. BRAF proteins help control cell growth and may be mutated (changed) in some types of brain stem glioma. Blocking mutated BRAF kinase proteins may help keep cancer cells from growing.

Follow-up tests may be needed.

Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated. Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working. Decisions about whether to continue

If the results of imaging tests done after treatment show a mass in the brain

column1: Treatment Options for Childhood Brain Stem Glioma
Newly Diagnosed Childhood Brain Stem Glioma

Newly diagnosed childhood brain stem glioma is a tumor for which no treatment has been given. The child may have received drugs or treatment to relieve signs or symptoms caused by the tumor.       Standard treatment of diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) may include the following:            -  Radiation therapy.     -  Chemotherapy (in infants).               Standard treatment of focal glioma may include the following:            -  Surgery that may be followed by chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.     -  Observation for small tumors that grow slowly. Cerebrospinal fluid diversion may be done when there is extra fluid in the brain.     -  Internal radiation therapy with radioactive seeds
column2: with or without chemotherapy
column3: when the tumor cannot be removed by surgery.     -  Targeted therapy with a BRAF kinase inhibitor
column4: for certain tumors that cannot be removed by surgery.               Treatment of brain stem glioma in children with neurofibromatosis type 1 may be observation. The tumors are slow-growing in these children and may not need specific treatment for years.     Check the list of NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood brain stem glioma. For more specific results
column5: refine the search by using other search features

column7: the type of treatment
column8: or the name of the drug. Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child. General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.

column1: Progressive or Recurrent Childhood Brain Stem Glioma
When cancer does not get better with treatment or comes back
column2: palliative care is an important part of the child's treatment plan. It includes physical
column3: psychological
column4: social
column5: and spiritual support for the child and family. The goal of palliative care is to help control symptoms and give the child the best quality of life possible. Parents may not be sure about whether to continue treatment or what kind of treatment is best for their child. The healthcare team can give parents information to help them make these decisions.      There is no standard treatment for progressive or recurrent diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma. The child may be treated in a clinical trial of a new treatment.         Treatment of recurrent focal childhood brain stem glioma may include the following:            - A second surgery to remove the tumor.     -  External radiation therapy.     -  Chemotherapy.     - A clinical trial of a new treatment.            Check the list of NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent childhood brain stem glioma. For more specific results

column8: the type of treatment

column1: 723;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Diarrhea ?;"Acute diarrhea is usually caused by a bacterial
column2: viral
column3: or parasitic infection. Chronic diarrhea is usually related to a functional disorder such as irritable bowel syndrome or an intestinal disease such as Crohns disease.

column1: The most common causes of diarrhea include the following:
- Bacterial infections. Several types of bacteria consumed through contaminated food or water can cause diarrhea. Common culprits include Campylobacter
column2: Salmonella
column3: Shigella
column4: and Escherichia coli (E. coli).  - Viral infections. Many viruses cause diarrhea
column5: including rotavirus
column6: norovirus
column7: cytomegalovirus
column8: herpes simplex virus
column9: and viral hepatitis. Infection with the rotavirus is the most common cause of acute diarrhea in children. Rotavirus diarrhea usually resolves in 3 to 7 days but can cause problems digesting lactose for up to a month or longer.  - Parasites. Parasites can enter the body through food or water and settle in the digestive system. Parasites that cause diarrhea include Giardia lamblia
column10: Entamoeba histolytica
column11: and Cryptosporidium.  - Functional bowel disorders. Diarrhea can be a symptom of irritable bowel syndrome.  - Intestinal diseases. Inflammatory bowel disease
column12: ulcerative colitis
column13: Crohns disease
column14: and celiac disease often lead to diarrhea.  - Food intolerances and sensitivities. Some people have difficulty digesting certain ingredients
column15: such as lactose
column16: the sugar found in milk and milk products. Some people may have diarrhea if they eat certain types of sugar substitutes in excessive quantities.  - Reaction to medicines. Antibiotics
column17: cancer drugs
column18: and antacids containing magnesium can all cause diarrhea.

column1: Some people develop diarrhea after stomach surgery
column2: which may cause food to move through the digestive system more quickly.

column1: People who visit certain foreign countries are at risk for travelers diarrhea
column2: which is caused by eating food or drinking water contaminated with bacteria
column3: viruses
column4: or parasites. Travelers diarrhea can be a problem for people traveling to developing countries in Africa
column5: Asia
column6: Latin America
column7: and the Caribbean. Visitors to Canada
column8: most European countries
column9: Japan
column10: Australia
column11: and New Zealand do not face much risk for travelers diarrhea.

column1: In many cases
column2: the cause of diarrhea cannot be found. As long as diarrhea goes away on its own within 1 to 2 days
column3: finding the cause is not usually necessary.";"Diarrhea is a common digestive problem characterized by loose
column4: watery stools that occur more frequently than usual. It can be caused by various factors
column5: including bacterial
column6: viral
column7: or parasitic infections; food poisoning; certain medications; lactose intolerance; irritable bowel syndrome; inflammatory bowel disease; and certain medical conditions such as celiac disease or Crohn's disease. In some cases
column8: diarrhea can also be a sign of more serious underlying conditions
column9: such as thyroid problems or cancer. If diarrhea persists for more than a few days

column1: 724;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA ?;Mutations in the SPTLC1 gene cause hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA. The SPTLC1 gene provides instructions for making one part (subunit) of an enzyme called serine palmitoyltransferase (SPT). The SPT enzyme is involved in making certain fats called sphingolipids. Sphingolipids are important components of cell membranes and play a role in many cell functions.  SPTLC1 gene mutations reduce the amount of functional SPTLC1 subunit that is produced
column2: which results in an SPT enzyme with altered activity. This altered enzyme makes molecules called deoxysphingoid bases
column3: which it does not normally produce. Because of this new function
column4: the SPT enzyme's production of sphingolipid is reduced. Overall
column5: there does not seem to be a decrease in sphingolipid production because the body is able to compensate for the SPT enzyme's reduced production. When accumulated
column6: deoxysphingoid bases are toxic to neurons. The gradual destruction of nerve cells caused by the buildup of these toxic molecules results in loss of sensation and muscle weakness in people with hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA. Although the SPT enzyme does not produce a normal amount of sphingolipids
column7: the body is able to compensate
column8: and there does not seem to be an overall reduction of these fats in the body.;Hereditary sensory neuropathy type IA (HSN1A) is an inherited disorder of the peripheral nervous system that affects the sensory nerves. It is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the protein septin 9 (SEPT9). SEPT9 is involved in the formation of the axonal cytoskeleton
column9: which is essential for the proper function of neurons. Mutations in SEPT9 can lead to the degeneration of sensory neurons
column10: resulting in symptoms such as numbness
column11: tingling
column12: and pain in the hands and feet. Additionally
column13: HSN1A can cause problems with coordination and balance

column1: 727;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for glycogen storage disease type III ?;These resources address the diagnosis or management of glycogen storage disease type III:  - Gene Review: Gene Review: Glycogen Storage Disease Type III  - Genetic Testing Registry: Glycogen storage disease type III   These resources from MedlinePlus offer information about the diagnosis and management of various health conditions:  - Diagnostic Tests  - Drug Therapy  - Surgery and Rehabilitation  - Genetic Counseling   - Palliative Care;Glycogen storage disease type III

column4: a complex sugar stored in the liver and muscles. Treatment options for glycogen storage disease type III include dietary modifications
column5: such as consuming smaller
column6: frequent meals high in complex carbohydrates and low in simple sugars
column7: and avoiding fasting. Medications such as acarbose or miglitol may be prescribed to help slow down the absorption of carbohydrates. In severe cases
column8: liver transplantation may be considered. Additionally

column2: also known as dermatopathia pigmentosa reticularis
column3: are currently limited and largely supportive. Therapies focus on managing symptoms and improving the patient's quality of life. Since it is a genetic condition

column9: such as corneal scarring or cataracts. 4) Orthopedic care: Physical therapy or orthotics may be beneficial in managing joint pain or deformities. 5) Psychological support: Counseling or support groups can provide emotional support and guidance for individuals and families coping with the physical and psychosocial aspects of NFJS.;0.016;62.0;149.0;0.198;0.03;0.086;0.623;-0.081;-0.052;-0.113

column2: the heart cannot pump enough blood through the body. Heart failure develops over time as the pumping action of the heart gets weaker. Heart failure does not mean that the heart has stopped working or is about to stop working. When the heart is weakened by heart failure
column3: blood and fluid can back up into the lungs and fluid builds up in the feet
column4: ankles
column5: and legs. People with heart failure often experience tiredness and shortness of breath.;Heart failure

column10: and high blood pressure. As a result
column11: blood can back up in the lungs
column12: causing shortness of breath

column14: leading to swelling and fluid retention. Heart failure can range from mild to severe

column16: lifestyle changes

column1: 733;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Arrhythmia ?;An arrhythmia is a problem with the rate or rhythm of your heartbeat. It means that your heart beats too quickly

column3: or with an irregular pattern. When the heart beats faster than normal
column4: it is called tachycardia. When the heart beats too slowly

column7: such as having had a heart attack
column8: smoking
column9: congenital heart defects
column10: and stress. Some substances or medicines may also cause arrhythmias.     Symptoms of arrhythmias include       - Fast or slow heart beat    - Skipping beats    - Lightheadedness or dizziness    - Chest pain    - Shortness of breath     - Sweating        Your doctor can run tests to find out if you have an arrhythmia. Treatment to restore a normal heart rhythm may include medicines
column11: an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) or pacemaker
column12: or sometimes surgery.     NIH: National Heart
column13: Lung
column14: and Blood Institute;Arrhythmia is a general term for any abnormality in the rate or rhythm of the heartbeat. It can be caused by a variety of underlying conditions
column15: including heart disease
column16: thyroid problems

column1: 735;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Leigh syndrome ?;Leigh syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of over 30 different genes. In humans
column2: most genes are found in DNA in the cell's nucleus
column3: called nuclear DNA. However
column4: some genes are found in DNA in specialized structures in the cell called mitochondria. This type of DNA is known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). While most people with Leigh syndrome have a mutation in nuclear DNA
column5: about 20 to 25 percent have a mutation in mtDNA.  Most genes associated with Leigh syndrome are involved in the process of energy production in mitochondria. Mitochondria use oxygen to convert the energy from food into a form cells can use. Five protein complexes
column6: made up of several proteins each
column7: are involved in this process
column8: called oxidative phosphorylation. The complexes are named complex I
column9: complex II
column10: complex III
column11: complex IV
column12: and complex V. During oxidative phosphorylation
column13: the protein complexes drive the production of ATP
column14: the cell's main energy source
column15: through a step-by-step transfer of negatively charged particles called electrons. Many of the gene mutations associated with Leigh syndrome affect proteins in complexes I
column16: II
column17: IV
column18: or V or disrupt the assembly of these complexes. These mutations reduce or eliminate the activity of one or more of these complexes
column19: which can lead to Leigh syndrome.  Disruption of complex IV
column20: also called cytochrome c oxidase or COX
column21: is the most common cause of Leigh syndrome. The most frequently mutated gene in COX-deficient Leigh syndrome is called SURF1. This gene
column22: which is found in nuclear DNA
column23: provides instructions for making a protein that helps assemble the COX protein complex (complex IV). The COX protein complex
column24: which is involved in the last step of electron transfer in oxidative phosphorylation
column25: provides the energy that will be used in the next step of the process to generate ATP. Mutations in the SURF1 gene typically lead to an abnormally short SURF1 protein that is broken down in cells
column26: resulting in the absence of functional SURF1 protein. The loss of this protein reduces the formation of normal COX complexes
column27: which impairs mitochondrial energy production.  Other nuclear DNA mutations associated with Leigh syndrome decrease the activity of other oxidative phosphorylation protein complexes or affect additional steps related to energy production. For example
column28: Leigh syndrome can be caused by mutations in genes that form the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex. These mutations lead to a shortage of pyruvate dehydrogenase
column29: an enzyme involved in mitochondrial energy production.  The most common mtDNA mutation in Leigh syndrome affects the MT-ATP6 gene
column30: which provides instructions for making a piece of complex V
column31: also known as the ATP synthase protein complex. Using the energy provided by the other protein complexes
column32: the ATP synthase complex generates ATP. MT-ATP6 gene mutations
column33: found in 10 to 20 percent of people with Leigh syndrome
column34: block the generation of ATP. Other mtDNA mutations associated with Leigh syndrome decrease the activity of other oxidative phosphorylation protein complexes or lead to reduced mitochondrial protein synthesis

column1: 736;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Gamma aminobutyric acid transaminase deficiency ?;GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) is an important molecule which slows down the activity of cells in the brain.[1] GABA is broken down in the body by a substance known as 4-aminobutyrate aminotransferase

column1: 737;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to citrullinemia ?;Mutations in the ASS1 and SLC25A13 genes cause citrullinemia. column2: which is excreted in urine.  Mutations in the ASS1 gene cause type I citrullinemia. This gene provides instructions for making an enzyme

column5: which disrupts the urea cycle and prevents the body from processing nitrogen effectively. Excess nitrogen (in the form of ammonia) and other byproducts of the urea cycle accumulate in the bloodstream. Ammonia is particularly toxic to the nervous system

column1: 747;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome ?;"Treatments for obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) include breathing support
column2: weight loss
column3: and medicines.

column1: The goals of treating OHS may include:
Supporting and aiding your breathing
Achieving major weight loss
Treating underlying and related conditions
Breathing Support
Positive Airway Pressure
Treatment for OHS often involves a machine that provides positive airway pressure (PAP) while you sleep.

PAP therapy uses mild air pressure to keep your airways open. This treatment can help your body better maintain the carbon dioxide and oxygen levels in your blood. PAP therapy also can help relieve daytime sleepiness.

Your doctor might recommend CPAP (continuous positive airway pressure) or BiPAP (bilevel positive airway pressure). CPAP provides continuous mild air pressure to keep your airways open. BiPAP works almost the same
column2: but it changes the air pressure while you breathe in and out.

column1: The machines have three main parts:
A mask or other device that fits over your nose or your nose and mouth. Straps keep the mask in place while you're wearing it.
A tube that connects the mask to the machine's motor.
A motor that blows air into the tube.
Some machines have other features
column2: such as heated humidifiers. The machines are small
column3: lightweight
column4: and fairly quiet. The noise they make is soft and rhythmic.

column1: Some people who have OHS receive extra oxygen as part of their PAP treatment. However
column2: oxygen therapy alone isn't recommended as a treatment for OHS.

column1: PAP therapy also is used to treat obstructive sleep apnea. Many people who have OHS also have this common condition.
If your doctor prescribes PAP therapy
column2: you'll work with someone from a home equipment provider to select a CPAP or BiPAP machine. The home equipment provider will help you pick a machine based on your prescription and the features that meet your needs.

column1: Ventilator Support
If you have severe OHS that requires treatment in a hospital
column2: you might be put on a ventilator. A ventilator is a machine that supports breathing. This machine:

column1: Gets oxygen into your lungs
Removes carbon dioxide from your body
Helps you breathe easier
A ventilator blows air
column2: or air with extra oxygen
column3: into the airways through a breathing tube. One end of the tube is inserted into your windpipe
column4: and the other end is hooked to the ventilator.

column1: Usually
column2: the breathing tube is put into your nose or mouth and then moved down into your throat. A tube placed like this is called an endotracheal (en-do-TRA-ke-al) tube. Endotracheal tubes are used only in a hospital setting.

column1: Sometimes the breathing tube is placed through a surgically made hole called a tracheostomy (TRA-ke-OS-toe-me). The hole goes through the front of your neck and into your windpipe.
The procedure to make a tracheostomy usually is done in an operating room. You'll be given medicine so you won't feel any pain. The tracheostomy allows you to be on a ventilator in the hospital
column2: in a long-term care facility
column3: or at home.

column1: Talk with your doctor about how long you'll need ventilator support and whether you can receive treatment at home.
For more information about ventilator support
column2: go to the Health Topics Ventilator/Ventilator Support article.

column1: Weight Loss
Your doctor will likely recommend weight loss as part of your treatment plan. Successful weight loss often involves setting goals and making lifestyle changes. For example
column2: eating fewer calories and being physically active can help you lose weight.

column1: Medicines and weight-loss surgery might be an option if lifestyle changes aren't enough. Your doctor will advise you on the best weight-loss treatment for you.
For more information about weight loss
column2: go to the treatment section of the Health Topics Overweight and Obesity article.

column1: Medicines
Your doctor may prescribe medicines to treat OHS (although this treatment is less common than others).
Your doctor also may advise you to avoid certain substances and medicines that can worsen OHS. Examples include alcohol
column2: sedatives
column3: and narcotics. They can interfere with how well your body is able to maintain normal carbon dioxide and oxygen levels.

column1: If you're having surgery
column2: make sure you tell your surgeon and health care team that you have OHS. Some medicines routinely used for surgery can worsen your condition.";Treatment for obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) typically involves a combination of lifestyle changes
column3: breathing support
column4: and medical interventions. Lifestyle changes may include weight loss through diet and exercise
column5: smoking cessation
column6: and getting regular check-ups. Breathing support may involve supplemental oxygen therapy
column7: non-invasive ventilation (using a mask or nasal prongs to deliver pressurized air)
column8: or invasive ventilation (using a tracheostomy tube to deliver air directly to the lungs). Medical interventions may include medications to improve breathing
column9: such as bronchodilators
column10: diuretics
column11: and steroids. In some cases
column12: surgery may be necessary to reduce the size of the stomach or bypass part of the intestine in order to aid in weight loss.;0.0;635.0;101.0;0.203;0.047;0.137;0.777;-0.141;-0.291;0.014

column1: 749;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome ?;"Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) is a breathing disorder that affects some obese people. Why these people develop OHS isn't fully known. Researchers think that several factors may work together to cause OHS. These factors include:

column2: including the lungs

The presence of sleep apnea
column2: usually obstructive sleep apnea.";Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome (OHS) is a disorder characterized by excessive weight gain and inadequate breathing
column3: leading to abnormally low blood oxygen levels and high carbon dioxide levels. The primary cause of OHS is severe obesity
column4: particularly when body mass index (BMI) exceeds 40 kg/m^2. This excessive fat accumulation can lead to mechanical dysfunction of the respiratory system
column5: decreased lung volumes

column1: 750;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Unverricht-Lundborg disease ?;Mutations in the CSTB gene cause Unverricht-Lundborg disease. The CSTB gene provides instructions for making a protein called cystatin B. This protein reduces the activity of enzymes called cathepsins. Cathepsins help break down certain proteins in the lysosomes (compartments in the cell that digest and recycle materials). While the specific function of cystatin B is unclear
column2: it may help protect the cells' proteins from cathepsins that leak out of the lysosomes.  In almost all affected individuals
column3: Unverricht-Lundborg disease is caused by an increase in size of the CSTB gene. One region of the CSTB gene has a particular repeating sequence of 12 DNA building blocks (nucleotides). This sequence is normally repeated two or three times within the gene and is called a dodecamer repeat. Most people with this disorder have more than 30 repeats of the dodecamer sequence in both copies of the CSTB gene. A small number of people with Unverricht-Lundborg disease carry other mutations.  The increased number of dodecamer repeats in the CSTB gene seems to interfere with the production of the cystatin B protein. Levels of cystatin B in affected individuals are only 5 to 10 percent of normal
column4: and cathepsin levels are significantly increased. These changes are believed to cause the signs and symptoms of Unverricht-Lundborg disease
column5: but it is unclear how a reduction in the amount of cystatin B leads to the features of this disorder.;Unverricht-Lundborg disease is a rare
column6: inherited disorder of the nervous system characterized by progressive ataxia
column7: epilepsy
column8: and cognitive decline. It is caused by mutations in the CSTB gene
column9: which encodes the protein cystatin B. Cystatin B is a protease inhibitor that plays a role in regulating the activity of cathepsins
column10: a family of proteases involved in various cellular processes. Mutations in the CSTB gene lead to either a complete loss or reduction in the activity of cystatin B
column11: resulting in an imbalance in the activity of cathepsins. This imbalance is thought to contribute to the neurodegeneration and clinical features of Unverricht-Lundborg disease.;0.029;205.0;88.0;0.281;0.117;0.175;0.753;0.191;0.12;0.26

column1: 757;gemini-pro;prevention;How to prevent Vasculitis ?;"You can't prevent vasculitis. However
column2: treatment can help prevent or delay the complications of vasculitis.

column1: People who have severe vasculitis are treated with prescription medicines. Rarely
column2: surgery may be done. People who have mild vasculitis may find relief with over-the-counter pain medicines

column1: For more information about vasculitis treatments
column2: go to ""How Is Vasculitis Treated?""";"Preventing vasculitis entirely may not be possible
column3: but there are steps you can take to reduce your risk of developing the condition or experiencing complications if you already have it:

column1: - **Avoid infections**: Minimize your exposure to infections by practicing good hygiene
column2: such as washing your hands frequently
column3: avoiding close contact with people who are sick
column4: and getting vaccinated against common infections.

column1: - **Manage chronic conditions**: If you have a chronic condition
column2: such as diabetes
column3: lupus
column4: or rheumatoid arthritis
column5: work closely with your doctor to manage the condition effectively and reduce the risk of complications.

column1: - **Healthy lifestyle**: Maintain a healthy lifestyle by eating a balanced diet
column2: getting regular exercise
column3: and avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol consumption. These measures can help boost your immune system and reduce inflammation
column4: which may lower your risk of vasculitis.

column1: - **Medications**: If you have vasculitis
column2: your doctor may prescribe medications to suppress the overactive immune response and reduce inflammation. Taking these medications as directed can help prevent complications and improve your overall health.

column1: - **Regular check-ups**: If you have a history of vasculitis or are at increased risk
column2: schedule regular check-ups with your doctor to monitor your condition and catch any potential problems early on.";0.015;60.0;188.0;0.234;0.045;0.143;0.828;-0.023;0.058;-0.104

column1: 761;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) WAGR syndrome ?;WAGR syndrome is a disorder that affects many body systems and is named for its main features: Wilms tumor
column2: anirida

column2: but often they don't cause health problems. Most people with pituitary tumors never even know they have them. Symptoms of pituitary tumors include       - Headaches     - Vision problems    - Nausea and vomiting    - Problems caused by the production of too many hormones       Pituitary tumors are usually curable. column1: 765;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose VLCAD deficiency ?;How is VLCAD deficiency diagnosed? A diagnosis of VLCAD deficiency may be suspected based on an abnormal newborn screen or the presence of characteristic signs and symptoms. In both of these cases

column3: urine

column6: and/or liver tissue. Genetic testing for changes (mutations) in the ACADVL gene can confirm the diagnosis. GeneReview's Web site offers more specific information about the diagnosis of VLCAD deficiency. Please click on the link to access this resource.;"VLCAD (Very Long-Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase) deficiency is a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the inability of the body to break down certain long-chain fatty acids. Diagnosis involves several steps:

column1: 1. **Clinical Evaluation**: Assess the patient's signs and symptoms
column2: such as recurrent episodes of muscle pain
column3: weakness
column4: fatigue
column5: hypoglycemia
column6: heart problems
column7: and liver enlargement.

column1: 2. **Laboratory Tests**:
- **Blood Tests**: Measure levels of fatty acids
column2: acylcarnitines
column3: and creatine kinase to detect abnormal patterns indicative of VLCAD deficiency.

column1: - **Genetic Testing**: Conduct genetic analysis to identify mutations in the VLCAD gene that confirm the diagnosis.
3. **Muscle Biopsy**: Take a small muscle tissue sample to analyze the activity of VLCAD enzyme and detect any abnormalities in fatty acid metabolism.
4. **Carnitine Profile**: Assess the levels of different types of carnitine in the blood to evaluate the patient's carnitine status and aid in diagnosis.

5. **Exercise Challenge Test**: Have the patient perform a controlled exercise test to assess their response to physical exertion and monitor for signs of metabolic stress indicative of VLCAD deficiency.

A combination of these diagnostic approaches helps confirm VLCAD deficiency and allows for appropriate medical management and monitoring of the condition.";0.028;88.0;176.0;0.261;0.064;0.163;0.682;0.003;0.089;-0.082

column8: or taking over-the-counter or prescription medications.;"If you're experiencing excessive gas in your digestive tract
column9: there are several strategies you can try to alleviate the discomfort:

column1: 1. **Dietary Modifications:**
- Reduce the intake of foods known to cause gas
column2: such as beans
column3: lentils
column4: cabbage
column5: and cruciferous vegetables.

column1: - Avoid carbonated drinks and sugary foods
column2: as they can release gas during digestion.

column1: - Eat smaller meals more frequently throughout the day to aid digestion and reduce bloating.
2. **Lifestyle Changes:**
- Incorporate regular physical activity into your routine
column2: as exercise can help move gas through the digestive tract.

column1: - Avoid chewing gum or sucking on hard candies
column2: as these actions can introduce air into your digestive system.

column1: - Try relaxation techniques like yoga or deep breathing to reduce stress
column2: which can contribute to gas production.

column1: 3. **Over-the-Counter Remedies:**
- Consider using over-the-counter gas relievers like simethicone or activated charcoal
column2: which can help break down and absorb gas bubbles.

column1: - Peppermint or ginger supplements may also help alleviate gas and bloating.
4. **Consult a Doctor:**
- If your gas symptoms are severe

column3: or accompanied by other digestive issues like abdominal pain
column4: nausea
column5: or diarrhea

column1: 770;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Hyperthyroidism ?;Hyperthyroidism is a disorder that occurs when the thyroid gland makes more thyroid hormone than the body needs. Hyperthyroidism is sometimes called thyrotoxicosis

column1: More on: Resources for Health Professionals: Treatment";Treatment for fascioliasis typically involves the use of antiparasitic medications such as triclabendazole or albendazole. These medications work by damaging the parasite's outer covering
column2: causing it to lose its grip on the bile ducts and be expelled from the body. In some cases

column4: supportive care measures such as pain relievers

column1: 773;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma ?;Tests that examine the lymph system are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood Hodgkin lymphoma. The following tests and procedures may be used:         -   Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health
column2: including checking for signs of disease
column3: such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual. A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.    -   CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body
column4: such as the neck
column5: chest
column6: abdomen
column7: or pelvis
column8: taken from different angles. The pictures are made by a computer linked to an x-ray machine. A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly. This procedure is also called computed tomography
column9: computerized tomography
column10: or computerized axial tomography.     -   PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body. A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein. The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body. Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do. Sometimes a PET scan and a CT scan are done at the same time. If there is any cancer
column11: this increases the chance that it will be found.    -   Chest x-ray : An x-ray of the organs and bones inside the chest. An x-ray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film
column12: making a picture of areas inside the body.    -   Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following:               - The number of red blood cells
column13: white blood cells
column14: and platelets.      - The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.      - The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.              -   Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body. An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.    -   Sedimentation rate : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the rate at which the red blood cells settle to the bottom of the test tube. The sedimentation rate is a measure of how much inflammation is in the body. A higher than normal sedimentation rate may be a sign of lymphoma. Also called erythrocyte sedimentation rate
column15: sed rate
column16: or ESR.    -   Lymph node biopsy : The removal of all or part of a lymph node. The lymph node may be removed during an image-guided CT scan or a thoracoscopy
column17: mediastinoscopy
column18: or laparoscopy. One of the following types of biopsies may be done:                -  Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lymph node.       -  Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node.      -  Core biopsy : The removal of tissue from a lymph node using a wide needle.      -  Fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue from a lymph node using a thin needle.          A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells
column19: especially Reed-Sternberg cells. Reed-Sternberg cells are common in classical Hodgkin lymphoma. The following test may be done on tissue that was removed:               -  Immunophenotyping : A laboratory test used to identify cells
column20: based on the types of antigens or markers on the surface of the cell. This test is used to diagnose the specific type of lymphoma by comparing the cancer cells to normal cells of the immune system.;Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system
column21: a network of vessels and nodes that helps fight infection. Diagnosis typically begins with a thorough medical history and physical examination
column22: including feeling for enlarged lymph nodes. Blood tests may be done to check for abnormalities in blood counts or markers associated with Hodgkin Lymphoma. Imaging tests
column23: such as CT scans or PET scans
column24: are used to identify enlarged lymph nodes or other affected areas. A biopsy
column25: involving the removal of a small tissue sample from an affected lymph node
column26: is performed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the specific subtype of Hodgkin Lymphoma. Additional tests may be done to assess the extent of the disease and plan appropriate treatment. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial for timely intervention and potentially achieving better outcomes.;0.003;527.0;126.0;0.268;0.054;0.147;0.668;-0.1;-0.266;0.074

column1: 775;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Trisomy 2 mosaicism ?;Trisomy 2 mosaicism is a rare chromosome condition caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 2 in a subset of a persons cells. Many cases of trisomy 2 mosaicism result in spontaneous abortion or miscarriage during pregnancy. In live born infants
column2: signs and symptoms vary widely but generally include poor growth of the baby while in the womb and multiple birth defects.  Trisomy 2 mosaicism may be encountered during pregnancy as a finding following chorionic villus sampling. In these situations the trisomic cells are most often confined to the placenta and the pregnancy results in a healthy infant. Further investigation is warranted however
column3: because in a small percentage of cases this finding is associated with an increased risk for intrauterine growth restriction  and oligohydramnios. Questions regarding trisomy 2 mosaicism should be discussed with a genetic professional. Click here to visit GeneTests to search for a genetics professional near you.;Trisomy 2 mosaicism is a rare chromosomal condition that occurs when some cells in the body have three copies of chromosome 2

column5: including intellectual disability

column8: and genetic counseling is recommended for affected individuals and their families.;0.046;136.0;83.0;0.255;0.058;0.191;0.783;0.138;0.042;0.235

column1: 776;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) multiple familial trichoepithelioma ?;"Multiple familial trichoepithelioma is a condition involving multiple skin tumors that develop from structures associated with the skin (skin appendages)
column2: such as hair follicles and sweat glands. People with multiple familial trichoepithelioma typically develop large numbers of smooth
column3: round tumors called trichoepitheliomas
column4: which arise from hair follicles. Trichoepitheliomas are generally noncancerous (benign) but occasionally develop into a type of skin cancer called basal cell carcinoma.  Individuals with multiple familial trichoepithelioma occasionally also develop other types of tumors
column5: including growths called spiradenomas and cylindromas. Spiradenomas develop in sweat glands. The origin of cylindromas has been unclear; while previously thought to derive from sweat glands
column6: they are now generally believed to begin in hair follicles. Affected individuals are also at increased risk of developing tumors in tissues other than skin appendages
column7: particularly benign or malignant tumors of the salivary glands.  People with multiple familial trichoepithelioma typically begin developing tumors during childhood or adolescence. The tumors mostly appear on the face
column8: especially in the folds in the skin between the nose and lips (nasolabial folds
column9: sometimes called smile lines)
column10: but may also occur on the neck
column11: scalp
column12: or trunk. They may grow larger and increase in number over time.  In severe cases
column13: the tumors may get in the way of the eyes
column14: ears
column15: nose
column16: or mouth and affect vision
column17: hearing
column18: or other functions. The growths can be disfiguring and may contribute to depression or other psychological problems. For reasons that are unclear
column19: females with multiple familial trichoepithelioma are often more severely affected than males.";Multiple familial trichoepithelioma is a rare genetic condition characterized by the appearance of multiple small
column20: benign tumors on the face
column21: scalp
column22: and neck. These tumors are typically flesh-colored or slightly pink and can range in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters. Multiple familial trichoepithelioma is usually asymptomatic
column23: but some individuals may experience mild itching or irritation. The exact cause of multiple familial trichoepithelioma is unknown
column24: but it is believed to be caused by a mutation in the CYLD gene. This mutation leads to the overproduction of a protein called cylindromatosis
column25: which is involved in cell growth and differentiation. Multiple familial trichoepithelioma is typically diagnosed based on a physical examination and a biopsy of the tumor. Treatment options may include surgical removal of the tumors

column1: 777;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy ?;How is autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy diagnosed? The diagnosis of autosomal dominant nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy (ADNFLE) is made on clinical grounds. The key to diagnosis is a detailed history from the affected person
column2: as well as witnesses. Sometimes video-EEG monitoring is necessary. column3: cognitive deficits
column4: or psychiatric disorders may occur) normal findings on neuroimaging ictal EEG (recorded during a seizure) that may be normal or obscured by movement of the cables or electrodes interictal EEG (recorded in between seizures) that shows infrequent epileptiform discharges (distinctive patterns resembling those that occur in people with epilepsy) the presence of the same disorder in other family members
column5: with evidence of autosomal dominant inheritance The diagnosis can be established in a person with the above features
column6: combined with a positive family history and/or genetic testing that detects a mutation in one of the genes known to cause ADNFLE. column7: detailed medical history

column11: including their frequency
column12: duration
column13: and associated symptoms
column14: is crucial. Neurological examination and assessment of cognitive function help identify any deficits or abnormalities. EEG recordings
column15: particularly during sleep
column16: are essential for capturing characteristic frontal lobe seizure patterns. Genetic testing plays a significant role in confirming the diagnosis by identifying mutations in specific genes
column17: such as CHRNA4
column20: associated with ADNFLE. Neuroimaging techniques

column1: 780;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Cleidocranial dysplasia ?;Cleidocranial dysplasia is a condition that primarily affects the development of the bones and teeth. Characteristic features of this condition include underdeveloped or absent collarbones (clavicles) and delayed closing of the spaces between the bones of the skull (fontanels). Individuals with cleidocranial dysplasia may also have decreased bone density (osteopenia)
column2: osteoporosis
column3: dental abnormalities
column4: hearing loss

Dental problems are addressed with several procedures. Ear and sinus infections may be treated with antibiotics and use of ear tubes. In some cases surgery is needed for the cranial defect.; Cleidocranial dysplasia
column7: also known as Marie-Sainton syndrome
column8: is a rare genetic disorder that affects the development of bones and teeth. It is characterized by the following features: delayed closure of the skull bones (craniosynostosis)

column1: 781;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Parasites - Leishmaniasis ?;Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease that is found in parts of the tropics
column2: subtropics
column3: and southern Europe. Leishmaniasis is caused by infection with Leishmania parasites

column5: which causes skin sores
column6: and visceral leishmaniasis
column7: which affects several internal organs (usually spleen
column8: liver
column9: and bone marrow).;Leishmaniasis is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies. The disease has three main clinical forms: visceral leishmaniasis (also known as kala-azar)
column10: cutaneous leishmaniasis (oriental sore)

column12: mouth

column1: 782;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to microvillus inclusion disease ?;Mutations in the MYO5B gene cause microvillus inclusion disease. The MYO5B gene provides instructions for making a protein called myosin Vb. This protein helps to determine the position of various components within cells (cell polarity). Myosin Vb also plays a role in moving components from the cell membrane to the interior of the cell for recycling.  MYO5B gene mutations that cause microvillus inclusion disease result in a decrease or absence of myosin Vb function. In cells that line the small intestine (enterocytes)
column2: a lack of myosin Vb function changes the cell polarity. As a result
column3: enterocytes cannot properly form structures called microvilli
column4: which normally project like small fingers from the surface of the cells and absorb nutrients and fluids from food as it passes through the intestine. Inside affected enterocytes
column5: small clumps of abnormal microvilli mix with misplaced digestive proteins to form microvillus inclusions
column6: which contribute to the dysfunction of enterocytes. Disorganized enterocytes with poorly formed microvilli reduce the intestine's ability to take in nutrients. The inability to absorb nutrients and fluids during digestion leads to recurrent diarrhea
column7: malnutrition
column8: and dehydration in individuals with microvillus inclusion disease.  Some people with the signs and symptoms of microvillus inclusion disease do not have mutations in the MYO5B gene. These cases may be variants of microvillus inclusion disease. Studies suggest that mutations in other genes can cause these cases
column9: but the causes are usually unknown.;Microvillus inclusion disease (MVID) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by severe chronic diarrhea and malabsorption due to the absence or dysfunction of microvilli on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. The genetic changes associated with MVID primarily involve mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in the formation and maintenance of microvilli. These mutations can affect genes responsible for microvillar actin cytoskeleton organization
column10: apical junctional complex formation
column11: and intracellular trafficking and signaling pathways. Some of the commonly identified genetic alterations include mutations in the MYO5B
column12: EPCAM
column13: STX3
column14: and SLC9A3 genes
column15: among others. These mutations can lead to impaired microvillar structure and function
column16: resulting in the clinical manifestations of MVID.;0.014;210.0;101.0;0.26;0.043;0.187;0.641;0.008;-0.017;0.031

column5: episcleritis

column8: hearing loss
column9: tinnitus) In some cases
column10: a biopsy of affected tissue may be necessary to support the diagnosis.;Relapsing polychondritis is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by recurrent inflammation of cartilage and other connective tissues in the body. Diagnosis is done through a combination of clinical evaluation
column11: imaging studies
column12: and laboratory tests. Clinical evaluation involves assessing the patient's symptoms
column13: including joint pain
column14: swelling
column15: and stiffness

column17: hoarseness

column23: imaging results

column1: 784;gemini-pro;symptoms;What are the symptoms of Sonoda syndrome ?;What are the signs and symptoms of Sonoda syndrome? The Human Phenotype Ontology provides the following list of signs and symptoms for Sonoda syndrome. If the information is available

Signs and Symptoms Approximate number of patients (when available) Abnormal dermatoglyphics 90% Abnormality of the oral cavity 90% Anteverted nares 90% Depressed nasal ridge 90% Generalized hyperpigmentation 90% Hypopigmentation of hair 90% Narrow mouth 90% Round face 90% Short nose 90% Short stature 90% Displacement of the external urethral meatus 50% Autosomal recessive inheritance - Depressed nasal bridge - High axial triradius - Intellectual disability - Ventricular septal defect - The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) has collected information on how often a sign or symptom occurs in a condition. Much of this information comes from Orphanet
column3: a European rare disease database. The frequency of a sign or symptom is usually listed as a rough estimate of the percentage of patients who have that feature. The frequency may also be listed as a fraction. The first number of the fraction is how many people had the symptom
column4: and the second number is the total number of people who were examined in one study. For example
column5: a frequency of 25/25 means that in a study of 25 people all patients were found to have that symptom. Because these frequencies are based on a specific study
column6: the fractions may be different if another group of patients are examined. Sometimes
column7: no information on frequency is available. In these cases
column8: the sign or symptom may be rare or common.;Sonoda syndrome is an extremely rare genetic disorder characterized by distinctive facial features
column9: intellectual disability
column10: speech delay

column1: 785;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Broken Heart Syndrome ?;"Even though broken heart syndrome may feel like a heart attack

column1: Diuretics (water or fluid pills)

column1: Treatment of Complications

column1: The good news is that this condition improves very quickly

column3: even the most critically ill tend to make a quick and complete recovery.

column2: medicine

column1: 787;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to mucolipidosis II alpha/beta ?;"Mutations in the GNPTAB gene cause mucolipidosis II alpha/beta. This gene provides instructions for making part of an enzyme called GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase. This enzyme helps prepare certain newly made enzymes for transport to lysosomes. Lysosomes are compartments within the cell that use digestive enzymes to break down large molecules into smaller ones that can be reused by cells. GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase is involved in the process of attaching a molecule called mannose-6-phosphate (M6P) to specific digestive enzymes. Just as luggage is tagged at the airport to direct it to the correct destination
column2: enzymes are often ""tagged"" after they are made so they get to where they are needed in the cell. M6P acts as a tag that indicates a digestive enzyme should be transported to the lysosome.  Mutations in the GNPTAB gene that cause mucolipidosis II alpha/beta prevent the production of any functional GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase. Without this enzyme
column3: digestive enzymes cannot be tagged with M6P and transported to lysosomes. Instead
column4: they end up outside the cell and have increased digestive activity. The lack of digestive enzymes within lysosomes causes large molecules to accumulate there. Conditions that cause molecules to build up inside lysosomes
column5: including mucolipidosis II alpha/beta
column6: are called lysosomal storage disorders. The signs and symptoms of mucolipidosis II alpha/beta are most likely caused by the lack of digestive enzymes within lysosomes and the effects these enzymes have outside the cell.  Mutations in the GNPTAB gene can also cause a similar but milder disorder called mucolipidosis III alpha/beta. Instead of preventing the production of any enzyme
column7: these mutations reduce the activity of GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase. Mucolipidosis III alpha/beta and mucolipidosis II alpha/beta represent two ends of a spectrum of disease severity.";Mucolipidosis II alpha/beta
column8: also known as I-cell disease
column9: is an inherited metabolic disorder caused by mutations in the GNPTAB gene. This gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase (GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase)
column10: which is involved in the breakdown of certain sugars. Mutations in the GNPTAB gene lead to a deficiency of GlcNAc-1-phosphotransferase
column11: resulting in the accumulation of undegraded sugars in cells. This accumulation can interfere with the normal function of cells
column12: leading to a range of symptoms including developmental delays
column13: skeletal abnormalities
column14: coarse facial features

column1: 799;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Chronic Myeloproliferative Neoplasms ?;"Key Points

column1: Myeloproliferative neoplasms are a group of diseases in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells
column2: white blood cells
column3: or platelets.

column1: Normally
column2: the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.     A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell. A lymphoid stem cell becomes a white blood cell. A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells:         -  Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.    - White blood cells that fight infection and disease.    -  Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.          In myeloproliferative neoplasms
column3: too many blood stem cells become one or more types of blood cells. The neoplasms usually get worse slowly as the number of extra blood cells increases.

column1: There are 6 types of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.
The type of myeloproliferative neoplasm is based on whether too many red blood cells
column2: white blood cells
column3: or platelets are being made. Sometimes the body will make too many of more than one type of blood cell
column4: but usually one type of blood cell is affected more than the others are. Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms include the following 6 types:         -  Chronic myelogenous leukemia.    -  Polycythemia vera.    -  Primary myelofibrosis (also called chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis).     -  Essential thrombocythemia.    -  Chronic neutrophilic leukemia.    -  Chronic eosinophilic leukemia.        These types are described below. Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms sometimes become acute leukemia
column5: in which too many abnormal white blood cells are made.";Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms (CMPNs) are a group of blood cancers that arise from the overproduction of myeloid cells

column1: 808;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Heart Attack ?;There are many medicines that are used to treat a heart attack. - Clot-busters or thrombolytic drugs dissolve blood clots that are blocking blood flow to the heart.  - Beta blockers decrease the workload on your heart by slowing your heart rate.  - Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors lower your blood pressure and reduce the strain on your heart.  - Nitrates
column2: such as nitroglycerin  relax blood vessels and relieve chest pain.  - Anticoagulants thin the blood and prevent clots from forming in your arteries.  - Antiplatelet medications
column3: such as aspirin and clopidogrel
column4: stop platelets from clumping together to form clots. These medications are given to people who have had a heart attack
column5: have angina
column6: or have had angioplasty. Clot-busters or thrombolytic drugs dissolve blood clots that are blocking blood flow to the heart. column1: 822;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Menkes syndrome ?;"Menkes syndrome is a disorder that affects copper levels in the body. It is characterized by sparse
column2: kinky hair; failure to gain weight and grow at the expected rate (failure to thrive); and deterioration of the nervous system. Additional signs and symptoms include weak muscle tone (hypotonia)
column3: sagging facial features
column4: seizures
column5: developmental delay
column6: and intellectual disability. Children with Menkes syndrome typically begin to develop symptoms during infancy and often do not live past age 3. Early treatment with copper may improve the prognosis in some affected individuals. In rare cases
column7: symptoms begin later in childhood.  Occipital horn syndrome (sometimes called X-linked cutis laxa) is a less severe form of Menkes syndrome that begins in early to middle childhood. It is characterized by wedge-shaped calcium deposits in a bone at the base of the skull (the occipital bone)
column8: coarse hair
column9: and loose skin and joints.";Menkes syndrome
column10: also known as Menkes kinky hair syndrome
column11: is a rare genetic disorder that primarily affects males and is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase protein
column12: and its dysfunction leads to impaired copper absorption and utilization in the body. As a result
column13: individuals with Menkes syndrome exhibit a range of symptoms
column14: including distinctive kinky hair
column15: intellectual disability
column16: seizures
column17: growth failure
column18: and connective tissue abnormalities. The condition typically presents in early infancy and is often fatal within the first decade of life due to complications such as respiratory infections and neurological deterioration. Menkes syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner
column19: meaning that it is more commonly seen in males
column20: while females can be carriers and may exhibit milder symptoms.;0.038;134.0;118.0;0.343;0.084;0.188;0.79;0.09;0.096;0.081

column1: 823;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Fetal retinoid syndrome ?;Fetal retinoid syndrome is a characteristic pattern of physical and mental birth defects that results from maternal use of retinoids during pregnancy. The most well known retinoid is isotretinoin (Accutane)
column2: a drug used to treat severe cystic acne. Birth defects associated with fetal retinoid syndrome include: hydrocephalus
column3: microcephaly
column4: intellectual disabilities
column5: ear and eye abnormalities
column6: cleft palate and other facial differences
column7: and heart defects. Isotretinoin can cause these birth defects in the early weeks of pregnancy
column8: even before a woman knows that she is pregnant.;Fetal retinoid syndrome is a group of birth defects that can occur in a baby when the mother takes a type of vitamin A medication called retinoids during pregnancy. Retinoids are often used to treat skin conditions such as acne
column9: psoriasis
column10: or wrinkles. The most common birth defects seen with fetal retinoid syndrome include distinctive facial features with an abnormally small head size
column11: cleft lip/palate
column12: heart problems
column13: and delayed physical and mental development. Retinoids can also cause hearing loss
column14: eye problems
column15: and skeletal abnormalities in the baby. It is important for women who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant to avoid taking retinoids
