column1: 826;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to sick sinus syndrome ?;Sick sinus syndrome can result from genetic or environmental factors. In many cases
column2: the cause of the condition is unknown.  Genetic changes are an uncommon cause of sick sinus syndrome. Mutations in two genes
column3: SCN5A and HCN4
column4: have been found to cause the condition in a small number of families. These genes provide instructions for making proteins called ion channels that transport positively charged atoms (ions) into cardiac cells
column5: including cells that make up the SA node. The flow of these ions is essential for creating the electrical impulses that start each heartbeat and coordinate contraction of the cardiac muscle. Mutations in these genes reduce the flow of ions
column6: which alters the SA node's ability to create and spread electrical signals. These changes lead to abnormal heartbeats and the other symptoms of sick sinus syndrome.  A particular variation in another gene
column7: MYH6
column8: appears to increase the risk of developing sick sinus syndrome. The protein produced from the MYH6 gene forms part of a larger protein called myosin
column9: which generates the mechanical force needed for cardiac muscle to contract. Researchers believe that the MYH6 gene variation changes the structure of myosin
column10: which can affect cardiac muscle contraction and increase the likelihood of developing an abnormal heartbeat.  More commonly
column11: sick sinus syndrome is caused by other factors that alter the structure or function of the SA node. These include a variety of heart conditions
column12: other disorders such as muscular dystrophy
column13: abnormal inflammation
column14: or a shortage of oxygen (hypoxia). Certain medications
column15: such as drugs given to treat abnormal heart rhythms or high blood pressure
column16: can also disrupt SA node function. One of the most common causes of sick sinus syndrome in children is trauma to the SA node
column17: such as damage that occurs during heart surgery.  In older adults
column18: sick sinus syndrome is often associated with age-related changes in the heart. Over time
column19: the SA node may harden and develop scar-like damage (fibrosis) that prevents it from working properly.;Sick sinus syndrome (SSS) is a heart rhythm disorder characterized by the inability of the sinoatrial node (SA node) to generate electrical impulses effectively
column20: leading to slow heart rate and pauses. Several genetic changes have been identified as potential causes of SSS
column21: including mutations in genes encoding ion channels
column22: such as SCN5A
column23: HCN4
column24: and KCNQ1
column25: which are involved in the generation and conduction of electrical impulses in the heart. Mutations in genes related to calcium handling
column27: have also been implicated in the development of SSS. Additionally
column28: genetic variations in genes involved in fibrosis and inflammation
column29: such as TGF-beta and IL-6
column30: have been associated with an increased risk of SSS. These genetic changes can disrupt the normal electrical properties and structure of the heart

column1: 834;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Trichomoniasis ?;Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted disease caused by a parasite. You get it through sexual intercourse with an infected partner. Many people do not have any symptoms. If you do get symptoms

column1: 836;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Kawasaki syndrome ?;"Kawasaki syndrome is a condition that involves inflammation of the blood vessels. It is typically diagnosed in young children

column1: 837;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) laryngo-onycho-cutaneous syndrome ?;"Laryngo-onycho-cutaneous (LOC) syndrome is a disorder that leads to abnormalities of the voicebox (laryngo-)
column2: finger- and toenails (onycho-)
column3: and skin (cutaneous). Many of the condition's signs and symptoms are related to the abnormal growth of granulation tissue in different parts of the body. This red

column5: in people with LOC syndrome

People with LOC syndrome can also have malformed nails and small
column11: abnormal teeth. The hard

column22: and pharmacological interventions

column1: 855;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Prostate Cancer ?;"Key Points

- Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.    - Signs of prostate cancer include a weak flow of urine or frequent urination.     - Tests that examine the prostate and blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose prostate cancer.    - Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.
Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.

The prostate is a gland in the male reproductive system. It lies just below the bladder (the organ that collects and empties urine) and in front of the rectum (the lower part of the intestine). It is about the size of a walnut and surrounds part of the urethra (the tube that empties urine from the bladder). The prostate gland makes fluid that is part of the semen.      Prostate cancer is most common in older men. In the U.S.
column2: about 1 out of 5 men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer.";Prostate cancer is a common type of cancer that affects men. It starts in the prostate gland
column3: which is located just below the bladder and in front of the rectum. The prostate gland produces fluid that helps to nourish and protect sperm. Prostate cancer occurs when cells in the prostate gland start to grow out of control. These cells can form a tumor in the prostate gland
column4: which can cause problems with urination
column5: ejaculation
column6: and sexual function. Prostate cancer can also spread to other parts of the body

column1: 858;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Pinworms ?;Pinworms are small parasites that can live in the colon and rectum. You get them when you swallow their eggs. The eggs hatch inside your intestines. While you sleep

column1: 864;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Stroke ?;There are two kinds of stroke. The most common kind of stroke is called ischemic stroke. It accounts for approximately 80 percent of all strokes. An ischemic stroke is caused by a blood clot that blocks or plugs a blood vessel in the brain. The other kind of stroke is called hemorrhagic stroke. A hemorrhagic stroke is caused by a blood vessel that breaks and bleeds into the brain.;A stroke

column3: occurs when blood supply to a part of the brain is interrupted or reduced
column4: depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. This lack of blood flow can cause brain cells to die
column5: leading to a range of symptoms depending on the location and severity of the stroke. Strokes are often classified into two main types: ischemic strokes
column6: which are caused by a blockage in an artery supplying blood to the brain
column7: and hemorrhagic strokes
column8: which are caused by a rupture or leak in a blood vessel in the brain. The symptoms of a stroke can vary widely
column9: but may include sudden weakness or numbness on one side of the body
column10: difficulty speaking or understanding speech
column11: vision problems
column12: dizziness
column13: and loss of balance or coordination. If you or someone you know experiences any of these symptoms
column14: it is essential to seek immediate medical attention
column15: as prompt treatment can help to minimize brain damage and improve outcomes.;0.031;60.0;148.0;0.265;0.053;0.191;0.641;0.113;0.264;-0.032

column1: 866;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is Norrie disease inherited ?;This condition is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. A condition is considered X-linked if the mutated gene that causes the disorder is located on the X chromosome
column2: one of the two sex chromosomes. In males (who have only one X chromosome)
column3: one altered copy of the gene in each cell is sufficient to cause the condition. In females (who have two X chromosomes)
column4: a mutation must be present in both copies of the gene to cause the disorder. Males are affected by X-linked recessive disorders much more frequently than females. A characteristic of X-linked inheritance is that fathers cannot pass X-linked traits to their sons.  In X-linked recessive inheritance
column5: a female with one altered copy of the gene in each cell is called a carrier. She can pass on the gene
column6: but generally does not experience signs and symptoms of the disorder. In rare cases
column7: however
column8: carrier females have shown some retinal abnormalities or mild hearing loss associated with Norrie disease.;Yes
column9: Norrie disease is an inherited condition caused by mutations in the NDP gene. This gene provides instructions for making a protein called norrin
column10: which is involved in the development of the eyes and ears. Mutations in the NDP gene disrupt the production or function of norrin
column11: leading to the symptoms of Norrie disease. It is typically passed down in an X-linked recessive pattern
column12: meaning that it is carried on the X chromosome and males are more commonly affected than females. In rare cases
column13: Norrie disease can be inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern
column14: meaning that both copies of the gene must be mutated to cause the condition.;0.069;145.0;95.0;0.493;0.179;0.2;0.698;0.145;0.108;0.179

868;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Neurofibromatosis ?;The mission of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) is to seek fundamental knowledge about the brain and nervous system and to use that knowledge to reduce the burden of neurological disease. column1: 871;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Benign Tumors ?;Tumors are abnormal growths in your body. They are made up of extra cells. Normally
column2: cells grow and divide to form new cells as your body needs them. When cells grow old
column3: they die
column4: and new cells take their place. Sometimes
column5: this process goes wrong. New cells form when your body does not need them
column6: and old cells do not die when they should. When these extra cells form a mass
column7: it is called a tumor.    Tumors can be either benign or malignant. Benign tumors aren't cancer. Malignant ones are. Benign tumors grow only in one place. They cannot spread or invade other parts of your body. Even so
column8: they can be dangerous if they press on vital organs
column9: such as your brain.    Treatment often involves surgery. Benign tumors usually don't grow back.    NIH: National Cancer Institute;Benign tumors are abnormal growths of cells that do not invade surrounding tissues or spread to other parts of the body. They are typically slow-growing and do not cause any symptoms unless they become large enough to press on nearby organs or tissues. Common examples of benign tumors include moles
column10: skin tags
column11: uterine fibroids
column12: and breast cysts. Treatment for benign tumors may involve surgical removal
column13: medication
column14: or observation if they are not causing any problems.;0.04;135.0;74.0;0.338;0.115;0.279;0.743;0.081;0.035;0.124

column1: 874;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Robinow syndrome ?;Is genetic testing available for Robinow syndrome? Genetic testing for autosomal recessive Robinow syndrome and autosomal dominant Robinow syndrome is available. However

column3: the cause remains unknown. Carrier testing for autosomal recessive Robinow syndrome is possible if the disease-causing mutations have been identified in an affected family member. The Genetic Testing Registry (GTR) provides information about the genetic tests for Robinow syndrome. The intended audience for the GTR is health care providers and researchers. column5: broad thumbs and big toes
column6: and distinctive facial features. A clinical diagnosis is usually made based on physical examination and characteristic clinical features. Genetic testing
column7: such as chromosomal microarray analysis or specific gene panel testing
column8: can confirm the diagnosis. Additional diagnostic tests may include X-rays to assess skeletal abnormalities

column1: 877;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is Metachromatic leukodystrophy inherited ?;"How is metachromatic leukodystrophy inherited? Metachromatic leukodystrophy is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. This means that both copies of the disease-causing gene in each cell must have a mutation for an individual to be affected. Individuals inherit two copies of each gene - one copy from each parent. Typically
column2: an individual is affected because they inherited a mutated copy of the gene from each parent. Individuals with one mutated copy of the gene (such as an unaffected parent of an affected individual) are referred to as carriers; carriers typically do not have any signs or symptoms of the condition. When two carriers of an autosomal recessive condition have children
column3: each child has a 25% (1 in 4) chance to have the condition
column4: a 50% (1 in 2) chance to be a carrier like each of the parents
column5: and a 25% chance to not have the condition and not be a carrier.";Yes
column6: metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) is an inherited disorder caused by mutations in the ARSA gene. This gene provides instructions for making an enzyme called arylsulfatase A that is involved in the breakdown of certain fats called sulfatides in the body. Without enough arylsulfatase A
column7: sulfatides accumulate in the brain and other parts of the nervous system
column8: leading to progressive damage and dysfunction. MLD is an autosomal recessive condition
column9: meaning that both copies of the ARSA gene must have mutations in order for the disorder to develop. In most cases
column10: individuals with MLD inherit one mutated copy of the ARSA gene from each parent
column11: who are both carriers of the mutation but do not have the disorder themselves.;0.09;131.0;102.0;0.478;0.171;0.391;0.661;0.101;0.148;0.053

column6: it is also possible for the condition to occur in people with no family history of the disorder

column1: 879;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Madelung disease ?;"How might Madelung disease be treated? To date
column2: the most effective treatment for Madelung disease is surgery which may include surgical excision (removal) and/or liposuction. Liposuction has gained popularity in more recent years since it results in minimal scarring. It is also considered less invasive
column3: technically easier
column4: and better suited for people with a higher surgical or anaesthetic risk. Some researchers believe it is unnecessary to subject affected people to the risks of surgery because the condition is usually benign. In their opinion
column5: surgical excision should be limited to those with airway compression or severe physical deformities. The limitations of liposuction include incomplete removal of lipomas. The main disadvantage of surgical excision is the scarring; however
column6: it offers the chance of more extensive ""debulking"" of affected areas. Reportedly
column7: it is rarely possible to remove the lipomas completely and they often recur after both of these procedures. Some researchers have reported modest success treating the condition with the medication salbutamol
column8: which increases the breakdown of fats. Abstaining from alcohol intake
column9: weight loss
column10: and correction of any associated metabolic/endocrine abnormalities are also recommended.";"Madelung disease
column11: also known as multiple symmetric lipomatosis
column12: is characterized by the accumulation of fatty deposits in various parts of the body
column13: particularly the neck
column14: shoulders
column15: and upper back. Treatment options may include:

column1: - **Conservative Management**: Lifestyle modifications like diet and exercise to reduce overall body weight and improve overall health. Regular monitoring of lipid levels and blood pressure is also important.
- **Liposuction**: A surgical procedure that involves removing excess fat deposits from affected areas. This can be done using techniques like tumescent liposuction or laser-assisted lipolysis.
- **Medications**: Some medications
column2: such as beta-blockers or alpha-blockers
column3: may be prescribed to manage symptoms like high blood pressure or anxiety. Statins may be used to lower cholesterol levels.

column1: - **Surgery**: In severe cases
column2: surgical removal of enlarged fatty deposits may be necessary. This is typically done for cosmetic reasons or to alleviate pressure on vital structures.";0.013;169.0;137.0;0.223;0.034;0.13;0.783;-0.061;-0.085;-0.04

column1: 882;gemini-pro;research;what research (or clinical trials) is being done for Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) ?;The NINDS supports a broad program of research on disorders of the nervous system
column2: including CIDP. Much of this research is aimed at increasing the understanding of these disorders and finding ways to prevent
column3: treat
column4: and cure them.;"Research efforts for Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) involve several promising avenues:

column1: 1. **Immunotherapy:** Studies are investigating the use of immunomodulatory therapies
column2: such as intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)
column3: plasmapheresis
column4: and immunosuppressive drugs
column5: to suppress the misguided immune response attacking the peripheral nerves.

column1: 2. **Biologics:** Research is exploring the potential of biologics
column2: including monoclonal antibodies and cytokines
column3: to target specific inflammatory pathways involved in CIDP. These therapies aim to modulate the immune system and reduce inflammation.

column1: 3. **Neuroprotective Agents:** Clinical trials are evaluating neuroprotective agents to protect nerve cells from damage caused by inflammation and demyelination. These agents may include antioxidants
column2: growth factors
column3: and drugs that promote nerve regeneration.

column1: 4. **Stem Cell Therapy:** Researchers are investigating the use of stem cell therapy to repair damaged nerve cells and promote remyelination. Stem cells have the potential to develop into various cell types
column2: including Schwann cells
column3: which are responsible for producing myelin.

column1: 5. **Gene Therapy:** Studies are exploring gene therapy approaches to address the underlying genetic factors contributing to CIDP. Gene therapy aims to introduce functional genes or modify faulty genes to correct the immune dysfunction.
These research directions hold promise for improving the treatment and management of CIDP
column2: potentially leading to better outcomes and enhanced quality of life for individuals affected by this condition.";0.006;34.0;201.0;0.126;0.009;0.088;0.536;-0.125;0.041;-0.283

column1: 883;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency ?;"Peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency is caused by mutations in the ACOX1 gene
column2: which provides instructions for making an enzyme called peroxisomal straight-chain acyl-CoA oxidase. This enzyme is found in sac-like cell structures (organelles) called peroxisomes
column3: which contain a variety of enzymes that break down many different substances. The peroxisomal straight-chain acyl-CoA oxidase enzyme plays a role in the breakdown of certain fat molecules called very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). Specifically
column4: it is involved in the first step of a process called the peroxisomal fatty acid beta-oxidation pathway. This process shortens the VLCFA molecules by two carbon atoms at a time until the VLCFAs are converted to a molecule called acetyl-CoA
column5: which is transported out of the peroxisomes for reuse by the cell.  ACOX1 gene mutations prevent the peroxisomal straight-chain acyl-CoA oxidase enzyme from breaking down VLCFAs efficiently. As a result
column6: these fatty acids accumulate in the body. It is unclear exactly how VLCFA accumulation leads to the specific features of peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency. However
column7: researchers suggest that the abnormal fatty acid accumulation triggers inflammation in the nervous system that leads to the breakdown of myelin
column8: which is the covering that protects nerves and promotes the efficient transmission of nerve impulses. Destruction of myelin leads to a loss of myelin-containing tissue (white matter) in the brain and spinal cord; loss of white matter is described as leukodystrophy. Leukodystrophy is likely involved in the development of the neurological abnormalities that occur in peroxisomal acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency.";"Peroxisomal Acyl-CoA oxidase deficiency (PAOX)
column9: a rare inherited disorder
column10: is characterized by mutations in the encoding gene ACOX1. This gene provides instructions for making the enzyme Acyl-CoA oxidase
column11: which is located in specialized cellular structures called ""peroxisomes"". This enzyme plays a crucial role in breaking down and metabolizing specific fatty acids known as ""very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs)"". Genetic changes in ACOX1 can lead to the production of a defective or non-functional enzyme
column12: resulting in the accumulation of VLCFAs in the body. These accumulated VLCFAs can be toxic to cells
column13: particularly those in the brain
column14: liver
column15: and muscles
column16: leading to a range of clinical manifestations
column17: including neurological problems
column19: and heart abnormalities. Understanding these genetic alterations is essential for diagnosis
column20: genetic counseling
column21: and potential development of targeted therapies for PAOX.";0.05;217.0;120.0;0.377;0.137;0.28;0.795;0.202;0.122;0.282

column1: 884;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to epidermolysis bullosa simplex ?;The four major types of epidermolysis bullosa simplex can result from mutations in either the KRT5 or KRT14 gene. These genes provide instructions for making proteins called keratin 5 and keratin 14. These tough
column2: fibrous proteins work together to provide strength and resiliency to the outer layer of the skin (the epidermis). Mutations in either the KRT5 or KRT14 gene prevent the keratin proteins from assembling into strong networks
column3: causing cells in the epidermis to become fragile and easily damaged. As a result
column4: the skin is less resistant to friction and minor trauma and blisters easily. In rare cases
column5: no KRT5 or KRT14 gene mutations are identified in people with one of the four major types of epidermolysis bullosa simplex.  Mutations in another gene
column6: PLEC
column7: have been associated with the rare Ogna type of epidermolysis bullosa simplex. The PLEC gene provides instructions for making a protein called plectin
column8: which helps attach the epidermis to underlying layers of skin. Researchers are working to determine how PLEC gene mutations lead to the major features of the condition.;Epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS) is a group of inherited skin disorders characterized by fragile skin that blisters and peels in response to minor friction or trauma. It is caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins that are essential for the structure and function of the skin. The most common type of EBS
column9: known as EBS simplex
column10: is caused by mutations in the keratin 5 (KRT5) and keratin 14 (KRT14) genes. These genes encode proteins that are components of the intermediate filaments in the skin cells
column11: which provide structural support and mechanical strength to the skin. Mutations in these genes result in the production of defective keratin proteins
column12: leading to weakened skin that is prone to blistering and erosion. Other types of EBS
column13: such as EBS Dowling-Meara and EBS Ogna
column14: are caused by mutations in other genes involved in skin structure and function
column15: such as the plectin (PLEC) and collagen type XVII (COL17A1) genes.;0.034;158.0;143.0;0.448;0.086;0.242;0.877;0.18;0.17;0.187

column1: 886;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) isolated Duane retraction syndrome ?;"Isolated Duane retraction syndrome is a disorder of eye movement. This condition prevents outward movement of the eye (toward the ear)
column2: and in some cases may also limit inward eye movement (toward the nose). As the eye moves inward
column3: the eyelids partially close and the eyeball pulls back (retracts) into its socket. Most commonly
column4: only one eye is affected. About 10 percent of people with isolated Duane retraction syndrome develop amblyopia (""lazy eye"")
column5: a condition that causes vision loss in the affected eye.  About 70 percent of all cases of Duane retraction syndrome are isolated
column6: which means they occur without other signs and symptoms. Duane retraction syndrome can also occur as part of syndromes that affect other areas of the body. For example
column7: Duane-radial ray syndrome is characterized by this eye disorder in conjunction with abnormalities of bones in the arms and hands.  Researchers have identified three forms of isolated Duane retraction syndrome
column8: designated types I
column9: II
column10: and III. The types vary in which eye movements are most severely restricted (inward
column11: outward
column12: or both). All three types are characterized by retraction of the eyeball as the eye moves inward.";Duane retraction syndrome (DRS) is a rare congenital eye movement disorder characterized by limited horizontal eye movement
column13: retraction of the eyeball into the socket
column14: and narrowing of the eyelid opening upon attempted adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose). Isolated DRS affects only one eye
column15: while bilateral DRS affects both eyes. Isolated DRS may be caused by mutations in various genes
column16: including CHN1
column17: SIX3

column1: 887;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Renal tubular acidosis with deafness ?;Renal tubular acidosis with deafness is characterized by kidney (renal) problems and sensorineural hearing loss. column4: muscular

column1: Three sets of muscles work together like a dam

column1: To urinate

column1: 907;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Congenital Heart Defects ?;"Severe congenital heart defects generally are diagnosed during pregnancy or soon after birth. Less severe defects often aren't diagnosed until children are older.
Minor defects often have no signs or symptoms. Doctors may diagnose them based on results from a physical exam and tests done for another reason.
Specialists Involved
Pediatric cardiologists are doctors who specialize in the care of babies and children who have heart problems. Cardiac surgeons are specialists who repair heart defects using surgery.
Physical Exam
During a physical exam
column2: the doctor will:

column1: Listen to your child's heart and lungs with a stethoscope
Look for signs of a heart defect
column2: such as cyanosis (a bluish tint to the skin
column3: lips
column4: or fingernails)
column5: shortness of breath
column6: rapid breathing
column7: delayed growth
column8: or signs of heart failure

column1: Diagnostic Tests
Echocardiography
Echocardiography (echo) is a painless test that uses sound waves to create a moving picture of the heart. During the test
column2: the sound waves (called ultrasound) bounce off the structures of the heart. A computer converts the sound waves into pictures on a screen.

column1: Echo allows the doctor to clearly see any problem with the way the heart is formed or the way it's working.

Echo is an important test for both diagnosing a heart problem and following the problem over time. The test can show problems with the heart's structure and how the heart is reacting to those problems. Echo will help your child's cardiologist decide if and when treatment is needed.
During pregnancy
column2: if your doctor suspects that your baby has a congenital heart defect
column3: fetal echo can be done. This test uses sound waves to create a picture of the baby's heart while the baby is still in the womb.

column1: Fetal echo usually is done at about 18 to 22 weeks of pregnancy. If your child is diagnosed with a congenital heart defect before birth
column2: your doctor can plan treatment before the baby is born.

column1: EKG (Electrocardiogram)
An EKG is a simple
column2: painless test that records the heart's electrical activity. The test shows how fast the heart is beating and its rhythm (steady or irregular). An EKG also records the strength and timing of electrical signals as they pass through the heart.

column1: An EKG can detect if one of the heart's chambers is enlarged
column2: which can help diagnose a heart problem.

column1: Chest X Ray
A chest x ray is a painless test that creates pictures of the structures in the chest
column2: such as the heart and lungs. This test can show whether the heart is enlarged. It also can show whether the lungs have extra blood flow or extra fluid
column3: a sign of heart failure.

column1: Pulse Oximetry
For this test
column2: a small sensor is attached to a finger or toe (like an adhesive bandage). The sensor gives an estimate of how much oxygen is in the blood.

column1: Cardiac Catheterization
During cardiac catheterization (KATH-e-ter-ih-ZA-shun)
column2: a thin
column3: flexible tube called a catheter is put into a vein in the arm
column4: groin (upper thigh)
column5: or neck. The tube is threaded to the heart.

column1: Special dye is injected through the catheter into a blood vessel or one of the hearts chambers. The dye allows the doctor to see blood flowing through the heart and blood vessels on an x-ray image.

The doctor also can use cardiac catheterization to measure the pressure and oxygen level inside the heart chambers and blood vessels. This can help the doctor figure out whether blood is mixing between the two sides of the heart.

Cardiac catheterization also is used to repair some heart defects.";"Congenital heart defects (CHDs) are structural abnormalities of the heart present at birth. Diagnosing CHDs involves a comprehensive approach that includes:
1. **Medical History and Physical Examination:** Detailed medical history
column2: including family history of heart defects
column3: symptoms like shortness of breath
column4: cyanosis
column5: murmurs
column6: and abnormal heart sounds during physical examination
column7: can provide initial clues.

column1: 2. **Echocardiography:** This is the primary imaging modality for CHD diagnosis. It uses ultrasound waves to produce detailed images of the heart
column2: allowing visualization of heart chambers
column3: valves
column4: and blood flow patterns.

column1: 3. **Chest X-ray:** A chest X-ray can reveal abnormal heart size
column2: shape
column3: and lung changes suggestive of CHDs.

column1: 4. **Electrocardiogram (ECG):** An ECG records the heart's electrical activity
column2: detecting abnormal heart rhythms or conduction defects associated with certain CHDs.

column1: 5. **Cardiac Catheterization:** Involves threading a thin tube into the heart to measure pressures
column2: oxygen levels
column3: and visualize heart structures. It is used for complex CHDs or when other tests are inconclusive.

column1: 6. **Fetal Echocardiography:** For suspected CHDs in utero
column2: fetal echocardiography uses ultrasound to evaluate the fetal heart during pregnancy.

column1: 7. **Pulse Oximetry:** A non-invasive test measuring blood oxygen levels can detect cyanosis (low blood oxygen) seen in some CHDs.

8. **Genetic Testing:** Genetic testing may be recommended to identify genetic syndromes or specific gene mutations associated with CHDs.";0.011;509.0;204.0;0.323;0.063;0.151;0.754;-0.015;-0.072;0.041

908;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Narcolepsy ?;"Narcolepsy is a chronic neurological disorder caused by the brain's inability to regulate sleep-wake cycles normally. At various times throughout the day
column2: people with narcolepsy experience irresistable bouts ofsleep. If the urge becomes overwhelming
column3: individuals will fall asleep for periods lasting from a few seconds to several minutes. In rare cases
column4: some people may remain asleep for an hour or longer. In addition to excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS)
column5: three other major symptoms frequently characterize narcolepsy: cataplexy
column6: or the sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone; vivid hallucinations during sleep onset or upon awakening; and brief episodes of total paralysis at the beginning or end of sleep. Narcolepsy is not definitively diagnosed in most patients until 10 to 15 years after the first symptoms appear. The cause of narcolepsy remains unknown. It is likely that narcolepsy involves multiple factors interacting to cause neurological dysfunction and sleep disturbances.";Narcolepsy is a chronic neurological disorder that affects the brain's ability to control sleep-wake cycles

column8: uncontrollable episodes of falling asleep during the day. It is characterized by an inability to maintain wakefulness
column9: often leading to sudden and irresistible sleep attacks that can occur at any time

column11: talking
column12: or driving. Narcolepsy can also cause cataplexy
column13: a sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions like laughter
column14: anger
column15: or surprise
column16: which can lead to temporary weakness or collapse. Additionally
column17: individuals with narcolepsy may experience sleep paralysis

column1: 909;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Neuroacanthocytosis ?;How might neuroacanthocytosis be treated? There is currently no cure for neuroacanthocytosis. column5: physical therapy and occupational therapy. Mechanical devices

column7: may benefit some people. Computer-assisted speech devices may be necessary in some cases. More detailed information about treatment for neuroacanthocytosis is available on eMedicine's Web site and can be viewed by clicking here.;Neuroacanthocytosis is a rare neurological disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in lipid metabolism and red blood cell shape. column1: 912;gemini-pro;causes;What causes What I need to know about My Child's Urinary Tract Infection ?;"Most UTIs are caused by bacteria that live in the bowel

column1: 914;gemini-pro;susceptibility;Who is at risk for Parasites - Cysticercosis? ?;"Cysticercosis is an infection caused by the larvae of the tapeworm
column2: Taenia solium. A person with an adult tapeworm
column3: which lives in the person’s gut
column4: sheds eggs in the stool.  The infection with the adult tapeworm is called taeniasis.  A pig then eats the eggs in the stool.  The eggs develop into larvae inside the pig and form cysts (called cysticerci) in the pig's muscles or other tissues. The infection with the cysts is called cysticercosis. Humans who eat undercooked or raw infected pork swallow the cysts in the meat. The larvae then come out of their cysts in the human gut and develop into adult tapeworms
column5: completing the cycle.

column1: People get cysticercosis when they swallow eggs that are excreted in the stool of people with the adult tapeworm. This may happen when people
- Drink water or eat food contaminated with tapeworm eggs
- Put contaminated fingers in their mouth
Cysticercosis is not spread by eating undercooked meat. However
column2: people get infected with tapeworms (taeniasis) by eating undercooked infected pork. People who have tapeworm infections can infect themselves with the eggs and develop cysticercosis (this is called autoinfection). They can also infect other people if they have poor hygiene and contaminate food or water that other people swallow. People who live with someone who has a tapeworm infection in their intestines have a much higher risk of getting cysticercosis than other people.

column1: Human cysticercosis is found worldwide

column3: where pigs roam freely and eat human feces. Taeniasis and cysticercosis are rare among persons who live in countries where pigs are not raised and in countries where pigs do not have contact with human feces. Although uncommon
column4: cysticercosis can occur in people who have never traveled outside of the United States if they are exposed to tapeworm eggs.

column1: 920;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to thiopurine S-methyltransferase deficiency ?;"TPMT deficiency results from changes in the TPMT gene. This gene provides instructions for making the TPMT enzyme

column3: these drugs are converted to toxic compounds that kill immune system cells in the bone marrow. The TPMT enzyme ""turns off"" thiopurine drugs by breaking them down into inactive
column4: nontoxic compounds. Changes in the TPMT gene reduce the stability and activity of the TPMT enzyme. Without enough of this enzyme
column5: the drugs cannot be ""turned off
column6: so they stay in the body longer and continue to destroy cells unchecked. The resulting damage to the bone marrow leads to potentially life-threatening myelosuppression.";Thiopurine S-methyltransferase (TPMT) deficiency is an inherited condition in which the body is unable to properly metabolize certain medications
column7: including thiopurine drugs such as azathioprine and mercaptopurine. This deficiency is caused by genetic variations in the TPMT gene
column8: which encodes the TPMT enzyme. Common genetic changes include single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)
column9: such as TPMT*2
column10: TPMT*3A
column11: and TPMT*3C
column12: which result in decreased or absent TPMT enzyme activity. These genetic variations can lead to an increased risk of side effects from thiopurine drugs
column13: such as bone marrow suppression and liver damage. Genetic testing for TPMT variants is recommended before starting thiopurine therapy to determine the appropriate dosage and minimize the risk of adverse reactions.;0.033;101.0;105.0;0.312;0.063;0.213;0.734;0.124;0.123;0.121

column1: 921;gemini-pro;symptoms;What are the symptoms of Abruzzo Erickson syndrome ?;What are the signs and symptoms of Abruzzo Erickson syndrome? The Human Phenotype Ontology provides the following list of signs and symptoms for Abruzzo Erickson syndrome. If the information is available

Much of this information comes from Orphanet

column5: a frequency of 25/25 means that in a study of 25 people all patients were found to have that symptom. Because these frequencies are based on a specific study
column6: the fractions may be different if another group of patients are examined. Sometimes
column7: no information on frequency is available. In these cases
column8: the sign or symptom may be rare or common.;Abruzzo Erickson Syndrome is an extremely rare inherited connective tissue disorder characterized by distinctive facial features
column9: skeletal abnormalities
column10: and intellectual disability. Individuals with this condition typically have a prominent forehead
column11: widely spaced eyes
column12: a broad nasal bridge
column13: a short nose
column14: and a small mouth. Skeletal abnormalities may include joint laxity
column15: scoliosis
column16: and pectus excavatum (sunken chest). Intellectual disability ranges from mild to severe

column1: 922;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Vitamin K;Summary : Vitamins are substances that your body needs to grow and develop normally. Vitamin K helps your body by making proteins for healthy bones and tissues. It also makes proteins for blood clotting. If you don't have enough vitamin K
column2: you may bleed too much.    Newborns have very little vitamin K. They usually get a shot of vitamin K soon after they are born.    If you take blood thinners
column3: you need to be careful about how much vitamin K you get. You also need to be careful about taking vitamin E supplements. Vitamin E can interfere with how vitamin K works in your body. Ask your health care provider for recommendations about these vitamins.    There are different types of vitamin K. Most people get vitamin K from plants such as green vegetables
column4: and dark berries. Bacteria in your intestines also produce small amounts of another type of vitamin K.;Vitamin K
column5: a fat-soluble vitamin
column6: plays a crucial role in blood clotting
column7: preventing excessive bleeding. It is found in leafy greens
column8: like spinach and kale
column9: as well as in some vegetable oils and meats. Vitamin K deficiency can lead to impaired blood clotting
column10: increasing the risk of excessive bleeding. This is especially important for individuals taking blood thinners or undergoing surgery. Maintaining adequate levels of vitamin K through diet or supplementation is essential for optimal blood clotting and overall well-being.;0.016;148.0;77.0;0.194;0.041;0.097;0.67;0.106;0.09;0.118

column1: 923;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome ?;Tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome is caused by mutations in the NOG gene
column2: which provides instructions for making a protein called noggin. This protein plays an important role in proper bone and joint development by blocking (inhibiting) signals that stimulate bone formation. The noggin protein attaches (binds) to proteins called bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs)
column3: which keeps the BMPs from triggering signals for the development of bone.  NOG gene mutations that cause tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome reduce the amount of functional noggin protein. With decreased noggin function
column4: BMPs abnormally stimulate bone formation in joint areas
column5: where there should be no bone
column6: causing the bone fusions seen in people with tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome.  Mutations in the NOG gene are involved in several disorders with overlapping signs and symptoms. Because of a shared genetic cause and overlapping features
column7: researchers have suggested that these conditions
column8: including tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome
column9: represent a spectrum of related conditions referred to as NOG-related-symphalangism spectrum disorder (NOG-SSD).;Tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the abnormal fusion of bones in the wrist and ankle joints. The exact genetic cause of the syndrome is unknown
column10: but studies have identified several genetic changes associated with the condition. These genetic changes involve mutations in genes that play a role in embryonic development
column11: particularly in the formation of the limbs. Specifically
column12: mutations in genes such as HOXD13
column13: PITX1
column14: and GDF5 have been linked to tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome. These mutations disrupt the normal signaling pathways involved in limb development
column15: leading to the abnormal fusion of bones in the wrist and ankle joints. Further research is ongoing to fully elucidate the genetic basis of tarsal-carpal coalition syndrome and to develop potential therapeutic strategies.;0.046;144.0;110.0;0.299;0.063;0.182;0.753;0.147;0.079;0.215

column1: 924;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose IgA Nephropathy ?;"A health care provider diagnoses kidney disease with
- a medical and family history  - a physical exam  - urine tests   - a blood test
Medical and Family History
Taking a medical and family history may help a health care provider diagnose kidney disease.
Physical Exam
A physical exam may help diagnose kidney disease. During a physical exam
column2: a health care provider usually

column1: - measures the patients blood pressure  - examines the patients body for swelling
Urine Tests

Dipstick test for albumin and blood. A dipstick test performed on a urine sample can detect the presence of albumin and blood. The patient provides a urine sample in a special container in a health care providers office or a commercial facility. A nurse or technician can test the sample in the same location
column2: or he or she can send it to a lab for analysis. The test involves placing a strip of chemically treated paper
column3: called a dipstick
column4: into the patients urine sample. Patches on the dipstick change color when albumin or blood is present in urine.

column1: Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio. A health care provider uses this measurement
column2: which compares the amount of albumin with the amount of creatinine in a urine sample
column3: to estimate 24-hour albumin excretion. A patient may have chronic kidney disease if the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is greater than 30 milligrams (mg) of albumin for each gram (g) of creatinine (30 mg/g). This measurement is also called UACR.

column1: Blood Test

A blood test involves having blood drawn at a health care providers office or a commercial facility and sending the sample to a lab for analysis. A health care provider may order a blood test to estimate how much blood a patients kidneys filter each minutea measurement called the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). Depending on the results
column2: the test can indicate the following:

column1: - eGFR of 60 or above is in the normal range  - eGFR below 60 may indicate kidney disease  - eGFR of 15 or below may indicate kidney failure";"IgA nephropathy is typically diagnosed through a combination of tests
column2: including:

column1: - Urinalysis: This test analyzes a sample of urine for the presence of red blood cells
column2: protein
column3: white blood cells
column4: and casts (cylinders of protein and cellular material).

column1: - Blood tests: These tests measure serum creatinine and IgA levels
column2: as well as assess kidney function and rule out other conditions.

column1: - Kidney biopsy: This procedure involves taking a small sample of kidney tissue for examination under a microscope. It is the definitive test for diagnosing IgA nephropathy and can help determine the extent of kidney damage.";0.002;279.0;87.0;0.195;0.013;0.13;0.502;-0.102;-0.211;0.008
925;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Cant syndrome ?;"Cant syndrome is a rare condition characterized by excess hair growth (hypertrichosis)
column2: a distinctive facial appearance
column3: heart defects
column4: and several other abnormalities. The features of the disorder vary among affected individuals.  People with Cant syndrome have thick scalp hair that extends onto the forehead and grows down onto the cheeks in front of the ears. They also have increased body hair
column5: especially on the back
column6: arms
column7: and legs. Most affected individuals have a large head (macrocephaly) and distinctive facial features that are described as ""coarse."" These include a broad nasal bridge
column8: skin folds covering the inner corner of the eyes (epicanthal folds)
column9: and a wide mouth with full lips. As affected individuals get older
column10: the face lengthens
column11: the chin becomes more prominent
column12: and the eyes become deep-set.  Many infants with Cant syndrome are born with a heart defect such as an enlarged heart (cardiomegaly) or patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). The ductus arteriosus is a connection between two major arteries
column13: the aorta and the pulmonary artery. This connection is open during fetal development and normally closes shortly after birth. However
column14: the ductus arteriosus remains open
column15: or patent
column16: in babies with PDA. Other heart problems have also been found in people with Cant syndrome
column17: including an abnormal buildup of fluid around the heart (pericardial effusion) and high blood pressure in the blood vessels that carry blood from the heart to the lungs (pulmonary hypertension).  Additional features of this condition include distinctive skeletal abnormalities
column18: a large body size (macrosomia) at birth
column19: a reduced amount of fat under the skin (subcutaneous fat) beginning in childhood
column20: deep horizontal creases in the palms of the hands and soles of the feet
column21: and an increased susceptibility to respiratory infections. Other signs and symptoms that have been reported include abnormal swelling in the body's tissues (lymphedema)
column22: side-to-side curvature of the spine (scoliosis)
column23: and reduced bone density (osteopenia). Some affected children have weak muscle tone (hypotonia) that delays the development of motor skills such as sitting
column24: standing
column25: and walking. Most have mildly delayed speech
column26: and some affected children have mild intellectual disability or learning problems.";Cant syndrome is a rare congenital disorder characterized by the association of multiple anomalies and distinctive facial features. The facial features include a broad and prominent forehead
column28: short palpebral fissures (narrow eye openings)
column29: a broad nasal bridge with a depressed nasal tip
column30: a long philtrum (the vertical groove between the nose and upper lip)
column31: and a thin upper lip. Additional features may include intellectual disability
column32: seizures
column33: heart defects
column35: and skeletal anomalies. The exact cause of Cant syndrome is unknown
column36: but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.;0.008;308.0;88.0;0.224;0.07;0.154;0.802;-0.06;-0.226;0.115

column1: 926;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets ?;Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets is a disorder related to low levels of phosphate in the blood (hypophosphatemia). Phosphate is a mineral that is essential for the normal formation of bones and teeth.  In most cases
column2: the signs and symptoms of hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets begin in early childhood. The features of the disorder vary widely
column3: even among affected members of the same family. Mildly affected individuals may have hypophosphatemia without other signs and symptoms. More severely affected children experience slow growth and are shorter than their peers. They develop bone abnormalities that can interfere with movement and cause bone pain. The most noticeable of these abnormalities are bowed legs or knock knees (a condition in which the lower legs are positioned at an outward angle). These abnormalities become apparent with weight-bearing activities such as walking. If untreated
column4: they tend to worsen with time.  Other signs and symptoms of hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets can include premature fusion of the skull bones (craniosynostosis) and dental abnormalities. The disorder may also cause abnormal bone growth where ligaments and tendons attach to joints (enthesopathy). In adults
column5: hypophosphatemia is characterized by a softening of the bones known as osteomalacia.  Researchers have described several forms of hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets
column6: which are distinguished by their pattern of inheritance and genetic cause. The most common form of the disorder is known as X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH). It has an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance. X-linked recessive
column7: autosomal dominant
column8: and autosomal recessive forms of the disorder are much rarer. The different inheritance patterns are described below.  Another rare type of the disorder is known as hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria (HHRH). In addition to hypophosphatemia
column9: this condition is characterized by the excretion of high levels of calcium in the urine (hypercalciuria).;Hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets (HHR) is a rare inherited disorder that affects the way the body absorbs and uses phosphorus
column10: leading to soft and weakened bones (rickets) and other health problems. It is caused by mutations in genes involved in the regulation of phosphate homeostasis
column11: such as SLC34A3
column12: PHEX
column13: CLCN5
column14: and DENT1
column15: resulting in impaired phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule of the kidneys and excessive urinary phosphate loss. This leads to low levels of phosphate in the blood (hypophosphatemia)
column16: which disrupts normal bone mineralization and growth. HHR can manifest in various forms
column17: including vitamin D-dependent rickets
column20: each with distinct genetic and clinical features.;0.026;265.0;103.0;0.314;0.072;0.152;0.863;0.041;-0.027;0.108

column1: 927;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Dry Mouth ?;Dry mouth is the feeling that there is not enough saliva in the mouth. Everyone has dry mouth once in a while -- if they are nervous
column2: upset
column3: under stress
column4: or taking certain medications. But if you have dry mouth all or most of the time
column5: see a dentist or physician. Many older adults have dry mouth
column6: but it is not a normal part of aging. (Watch the video to learn more about dry mouth. To enlarge the video
column7: click the brackets in the lower right-hand corner. To reduce the video
column8: press the Escape (Esc) button on your keyboard.) Why Saliva is Important Saliva does more than keep your mouth wet. It protects teeth from decay
column9: helps heal sores in your mouth
column10: and prevents infection by controlling bacteria
column11: viruses
column12: and fungi in the mouth. Saliva helps digest food and helps us chew and swallow. Saliva is involved in taste perception as well. Each of these functions of saliva is hampered when a person has dry mouth. How Dry Mouth Feels Dry mouth can be uncomfortable. Some people notice a sticky
column13: dry feeling in the mouth. Others notice a burning feeling or difficulty while eating. The throat may feel dry
column14: too
column15: making swallowing difficult and choking common. Also
column16: people with dry mouth may get mouth sores
column17: cracked lips
column20: also known as xerostomia
column21: is a condition in which the salivary glands in the mouth do not produce enough saliva to keep the mouth moist. Saliva helps to break down food
column22: clean the mouth
column23: and protect the teeth from decay. When the mouth is dry
column24: it can cause a number of problems
column25: including difficulty speaking
column28: as well as an increased risk of cavities and gum disease. Dry mouth can be caused by a number of factors
column29: including certain medications
column30: medical conditions

column1: 934;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Phenylketonuria ?;Phenylketonuria (PKU) is a genetic disorder in which the body can't process part of a protein called phenylalanine (Phe). Phe is in almost all foods. If the Phe level gets too high
column2: it can damage the brain and cause severe intellectual disability. All babies born in U.S. hospitals must now have a screening test for PKU. This makes it easier to diagnose and treat the problem early.     The best treatment for PKU is a diet of low-protein foods. There are special formulas for newborns. For older children and adults
column3: the diet includes many fruits and vegetables. It also includes some low-protein breads
column4: pastas and cereals. Nutritional formulas provide the vitamins and minerals they can't get from their food.    Babies who get on this special diet soon after they are born develop normally. Many have no symptoms of PKU. It is important that they stay on the diet for the rest of their lives.    NIH: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development;Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the body's inability to properly break down the amino acid phenylalanine. This leads to a build-up of phenylalanine in the blood and can cause severe intellectual disability
column5: seizures
column6: behavioral problems
column7: and other health issues if left untreated. Treatment involves following a strict diet low in phenylalanine and regular monitoring of phenylalanine levels in the blood. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications and ensure optimal outcomes.;0.021;149.0;70.0;0.268;0.047;0.191;0.815;0.121;-0.025;0.272

column17: and emotional well-being are key factors in promoting healthy aging. By understanding these health aspects and implementing appropriate interventions

column1: 939;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Marfan Syndrome ?;"Marfan syndrome has no cure. However
column2: treatments can help delay or prevent complications
column3: especially when started early.

column1: Marfan syndrome can affect many parts of your body
column2: including your heart
column3: bones and joints
column4: eyes
column5: nervous system
column6: and lungs. The type of treatment you receive will depend on your signs and symptoms.

column1: Heart Treatments
Aortic dilation
column2: or aortic aneurysm
column3: is the most common and serious heart problem linked to Marfan syndrome. In this condition
column4: the aortathe main artery that carries oxygen-rich blood to your bodystretches and grows weak.

column1: Medicines are used to try to slow the rate of aortic dilation. Surgery is used to replace the dilated segment of aorta before it tears.
If you have Marfan syndrome
column2: you'll need routine care and tests to check your heart valves and aorta.

column1: Medicines
Beta blockers are medicines that help your heart beat slower and with less force. These medicines may help relieve strain on your aorta and slow the rate of aortic dilation.
Some people have side effects from beta blockers
column2: such as tiredness and nausea (feeling sick to your stomach). If side effects occur
column3: your doctor may prescribe a calcium channel blocker or ACE inhibitor instead of a beta blocker. Both medicines help relieve stress on the aorta.

column1: Studies suggest that blocking a protein called TGF-beta may help prevent some of the effects of Marfan syndrome. Research shows that the medicine losartan may block the protein in other conditions.
The National Heart
column2: Lung
column3: and Blood Institute currently is sponsoring a study comparing losartan to a beta blocker in children and adults who have Marfan syndrome. The study's goal is to find out which medicine
column4: if either
column5: is best at slowing the rate of aortic dilation.

column1: Surgery
If your aorta stretches
column2: it's more likely to tear (a condition called aortic dissection). To prevent this
column3: your doctor may recommend surgery to repair or replace part of your aorta.

column1: Surgery may involve:
A composite valve graft. For this surgery
column2: part of the aorta and the aortic valve are removed. The aorta is replaced with a man-made tube called a graft. A man-made valve replaces the original valve.

column1: Aortic valve-sparing surgery. If your aortic valve is working well
column2: your doctor may recommend valve-sparing surgery. For this surgery
column3: your doctor replaces the enlarged part of your aorta with a graft. Your aortic valve is left in place.

column1: After aortic surgery
column2: you may need medicines or followup tests. For example
column3: after a composite valve graft
column4: your doctor will prescribe medicines called anticoagulants
column5: or ""blood thinners.""

column1: Blood thinners help prevent blood clots from forming on your man-made aortic valve. You'll need to take these medicines for the rest of your life. If you've had valve-sparing surgery
column2: you'll only need to take blood thinners for a short time
column3: as your doctor prescribes.

column1: If you've had a composite valve graft
column2: you're at increased risk for endocarditis (EN-do-kar-DI-tis). This is an infection of the inner lining of your heart chambers and valves. Your doctor may recommend that you take antibiotics before certain medical or dental procedures that increase your risk of endocarditis.

column1: Your doctor also may advise you to continue taking beta blockers or other medicines after either type of aortic surgery.
After surgery
column2: you may have routine cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or cardiac computed tomography (CT) scans to check your aorta.

column1: Cardiac MRI is a painless test that uses radio waves and magnets to created detailed pictures of your organs and tissues. Cardiac CT is a painless test that uses an x-ray machine to take clear
column2: detailed pictures of your heart.

column1: Bone and Joint Treatments
If you have scoliosis (a curved spine)
column2: your doctor may suggest a brace or other device to prevent the condition from getting worse. Severe cases of scoliosis may require surgery.

column1: Some people who have Marfan syndrome need surgery to repair a chest that sinks in or sticks out. This surgery is done to prevent the chest from pressing on the lungs and heart.
Eye Treatments
Marfan syndrome can lead to many eye problems
column2: such as a dislocated lens
column3: nearsightedness
column4: early glaucoma (high pressure in the fluid in the eyes)
column5: and cataracts (clouding of an eye's lens).

column1: Glasses or contact lenses can help with some of these problems. Sometimes surgery is needed.
Nervous System Treatments
Marfan syndrome can lead to dural ectasia. In this condition
column2: a substance called the dura (which covers the fluid around your brain and spinal cord) stretches and grows weak. This can cause the bones of the spine to wear away. Dural ectasia usually is treated with pain medicines.

column1: Lung Treatments
Marfan syndrome may cause pneumothorax
column2: or collapsed lung. In this condition
column3: air or gas builds up in the space between the lungs and the chest wall.

column1: If the condition is minor
column2: it may go away on its own. However
column3: you may need to have a tube placed through your skin and chest wall to remove the air. Sometimes surgery is needed.";Treatment for Marfan syndrome is focused on managing the specific manifestations of the disorder. Medications such as beta-blockers or angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors may be prescribed to reduce strain on the heart and prevent aortic dissection. Surgery may be necessary to repair or replace the aortic valve or ascending aorta if they become enlarged or weakened. Regular monitoring and follow-up with a cardiologist and other specialists is essential to ensure early detection and treatment of any complications. Genetic counseling can be beneficial for individuals with Marfan syndrome and their families to understand the inheritance pattern and recurrence risks. Lifestyle modifications
column4: such as avoiding strenuous physical activity and maintaining a healthy diet

column1: 941;gemini-pro;causes;What causes Systemic scleroderma ?;"What causes systemic scleroderma? The exact
column2: underlying cause of systemic sclerosis is unknown. The cause appears to involve some injury to the cells that line blood vessels
column3: resulting in excessive activation of dermal connective tissue cells
column4: called fibroblasts. Fibroblasts normally produce collagen and other proteins. Build-up of collagen in the skin and other organs causes the signs and symptoms of the condition. It is suspected that scleroderma may develop from a variety of factors
column5: which may include: Abnormal immune or inflammatory activity Genetic susceptibility: while no specific genes are thought to cause scleroderma
column6: certain genes (or combination of genes) may increase a person's risk to be affected. However
column7: the condition is not passed directly from parents to children. Environmental triggers: suspected triggers may include infections; injury; drugs (e.g. vitamin K
column8: cocaine
column9: penicillamine
column10: appetite suppressants and some chemotherapeutic agents); and chemicals (e.g. silica
column11: organic solvents
column12: pesticides
column13: aliphatic hydrocarbons and epoxy resin). Hormones: because women develop scleroderma more often than men
column14: researchers suspect that hormones may play a role. However
column15: the role of female hormones has not been proven. Widespread scleroderma can also occur in association with other autoimmune diseases
column16: including systemic lupus erythematosus and polymyositis.";Systemic scleroderma
column17: also known as systemic sclerosis
column18: is an autoimmune disease that causes the overproduction of collagen in the body. This results in the hardening and thickening of the skin

column20: heart
column21: kidneys
column22: and digestive system. The exact cause of systemic scleroderma is unknown
column23: but genetic
column24: environmental

column28: abnormalities in the immune system lead to the production of autoantibodies

column1: 943;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) IRAK-4 deficiency ?;IRAK-4 deficiency is an inherited disorder of the immune system (primary immunodeficiency). This immunodeficiency leads to recurrent infections by a subset of bacteria known as pyogenic bacteria but not by other infectious agents. (Infection with pyogenic bacteria causes the production of pus.) The most common infections in IRAK-4 deficiency are caused by the Streptococcus pneumoniae
column2: Staphylococcus aureus
column3: and Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteria. Most people with this condition have their first bacterial infection before age 2
column4: and the infections can be life-threatening in infancy and childhood. Infections become less frequent with age.  Most people with IRAK-4 deficiency have invasive bacterial infections
column5: which can involve the blood (septicemia)
column6: the membrane covering the brain and spinal cord (meningitis)
column7: or the joints (leading to inflammation and arthritis). Invasive infections can also cause areas of tissue breakdown and pus production (abscesses) on internal organs. In addition
column8: affected individuals can have localized infections of the upper respiratory tract
column9: skin
column10: or eyes. Although fever is a common reaction to bacterial infections
column11: many people with IRAK-4 deficiency do not at first develop a high fever in response to these infections
column12: even if the infection is severe.;IRAK-4 deficiency is a rare genetic disorder characterized by an impaired immune response

column14: which encodes a protein crucial for signaling pathways involved in the activation of innate immune responses. Individuals with IRAK-4 deficiency often experience recurrent and severe infections

column1: 944;gemini-pro;considerations;What to do for Medullary Sponge Kidney ?;"The following changes in diet may help prevent UTIs and kidney stone formation:

- Drinking plenty of water and other liquids can help flush bacteria from the urinary tract and dilute urine so kidney stones cannot form. A person should drink enough liquid to produce about 2 to 2.5 quarts of urine every day.3  - Reducing sodium intake
column2: mostly from salt
column3: may help prevent kidney stones. Diets high in sodium can increase the excretion of calcium into the urine and thus increase the chance of calciumcontaining kidney stones forming.  - Foods rich in animal proteins such as meat
column4: eggs
column5: and fish can increase the chance of uric acid stones and calcium stones forming. People who form stones should limit their meat consumption to 6 to 8 ounces a day.4  - People who are more likely to develop calcium oxalate stones should include 1
column6: 000 milligrams of calcium in their diet every day. Adults older than 50 years should consume 1
column7: 200 milligrams of calcium daily.3 Calcium in the digestive tract binds to oxalate from food and keeps it from entering the blood and the urinary tract
column8: where it can form stones.

column1: 946;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Diabetes
column2: Heart Disease
column3: and Stroke ?;"Two major types of heart and blood vessel disease
column4: also called cardiovascular disease
column5: are common in people with diabetes: coronary artery disease (CAD) and cerebral vascular disease. People with diabetes are also at risk for heart failure. Narrowing or blockage of the blood vessels in the legs
column6: a condition called peripheral arterial disease
column7: can also occur in people with diabetes.

column1: Coronary Artery Disease
Coronary artery disease
column2: also called ischemic heart disease
column3: is caused by a hardening or thickening of the walls of the blood vessels that go to your heart. Your blood supplies oxygen and other materials your heart needs for normal functioning. If the blood vessels to your heart become narrowed or blocked by fatty deposits
column4: the blood supply is reduced or cut off
column5: resulting in a heart attack.

column1: Cerebral Vascular Disease
Cerebral vascular disease affects blood flow to the brain
column2: leading to strokes and TIAs. It is caused by narrowing
column3: blocking
column4: or hardening of the blood vessels that go to the brain or by high blood pressure.

column1: Stroke
A stroke results when the blood supply to the brain is suddenly cut off
column2: which can occur when a blood vessel in the brain or neck is blocked or bursts. Brain cells are then deprived of oxygen and die. A stroke can result in problems with speech or vision or can cause weakness or paralysis. Most strokes are caused by fatty deposits or blood clotsjelly-like clumps of blood cellsthat narrow or block one of the blood vessels in the brain or neck. A blood clot may stay where it formed or can travel within the body. People with diabetes are at increased risk for strokes caused by blood clots.

column1: A stroke may also be caused by a bleeding blood vessel in the brain. Called an aneurysm
column2: a break in a blood vessel can occur as a result of high blood pressure or a weak spot in a blood vessel wall.

column1: TIAs
TIAs are caused by a temporary blockage of a blood vessel to the brain. This blockage leads to a brief
column2: sudden change in brain function
column3: such as temporary numbness or weakness on one side of the body. Sudden changes in brain function also can lead to loss of balance
column4: confusion
column5: blindness in one or both eyes
column6: double vision
column7: difficulty speaking
column8: or a severe headache. However
column9: most symptoms disappear quickly and permanent damage is unlikely. If symptoms do not resolve in a few minutes
column10: rather than a TIA
column11: the event could be a stroke. The occurrence of a TIA means that a person is at risk for a stroke sometime in the future. See page 3 for more information on risk factors for stroke.

column1: Heart Failure
Heart failure is a chronic condition in which the heart cannot pump blood properlyit does not mean that the heart suddenly stops working. Heart failure develops over a period of years
column2: and symptoms can get worse over time. People with diabetes have at least twice the risk of heart failure as other people. One type of heart failure is congestive heart failure
column3: in which fluid builds up inside body tissues. If the buildup is in the lungs
column4: breathing becomes difficult.

column1: Blockage of the blood vessels and high blood glucose levels also can damage heart muscle and cause irregular heart beats. People with damage to heart muscle
column2: a condition called cardiomyopathy
column3: may have no symptoms in the early stages
column4: but later they may experience weakness
column5: shortness of breath
column6: a severe cough
column7: fatigue
column8: and swelling of the legs and feet. Diabetes can also interfere with pain signals normally carried by the nerves
column9: explaining why a person with diabetes may not experience the typical warning signs of a heart attack.

column1: Peripheral Arterial Disease
Another condition related to heart disease and common in people with diabetes is peripheral arterial disease (PAD). With this condition
column2: the blood vessels in the legs are narrowed or blocked by fatty deposits
column3: decreasing blood flow to the legs and feet. PAD increases the chances of a heart attack or stroke occurring. Poor circulation in the legs and feet also raises the risk of amputation. Sometimes people with PAD develop pain in the calf or other parts of the leg when walking
column4: which is relieved by resting for a few minutes.";Diabetes
column5: heart disease
column6: and stroke are all serious medical conditions that can have a significant impact on your health and well-being. Diabetes is a chronic condition in which the body cannot properly produce or use insulin
column7: leading to high blood sugar levels. Heart disease encompasses a range of conditions that affect the heart and blood vessels
column8: including coronary artery disease
column9: heart attack
column10: and heart failure. Stroke occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted
column11: depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. These conditions share common risk factors such as high blood pressure
column12: high cholesterol
column13: obesity
column14: and physical inactivity. Managing these risk factors and making healthy lifestyle choices can help reduce your chances of developing or experiencing complications from diabetes
column15: heart disease

column1: 947;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Liver Function Tests;Summary : Your liver helps your body digest food

column3: and remove poisons. Liver function tests are blood tests that check to see how well your liver is working. They check for liver damage

column7: enzymes
column8: and substances

column16: which measures how long it takes for your blood to clot. Prothrombin is made by the liver.;Liver function tests (LFTs) are a panel of blood tests used to assess the health of the liver. LFTs can detect liver damage

column21: bilirubin

column23: and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). Elevated levels of ALT

column1: 949;gemini-pro;exams and tests;How to diagnose Parasites - Baylisascaris infection ?;"If you suspect you have been infected

column1: 951;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Foot Drop ?;"Foot drop describes the inability to raise the front part of the foot due to weakness or paralysis of the muscles that lift the foot. As a result

column1: 952;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to neurofibromatosis type 1 ?;Mutations in the NF1 gene cause neurofibromatosis type 1.  The NF1 gene provides instructions for making a protein called neurofibromin. This protein is produced in many cells

column3: which means that it keeps cells from growing and dividing too rapidly or in an uncontrolled way. Mutations in the NF1 gene lead to the production of a nonfunctional version of neurofibromin that cannot regulate cell growth and division. As a result
column4: tumors such as neurofibromas can form along nerves throughout the body. It is unclear how mutations in the NF1 gene lead to the other features of neurofibromatosis type 1
column5: such as caf-au-lait spots and learning disabilities.;Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 gene
column6: which encodes neurofibromin
column7: a protein that functions as a tumor suppressor. Mutations in the NF1 gene result in the production of either a non-functional or partially functional neurofibromin protein
column8: leading to the development of various clinical features associated with NF1. These include the formation of multiple benign tumors called neurofibromas
column9: which can grow on nerve tissue throughout the body
column10: pigmented skin lesions known as café-au-lait spots
column11: distinctive bony abnormalities
column12: and an increased risk of developing certain types of cancer

column1: 953;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Lafora progressive myoclonus epilepsy ?;Lafora progressive myoclonus epilepsy can be caused by mutations in either the EPM2A gene or the NHLRC1 gene. column2: respectively. Laforin and malin play a critical role in the survival of nerve cells (neurons) in the brain.  Studies suggest that laforin and malin work together and may have several functions. One of these is to help regulate the production of a complex sugar called glycogen
column3: which is a major source of stored energy in the body. The body stores this sugar in the liver and muscles
column4: breaking it down when it is needed for fuel. Laforin and malin may prevent a potentially damaging buildup of glycogen in tissues that do not normally store this molecule
column5: such as those of the nervous system.  Researchers have discovered that people with Lafora progressive myoclonus epilepsy have distinctive clumps called Lafora bodies within their cells. Lafora bodies are made up of an abnormal form of glycogen that cannot be broken down and used for fuel. Instead

column8: while NHLRC1 gene mutations prevent the production of functional malin. It is unclear how a loss of either of these proteins leads to the formation of Lafora bodies. However

column10: which interferes with the brain's normal functions. The condition tends to progress more slowly in some people with NHLRC1 gene mutations than in those with EPM2A gene mutations. column12: myoclonus

column16: accounting for approximately 60% of cases. Mutations in NHLRC1
column17: which encodes the malin protein

column20: in neurons and other cell types

column1: 955;gemini-pro;information;Do you have information about Caregivers;"Summary : Caregivers provide help to another person in need. column1: 960;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is X-linked infantile spasm syndrome inherited ?;X-linked infantile spasm syndrome can have different inheritance patterns depending on the genetic cause.  When caused by mutations in the ARX gene

column3: which is one of the two sex chromosomes. In males (who have only one X chromosome)

column11: such that each X chromosome is active in about half of the body cells. Sometimes X-inactivation is not random
column12: and one X chromosome is active in more than half of cells. When X-inactivation does not occur randomly
column13: it is called skewed X-inactivation. Some ARX gene mutations may be associated with skewed X-inactivation
column14: which results in the inactivation of the X chromosome with the normal copy of the ARX gene in most cells of the body. This skewed X-inactivation causes the chromosome with the mutated ARX gene to be expressed in more than half of cells

column16: this condition is thought to have an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern. The CDKL5 gene is also located on the X chromosome

column19: so more females are diagnosed with the condition. In females

column1: 961;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) autosomal recessive congenital methemoglobinemia ?;"Autosomal recessive congenital methemoglobinemia is an inherited condition that mainly affects the function of red blood cells. Specifically
