column1: 964;gemini-pro;stages;What are the stages of Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors ?;"Key Points
- After ovarian low malignant potential tumor has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if abnormal cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body.    - The following stages are used for ovarian low malignant potential tumor:          - Stage I     - Stage II     - Stage III     - Stage IV

column1: After ovarian low malignant potential tumor has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if abnormal cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body.

column1: The process used to find out whether abnormal cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body is called staging. The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease. It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment. Certain tests or procedures are used for staging. Staging laparotomy (a surgical incision made in the wall of the abdomen to remove ovarian tissue) may be used. Most patients are diagnosed with stage I disease.
The following stages are used for ovarian low malignant potential tumor:
Stage I    In stage I

column1: 966;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome ?;"Atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome often results from a combination of environmental and genetic factors. Mutations in at least seven genes appear to increase the risk of developing the disorder. Mutations in a gene called CFH are most common; they have been found in about 30 percent of all cases of atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome. Mutations in the other genes have each been identified in a smaller percentage of cases.  The genes associated with atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome provide instructions for making proteins involved in a part of the body's immune response known as the complement system. This system is a group of proteins that work together to destroy foreign invaders (such as bacteria and viruses)
column2: trigger inflammation
column3: and remove debris from cells and tissues. The complement system must be carefully regulated so it targets only unwanted materials and does not attack the body's healthy cells. The regulatory proteins associated with atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome protect healthy cells by preventing activation of the complement system when it is not needed.  Mutations in the genes associated with atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome lead to uncontrolled activation of the complement system. The overactive system attacks cells that line blood vessels in the kidneys
column4: causing inflammation and the formation of abnormal clots. These abnormalities lead to kidney damage and
column5: in many cases
column6: kidney failure and ESRD.  Although gene mutations increase the risk of atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome
column7: studies suggest that they are often not sufficient to cause the disease. In people with certain genetic changes
column8: the signs and symptoms of the disorder may be triggered by factors including certain medications (such as anticancer drugs)
column9: chronic diseases
column10: viral or bacterial infections
column11: cancers
column12: organ transplantation
column13: or pregnancy.  Some people with atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome do not have any known genetic changes or environmental triggers for the disease. In these cases
column14: the disorder is described as idiopathic.";Atypical hemolytic-uremic syndrome (aHUS) is a rare
column15: life-threatening disorder characterized by the destruction of red blood cells
column16: low platelet count
column17: and kidney failure. It is caused by genetic mutations that impair the regulation of the complement system
column18: a part of the immune system that helps the body fight infection. The most common genetic changes associated with aHUS are mutations in the genes encoding complement factor H (CFH)
column20: membrane cofactor protein (MCP)

column1: 987;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for PDGFRB-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia ?;These resources address the diagnosis or management of PDGFRB-associated chronic eosinophilic leukemia:  - Cancer.Net: Leukemia--Eosinophilic: Treatment  - Genetic Testing Registry: Myeloproliferative disorder

column2: leading to a reduction in the number of eosinophils and improvement in symptoms.

column1: 2. Dasatinib: Another tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is also effective in reducing eosinophil counts and improving symptoms in patients with PDGFRB-associated CEL.
3. Nilotinib: A third-generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor that is sometimes used in patients who do not respond to imatinib or dasatinib.

column1: 988;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to vitiligo ?;Variations in over 30 genes
column2: occurring in different combinations
column3: have been associated with an increased risk of developing vitiligo. Two of these genes are NLRP1 and PTPN22. The NLRP1 gene provides instructions for making a protein that is involved in the immune system
column4: helping to regulate the process of inflammation. Inflammation occurs when the immune system sends signaling molecules and white blood cells to a site of injury or disease to fight microbial invaders and facilitate tissue repair. The body then stops (inhibits) the inflammatory response to prevent damage to its own cells and tissues.  The PTPN22 gene provides instructions for making a protein involved in signaling that helps control the activity of immune system cells called T cells. T cells identify foreign substances and defend the body against infection.  The variations in the NLRP1 and PTPN22 genes that are associated with an increased risk of developing vitiligo likely affect the activity of the NLRP1 and PTPN22 proteins
column5: making it more difficult for the body to control inflammation and prevent the immune system from attacking its own tissues.  Studies indicate that variations in a number of other genes also affect the risk of vitiligo. Many of these genes are also involved in immune system function or melanocyte biology
column6: and variations in each likely make only a small contribution to vitiligo risk. Some of the gene changes associated with an increased risk of vitiligo have also been associated with an increased risk of other autoimmune conditions.  It is unclear what specific circumstances trigger the immune system to attack melanocytes in the skin. Research suggests that the immune system of affected individuals may react abnormally to melanocytes that are stressed by factors such as chemicals or ultraviolet radiation. In addition
column7: the melanocytes of people with vitiligo may be more susceptible to stress than those of the general population and therefore may be more likely to be attacked by the immune system. The condition probably results from a combination of genetic and environmental factors

column12: variations in genes responsible for immune system regulation
column13: such as PTPN22
column14: CTLA-4
column15: and IL-2RA

column17: potentially leading to the autoimmune attack on melanocytes
column20: including MC1R

column1: 989;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Muscular dystrophy ?;Muscular dystrophy (MD) refers to a group of more than 30 genetic diseases characterized by progressive weakness and degeneration of the skeletal muscles that control movement. Some forms of MD are seen in infancy or childhood

column8: orthopedic appliances used for support
column9: corrective orthopedic surgery
column10: and medications including corticosteroids
column11: anticonvulsants (seizure medications)
column12: immunosuppressants
column13: and antibiotics. Some individuals may need assisted ventilation to treat respiratory muscle weakness or a pacemaker for cardiac (heart) abnormalities.;Muscular dystrophy is a group of genetic disorders characterized by progressive muscle weakness and degeneration. column1: 992;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to Leigh syndrome ?;Leigh syndrome can be caused by mutations in one of over 30 different genes. In humans
column2: most genes are found in DNA in the cell's nucleus
column3: called nuclear DNA. However
column4: some genes are found in DNA in specialized structures in the cell called mitochondria. This type of DNA is known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). While most people with Leigh syndrome have a mutation in nuclear DNA
column5: about 20 to 25 percent have a mutation in mtDNA.  Most genes associated with Leigh syndrome are involved in the process of energy production in mitochondria. Mitochondria use oxygen to convert the energy from food into a form cells can use. Five protein complexes
column6: made up of several proteins each
column7: are involved in this process
column8: called oxidative phosphorylation. The complexes are named complex I
column9: complex II
column10: complex III
column11: complex IV
column12: and complex V. During oxidative phosphorylation
column13: the protein complexes drive the production of ATP
column14: the cell's main energy source
column15: through a step-by-step transfer of negatively charged particles called electrons. Many of the gene mutations associated with Leigh syndrome affect proteins in complexes I
column16: II
column17: IV
column18: or V or disrupt the assembly of these complexes. These mutations reduce or eliminate the activity of one or more of these complexes
column19: which can lead to Leigh syndrome.  Disruption of complex IV
column20: also called cytochrome c oxidase or COX
column21: is the most common cause of Leigh syndrome. The most frequently mutated gene in COX-deficient Leigh syndrome is called SURF1. This gene
column22: which is found in nuclear DNA
column23: provides instructions for making a protein that helps assemble the COX protein complex (complex IV). The COX protein complex
column24: which is involved in the last step of electron transfer in oxidative phosphorylation
column25: provides the energy that will be used in the next step of the process to generate ATP. Mutations in the SURF1 gene typically lead to an abnormally short SURF1 protein that is broken down in cells

column35: all of which impair mitochondrial energy production.  Although the exact mechanism is unclear
column36: researchers believe that impaired oxidative phosphorylation can lead to cell death because of decreased energy available in the cell. Certain tissues that require large amounts of energy
column40: seem especially sensitive to decreases in cellular energy. Cell death in the brain likely causes the characteristic lesions seen in Leigh syndrome
column41: which contribute to the signs and symptoms of the condition. Cell death in other sensitive tissues may also contribute to the features of Leigh syndrome.;Leigh syndrome
column43: is genetically heterogeneous with mutations identified in dozens of nuclear and mitochondrial genes. The most common genetic cause of Leigh syndrome are mutations in mitochondrial genes

column1: 993;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone ?;"Key Points

- Osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of the bone are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in bone.    - Having past treatment with radiation can increase the risk of osteosarcoma.    - Signs and symptoms of osteosarcoma and MFH include swelling over a bone or a bony part of the body and joint pain.     - Imaging tests are used to detect (find) osteosarcoma and MFH.    - A biopsy is done to diagnose osteosarcoma.    - Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.
Osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of the bone are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in bone.
Osteosarcoma usually starts in osteoblasts
column2: which are a type of bone cell that becomes new bone tissue. Osteosarcoma is most common in adolescents. It commonly forms in the ends of the long bones of the body
column3: which include bones of the arms and legs. In children and adolescents
column4: it often forms in the bones near the knee. Rarely
column5: osteosarcoma may be found in soft tissue or organs in the chest or abdomen.   Osteosarcoma is the most common type of bone cancer. Malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of bone is a rare tumor of the bone. It is treated like osteosarcoma.     Ewing sarcoma is another kind of bone cancer
column6: but it is not covered in this summary. See the PDQ summary about Ewing Sarcoma Treatment for more information.";Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone (MFH) are aggressive primary bone tumors with a high metastatic potential. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor in children and adolescents
column7: characterized by the formation of immature bone tissue. MFH is more prevalent in adults
column8: known for its rapid and invasive growth
column9: and its tendency to metastasize to the lungs and other bones. Both tumors exhibit similar clinical features
column10: including localized pain
column11: swelling
column12: and impaired mobility in the affected area. These tumors require prompt diagnosis and aggressive treatment
column13: typically involving surgical resection followed by chemotherapy and radiation therapy. The prognosis for both osteosarcoma and MFH is variable
column14: depending on the tumor stage
column15: location

column1: 994;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Joubert syndrome ?;"Joubert syndrome is disorder of abnormal brain development that may affect many parts of the body. It is characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the cerebellar vermis (a part of the brain that controls balance and coordination) and a malformed brain stem (connection between the brain and spinal cord). This gives a characteristic appearance of a molar tooth sign on MRI. Signs and symptoms can vary but commonly include weak muscle tone (hypotonia); abnormal breathing patterns; abnormal eye movements; ataxia; distinctive facial features; and intellectual disability. Various other abnormalities may also be present. Joubert syndrome may be caused by mutations in any of many genes and is predominantly inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Rarely it may be inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. Treatment is supportive and depends on the symptoms in each person.";Joubert syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a distinctive brain malformation called the molar tooth sign
column2: which is observed on brain imaging. This malformation affects the cerebellum and brainstem
column3: leading to a wide range of neurological problems. The syndrome is associated with intellectual disability
column4: hypotonia (low muscle tone)
column5: ataxia (impaired coordination and balance)
column6: and breathing difficulties. Additional features may include seizures
column7: eye movement abnormalities
column8: nystagmus (involuntary rapid eye movements)
column9: and liver or kidney problems. Joubert syndrome is caused by mutations in genes involved in neuronal migration and development
column10: and inheritance patterns vary depending on the specific genetic cause.;0.058;124.0;93.0;0.475;0.125;0.262;0.939;0.298;0.233;0.361

To keep your feet healthy       -  Examine your feet regularly    -  Wear comfortable shoes that fit    -  Wash your feet daily with soap and lukewarm water     -  Trim your toenails straight across and not too short       Your foot health can be a clue to your overall health. column1: 996;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to hypomyelination and congenital cataract ?;Mutations in the FAM126A gene cause hypomyelination and congenital cataract. The FAM126A gene provides instructions for making a protein called hyccin

column1: 997;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) Chediak-Higashi syndrome ?;"Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a condition that affects many parts of the body
column2: particularly the immune system. This disease damages immune system cells
column3: leaving them less able to fight off invaders such as viruses and bacteria. As a result
column4: most people with Chediak-Higashi syndrome have repeated and persistent infections starting in infancy or early childhood. These infections tend to be very serious or life-threatening.  Chediak-Higashi syndrome is also characterized by a condition called oculocutaneous albinism
column5: which causes abnormally light coloring (pigmentation) of the skin
column6: hair
column7: and eyes. Affected individuals typically have fair skin and light-colored hair
column8: often with a metallic sheen. Oculocutaneous albinism also causes vision problems such as reduced sharpness; rapid
column9: involuntary eye movements (nystagmus); and increased sensitivity to light (photophobia).  Many people with Chediak-Higashi syndrome have problems with blood clotting (coagulation) that lead to easy bruising and abnormal bleeding. In adulthood
column10: Chediak-Higashi syndrome can also affect the nervous system
column11: causing weakness
column12: clumsiness
column13: difficulty with walking
column14: and seizures.  If the disease is not successfully treated
column15: most children with Chediak-Higashi syndrome reach a stage of the disorder known as the accelerated phase. This severe phase of the disease is thought to be triggered by a viral infection. In the accelerated phase
column16: white blood cells (which normally help fight infection) divide uncontrollably and invade many of the body's organs. The accelerated phase is associated with fever
column17: episodes of abnormal bleeding
column19: and organ failure. These medical problems are usually life-threatening in childhood.  A small percentage of people with Chediak-Higashi syndrome have a milder form of the condition that appears later in life. People with the adult form of the disorder have less noticeable changes in pigmentation and are less likely to have recurrent
column20: severe infections. They do
column21: however

column23: difficulty with movement and balance (ataxia)
column24: reduced sensation and weakness in the arms and legs (peripheral neuropathy)
column25: and a decline in intellectual functioning.";Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the formation and function of lysosomes
column26: which are organelles responsible for cellular waste disposal and recycling. This defect leads to the accumulation of undegraded material within cells
column27: causing a variety of health problems. Common features of Chediak-Higashi syndrome include oculocutaneous albinism (reduced pigmentation of the skin
column28: hair
column29: and eyes)
column30: nystagmus (rapid
column31: involuntary eye movements)
column32: photophobia (sensitivity to light)
column33: recurrent infections due to impaired immune function
column34: and pancytopenia (decreased production of blood cells). The severity of symptoms can vary widely among individuals
column35: with some experiencing life-threatening complications and others having a milder form of the disorder. Treatment is supportive and may involve regular blood transfusions
column37: and management of infections. Bone marrow transplantation has been successful in some cases.;0.029;296.0;121.0;0.314;0.094;0.199;0.802;0.084;0.036;0.13

column5: are available to control these heart symptoms. In rare cases
column6: heart transplantation is needed.;Left ventricular noncompaction (LVNC) is a rare congenital heart condition characterized by the presence of prominent trabeculations and deep intertrabecular recesses in the left ventricle

column12: but it is thought to be caused by a defect in the formation of the ventricular myocardium during embryonic development. LVNC can be diagnosed using echocardiography

column3: or tender gums

column1: * Bleeding gums

column1: * Bad breath
* Loose or separating teeth
* Pus between the teeth and gums
* Gums that recede from the teeth
column2: making them look longer

column1: * Pain when chewing
* Tooth sensitivity

column1: 1001;gemini-pro;genetic changes;What are the genetic changes related to sitosterolemia ?;"Sitosterolemia is caused by mutations in the ABCG5 or ABCG8 gene. These genes provide instructions for making the two halves of a protein called sterolin. This protein is involved in eliminating plant sterols
column2: which cannot be used by human cells.  Sterolin is a transporter protein
column3: which is a type of protein that moves substances across cell membranes. It is found mostly in cells of the intestines and liver. After plant sterols in food are taken into intestinal cells
column4: the sterolin transporters in these cells pump them back into the intestinal tract
column5: decreasing absorption. Sterolin transporters in liver cells pump the plant sterols into a fluid called bile that is released into the intestine. From the intestine
column6: the plant sterols are eliminated with the feces. This process removes most of the dietary plant sterols
column7: and allows only about 5 percent of these substances to get into the bloodstream. Sterolin also helps regulate cholesterol levels in a similar fashion; normally about 50 percent of cholesterol in the diet is absorbed by the body.  Mutations in the ABCG5 or ABCG8 gene that cause sitosterolemia result in a defective sterolin transporter and impair the elimination of plant sterols and
column8: to a lesser degree
column9: cholesterol from the body. These fatty substances build up in the arteries
column10: skin
column11: and other tissues
column12: resulting in atherosclerosis
column13: xanthomas
column14: and the additional signs and symptoms of sitosterolemia. Excess plant sterols
column15: such as sitosterol
column16: in red blood cells likely make their cell membranes stiff and prone to rupture
column17: leading to hemolytic anemia. Changes in the lipid composition of the membranes of red blood cells and platelets may account for the other blood abnormalities that sometimes occur in sitosterolemia.";In sitosterolemia
column18: genetic alterations affect the activity or expression of proteins involved in the absorption
column20: and metabolism of plant sterols. The most common genetic cause is mutations in the ABCG5 and ABCG8 genes
column21: which encode sterolin-1 and sterolin-2
column22: respectively. These proteins are responsible for transporting plant sterols from the enterocytes back into the intestinal lumen
column23: preventing their absorption. Mutations in these genes can lead to increased absorption and accumulation of plant sterols in the body
column24: resulting in the development of sitosterolemia. Additionally
column25: mutations in the CYP7B1 gene
column26: which encodes the enzyme responsible for the conversion of plant sterols to bile acids
column27: can also contribute to the accumulation of plant sterols in the body and the development of sitosterolemia.;0.017;248.0;105.0;0.315;0.083;0.162;0.878;0.144;0.028;0.263

column1: 1002;gemini-pro;treatment;What are the treatments for Troyer syndrome ?;How might Troyer syndrome be treated? There are currently no treatments known to prevent or slow the progression of Troyer syndrome. Treatment aims to relieve symptoms of the disease and improve quality of life. Treatment for spasticity involves both exercise and medication
column2: especially baclofen (Lioresal)
column3: which is used either orally or by intrathecal pump. Tizanidine
column4: dantrolene (with precautions)
column5: and Botox have also been useful in reducing muscle spasticity. Daily physical therapy is recommended. Treatment may also include: Occupational therapy
column6: assistive walking devices
column7: and ankle-foot orthotics as needed Oxybutynin to reduce urinary urgency Antidepressants or mood stabilizers to manage emotional or mood disorders Additional information about the management of Troyer syndrome can be viewed on the GeneReviews Web site.;Troyer syndrome
column8: also known as cartilage-hair hypoplasia
column9: is a rare genetic disorder that affects bone and cartilage development
column10: as well as hair growth. Unfortunately
column11: there is no cure for Troyer syndrome
column12: and treatment focuses on managing the symptoms and providing supportive care. This may include growth hormone therapy to promote bone growth
column13: physical therapy to improve mobility and prevent joint problems
column14: and dietary management to ensure adequate nutrition. In some cases
column15: surgery may be necessary to correct skeletal deformities or address other complications of the condition. Additionally
column16: genetic counseling is recommended for affected individuals and their families to provide information about the condition and its inheritance pattern.;0.02;114.0;103.0;0.331;0.038;0.166;0.702;0.025;-0.056;0.105

column1: 1004;gemini-pro;information;What is (are) sialuria ?;"Sialuria is a rare disorder that has variable effects on development. Affected infants are often born with a yellow tint to the skin and the whites of the eyes (neonatal jaundice)
column2: an enlarged liver and spleen (hepatosplenomegaly)
column3: and unusually small red blood cells (microcytic anemia). They may develop a somewhat flat face and distinctive-looking facial features that are described as ""coarse."" Temporarily delayed development and weak muscle tone (hypotonia) have also been reported.  Young children with sialuria tend to have frequent upper respiratory infections and episodes of dehydration and stomach upset (gastroenteritis). Older children may have seizures and learning difficulties. In some affected children
column4: intellectual development is nearly normal.  The features of sialuria vary widely among affected people. Many of the problems associated with this disorder appear to improve with age
column5: although little is known about the long-term effects of the disease. It is likely that some adults with sialuria never come to medical attention because they have very mild signs and symptoms or no health problems related to the condition.";Sialuria is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the presence of excessive sialic acids in the urine. Sialic acids are a group of sugars that are found on the surface of cells and play a role in various cellular processes. In sialuria
column6: the body is unable to properly metabolize sialic acids
column7: leading to their accumulation in the urine. The condition can be caused by genetic defects or acquired disorders and can manifest with symptoms such as recurrent urinary tract infections
column8: kidney stones
column9: and growth retardation. Management of sialuria involves dietary modifications
column10: enzyme replacement therapy

column1: 1005;gemini-pro;inheritance;Is Von Willebrand disease inherited ?;Is von Willebrand disease always inherited from a parent? Most
column2: but not all
column3: cases of von Willebrand disease (VWD) are inherited. The majority of cases of type 1 and type 2A
column4: as well as type 2B and type 2M
column5: are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. VWD type 2N
column6: type 3
column7: and some cases of type 1 and type 2A are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Most individuals with an autosomal dominant type of VWD have an affected parent. However
column8: some individuals are affected due to having a new (de novo) mutation in the VWF gene that occurred for the first time in the affected individual. If the mutation found in the affected individual cannot be detected in either parent
column9: it is most often due to a de novo mutation but may also be due to germline mosaicism in a parent. Possible non-medical explanations which may be explored include alternate paternity or maternity (e.g.
column10: with assisted reproduction) or undisclosed adoption. There is also a separate
column11: rare condition called acquired von Willebrand syndrome (AVWS). This is a mild to moderate bleeding disorder that is typically seen in conjunction with other disorders
column12: such as diseases that affect bone marrow or immune cell function. AVWS is not caused by a mutation in the VWF gene and usually begins in adulthood.;Yes
column13: von Willebrand disease is typically inherited

column15: which is essential for normal blood clotting. Inherited forms of von Willebrand disease can be passed down in either an autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive manner. In the autosomal dominant form

column17: while in the autosomal recessive form

column1: 1007;gemini-pro;stages;What are the stages of Childhood Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma ?;"Key Points
- After childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.     - There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.    - The following stages are used for childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma:         - Stage I     - Stage II     - Stage III     - Stage IV

column1: After childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed
column2: tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.

column1: The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body is called staging. The results of tests and procedures used to diagnose non-Hodgkin lymphoma may also be used for staging. See the General Information section for a description of these tests and procedures. The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease. It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.    The following procedure also may be used to determine the stage:         -   Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells
column2: such as cancer cells
column3: in the bone. A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream. The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.

column1: There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.
Cancer can spread through tissue
column2: the lymph system
column3: and the blood:         - Tissue. The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.     - Lymph system. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system. The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.     - Blood. The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood. The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.

column1: The following stages are used for childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma:
Stage I     In stage I childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma
column2: cancer is found:            - in one group of lymph nodes; or     - in one area outside the lymph nodes.           No cancer is found in the abdomen or mediastinum (area between the lungs).       Stage II     In stage II childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma
column3: cancer is found:            - in one area outside the lymph nodes and in nearby lymph nodes; or     - in two or more areas either above or below the diaphragm
column4: and may have spread to nearby lymph nodes; or     - to have started in the stomach or intestines and can be completely removed by surgery. Cancer may have spread to certain nearby lymph nodes.              Stage III     In stage III childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma
column5: cancer is found:            - in at least one area above the diaphragm and in at least one area below the diaphragm; or     - to have started in the chest; or     - to have started in the abdomen and spread throughout the abdomen; or     - in the area around the spine.              Stage IV     In stage IV childhood non-Hodgkin lymphoma
column6: cancer is found in the bone marrow
column7: brain
column8: or cerebrospinal fluid. Cancer may also be found in other parts of the body.";"Childhood Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL) is classified into distinct stages based on the extent of tumor involvement at diagnosis. The most commonly used staging system is the St. Jude Staging System
column9: which categorizes NHL into four stages:

column1: Stage I: The tumor is localized to a single lymph node group or extranodal site.
Stage II: The tumor involves two or more lymph node groups on the same side of the diaphragm.
Stage III: The tumor involves lymph node groups on both sides of the diaphragm
column2: or involves extranodal sites with or without lymph node involvement.

column1: Stage IV: The tumor involves one or more extranodal organs or tissues
